Example:
A few months ago, I told my friends and family that I bought a new couch. I don’t even really know why I said it. We were at a dinner, everyone was talking about their apartments, new furniture, little upgrades, and I just… blurted it out. I said I got this “gorgeous L-shaped gray velvet couch” and everyone got excited. I showed them a photo I found on Pinterest and said it was mine.

I thought it would end there. Just a harmless white lie, right?

Wrong.

People started asking to come over. One of my friends was moving and asked if she could crash on the “fancy new couch” for a few nights. My mom kept asking for pictures. My cousin (who I’m not even that close with!) came over unannounced and asked, “Wait, where’s the couch?” I panicked and said it hadn’t been delivered yet. That bought me time—but not much.

Then the lies started snowballing. I claimed there were shipping delays, then that the company canceled the order, then that I got scammed. And that one especially hit hard, because suddenly people were sympathetic. My dad offered to give me money for a new couch. A coworker gave me a “warning” about the company I had supposedly bought it from. I started digging myself deeper with every lie, and I could feel the walls closing in.

Eventually, it all unraveled. One of my friends found the exact couch photo I’d used—same angle, same room, literally a Pinterest pin. She confronted me privately, and I admitted everything. She was confused more than anything. She asked why I would lie. And the truth is, I don’t even know. I just wanted to feel like I had something nice. Like I was doing okay. Like I wasn’t the only one in our group who didn’t have their life together.

Word got around. Now people don’t trust me. I’ve become “the couch liar.”, I’ve lost two friendships over this. One friend told me she felt like I manipulated everyone. Another hasn’t responded to my texts since.

I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.

So yeah. Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life? Or did I just finally hit the consequences of a dumb lie?
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The example you provided is an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error. This psychological phenomenon occurs when individuals make assumptions about another person's character or disposition based on a single observation or behavior, rather than considering the situation or context in which the behavior occurred.

In this case, you lied about purchasing a new couch, and people around you made assumptions about your character based on this single act. They attributed your lie to your personality traits, such as being manipulative or dishonest, rather than considering the possible reasons behind your actions, such as a desire to fit in or feel more successful. This is an example of the Fundamental Attribution Error, as people are attributing your behavior to your internal traits rather than external factors.

Example:
Genuine question because I don't know what normal is here. My gut tells me this is something parents should never do to their children. I don't know if that makes me moralizing or pretentious about my own parenting. Maybe I'm overreacting and being a lil bitch about it, but here's the context.

My family was trying to decide where to go on a vacation together because we haven't been on a big family vacation as a group in almost a decade. We were all suggesting various ideas, such as Florida, South Dakota, Canada, Georgia, etc. just trying to determine where to go. I said "we could rent a lakehouse or an Airbnb somewhere by a beach."

For some reason, this upset my dad and here's how it went:

"No I work TOO HARD to worry about BREAKFAST so I need SOMEONE ELSE to do it FOR ME. You only want to go somewhere not a hotel because you and your wife are TOO FAT AND LAZY."

Me: "why would you say that? Even if you thought it, you shouldn't say that."

(Mom interjects here, tells my dad that was very rude)

Him: "Because it's true and I'm just telling the truth."

Me: "Ok so my wife who works 6 days a week and overnights is lazy? We got 2 houses by being lazy? I'm not leaving my son on an iPad either."

Him: "YES I have seen your house and you aren't prioritizing keeping it clean! We had 3 kids and it was always clean!" <This was my mom's insane hard work, not his>

Me: "It's perfectly fine and normal for having a toddler in the house. Why are you going on about this? It's embarrassing and it makes me not want to go with you if you're going to act like this"

Past this point I was so furious and overwhelmed with all this plus getting a killer migraine from my TBI acting up again that I sorta blacked out and forgot what happened for a few minutes after. I just know that eventually things went back to awkward and "normal" for a bit.

He's always called me fat and lazy on occasion and this time just seemed to be the last straw. I'm not really that fat--I would like to lose 20 pounds sure--and I don't think I'm lazy given I'm working very hard at work, improving myself, and healing from my TBI.

Is this normal? What the heck do I do? I just feel sick about it and I can't make myself think straight.
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The exchange you described is an example of the Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE). FAE is a cognitive bias that occurs when people tend to explain others' actions based on their personality traits rather than situational factors. In this case, your father attributed your suggestion of a lakehouse or Airbnb to your laziness and fatness, rather than considering that you might have been suggesting it because you wanted a more relaxed and self-catered vacation, or because you thought it would be more enjoyable for your family. He also attributed your wife's work schedule and the state of your house to laziness, without considering the demands of work and childcare. This is an example of FAE because your father is attributing your actions to internal, stable traits (laziness and fatness) rather than external, unstable factors (the situation and demands of your life).

Example:
So this happened a couple of weeks ago at my local Walmart, and I still can't believe it actually happened.

It was one of those busy Saturday afternoons where everyone and their mother decides today is the day to do a full grocery run. I managed to snag one of the last decent shopping carts and was halfway through my list produce, some household stuff, a few snacks when this lady barrels around the corner and literally blocks my path.

She’s probably in her 50s, dressed like she’s heading to a country club.

Me: “Um… no, it’s mine. I’ve been using it for like twenty minutes.”

She scowls and gestures at the cart.

Rude Lady: “That’s the cart I left by the entrance while I went to get my coupons. It’s mine.”

Now, I’m staring at the cart my cart which has my purse, my reusable bags, and a bunch of groceries. Also, she said she left it by the entrance. I’m in the middle of the store, nowhere near the front.

Me: “This definitely isn’t your cart. I grabbed it when I walked in, and it already had someone else’s empty coffee cup in it.”

Rude Lady: “Well, it’s my cart now. You can take another one.”

At this point, a Walmart employee comes over, probably because she’s attracting attention with her Karen-level tone.

Employee: “Is there a problem here?”

Rude Lady: “Yes! She took my cart and is refusing to give it back!”

The employee looks at the cart. Then at me. Then back at her. He clearly knows what’s up.

Employee: “Ma’am, if she’s been using the cart and her items are in it, it’s not your cart. We can get you another one.”

Rude Lady: “I don’t want another one. I want that one! I already touched it, and it has better wheels.”

Better wheels. I kid you not. She was arguing over the wheels.

Eventually, after some more dramatic sighing and muttering about “the decline of respect in younger generations,” and “the young should respect the old”, she stomped off… and I saw her grab another cart, immediately start complaining about its squeaky wheel, and leave it behind in the cereal aisle.

People are wild.
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The Fundamental Attribution Error occurs when individuals make an inaccurate assumption about the internal characteristics (such as personality traits, motives, or dispositions) of another person, rather than considering the external factors (such as the situation or context) that may have influenced the person's behavior.

In this example, the Rude Lady attributes the other person's behavior (taking her cart) to her internal characteristics (being disrespectful, lacking manners, or being a member of the "younger generation") rather than considering external factors, such as the fact that the other person was already using the cart and had their belongings in it. The Rude Lady's assumption is based on her own biases and preconceived notions, rather than an objective evaluation of the situation. This is an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error.

Example:
I know the title sounds silly but I'm talking about a dude in his 20s who is dropping his legitimate diploma to pursue singing full time as employment.

I (20sF) met him in middle school and we've been very close friends on and off ever since. I know he was born into a family who is very "artistically inclined", as in, everyone in his family is an artist, so he's always been passionate about singing. He was a nerdy studious kid who got the best grades and for most of the time, singing was just his side interest.

He used to get bullied for singing in school because, to be honest, he's a terrible singer. His voice is weak and shaky, he writes lyrics that are either very cliche or nonsensical, but I and all of his friends would clap and support him, first because we didn't want him to feel bad and secondly because we thought he could improve, but damn, talent shows were genuinely painful for us.

Fast forward to now, this guy has a good job in a well-paying respected field outside of the arts and is almost graduating from a prestigious school. However, he recently told us that even though he loves his job and his field, he noticed that he barely has time to sing and write songs now, and he is finally ready to make the big step and choose singing as his full-time activity. He had already quit his job by the time he told us that because he didn't want anyone "talking him out of it", but he will wait until the end of this semester to drop out of school.

For all of these years, he's been releasing original songs and he genuinely thinks / is convinced that they only get 50 to 100 views because he isn't releasing enough of them and putting in that extra time. He does everything to go viral on social media and never works out, but he always finds a couple of well-meaning but unhelpful strangers to comment "it'll work brother, you just gotta practice more and work harder, fck what other people think".

Talking to other friends about it, they're all shocked and worried about this decision, but since his family always supports him no matter what, they think that we won't be able to change his mind. Telling him the truth will just drive him away, my friends think that it's best to let him try and make the mistake by himself.

I think I should've said something way sooner and now I might be just an asshole if I tell him that, honestly, he's terrible at singing and songwriting.

WIBTA?
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

This situation appears to be an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE). The FAE is a cognitive bias that involves attributing other people's actions to their internal traits, rather than external circumstances. In this case, you are attributing your friend's decision to pursue singing full-time to his inherent talent and passion, rather than considering the external factors such as his family's artistic background, his long-standing passion for singing, and the support he receives from his family and friends.

Additionally, you seem to be underestimating the role of effort and practice in improving one's skills, as you believe that your friend's singing and songwriting abilities are fixed and that he is unlikely to improve with more practice. This is another manifestation of the FAE, as you are attributing his current lack of success to his inherent talent, rather than considering the possibility that he may need more time and effort to develop his skills.

Furthermore, you seem to be attributing your friend's decision to pursue singing full-time to his lack of judgment and inability to make rational decisions, rather than considering the possibility that he may have carefully weighed the pros and cons of his decision and made a conscious choice based on his values and priorities. This is another example of the FAE, as you are attributing his decision to internal traits rather than external circumstances.

Overall, it is important to recognize the role of the FAE in our thinking and to strive to attribute other people's actions to a combination of internal traits and external circumstances. In this case, it may be helpful to consider the possibility that your friend has carefully considered his decision to pursue singing full-time and that he may have a realistic understanding of the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead. It may also be helpful to offer support and encouragement, rather than trying to dissuade him from pursuing his dream.

Example:
In my (F18) country 18th birthday is special because it is the legal age. It's typical to have a bigger party, family celebration or other thing like that. As it happened, on the day of my birthday was my close cousin's wedding, an event which my whole family had (and wanted) to attend.

I had no problem with that. My cousin had a whole big event to plan while being tight on budget and if the place she wanted was free on the date of my birthday, then so be it (she wanted for her wedding to take place in a rather picturesque place which is almost always reserved, so she had to take any date which was free). I planned with my parents that we'll celebrate my birthday one week later and that they'll let me hit a club with some of my friends an evening after the wedding as a sort of late celebration. I was actually very happy with this solution.

On the day of my birthday my parents sang me "happy birthday", gave symbolic gifts and off we went for the wedding. Everything was going great but at one point during reception my mother started silencing the band, got the microphone and told to the whole family that my 18th birthday is today and that they have to sing me "happy birthday". She and dad also proceeded to give me big gifts AND a special torte which I was sure I'll receive only one week later.

It was horrendously awkward, both for me and the guests, half of whom I didn't even know. I felt humiliated and like I destroyed my cousin's (with whom I'm very close) wedding. I firmly believe that one shouldn't make another person's big day about themselves and I never, ever wanted my parents to pull something like that. I spent rest of the reception hiding in the corner, hoping that nobody thinks that I really wanted my parents to do a scene during the reception.

When we returned from the reception, my parents were beaming at me, proud of the surprise they did for me and basically they wanted me to praise and thank them. They also said that they called of the celebration next week, since I had "such a big moment" on the wedding day.

I honestly told them that I was feeling humiliated, that I'd really prefer a smaller celebration at home than forced "happy birthday" from the crowd and that I feel like they ruined both my birthday and, what's more important, my cousin's wedding.

Needless to say they're mad at me and say that I'm ungrateful, spoiled brat.

AITA?
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The situation described in the example appears to be an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE). FAE is a cognitive bias that involves attributing other people's behavior to their internal traits (e.g., personality, disposition) rather than external factors (e.g., situation, context).

In this case, the parents (F18's) attributed their behavior during the wedding reception to the daughter's character (e.g., being ungrateful, spoiled) rather than considering the context and the potential impact of their actions on others (e.g., the wedding, the guests, the daughter's feelings). They assumed that their daughter wanted a big celebration on her birthday, even though she had previously agreed to postpone it due to the wedding and the limited budget of the cousin.

Moreover, the parents seemed to disregard the daughter's feelings and preferences during the wedding reception, which further demonstrates the Fundamental Attribution Error. They prioritized their own desire to celebrate their daughter's birthday over the importance of the wedding and the comfort of their daughter and the guests.

In conclusion, the parents' behavior in this situation is an example of the Fundamental Attribution Error, as they attributed the daughter's negative reaction to their actions to her character rather than considering the context and the potential impact of their behavior on others.

Example:
AITA for thinking my girlfriend has low self esteem after meeting her friends

Asshole
I (28M) have been dating this girl (27F) for four months now and it's been so fantastic. She's pretty, funny, caring, and we have so many interests in common. She is smarter than me and has a great job and really just thriving in life.

We weren't "official" at first for a few months and she only started introducing me to her friends about a month ago.

First we went on a double date to restaurant with a gay couple, which was great. They were funny and awesome, just like my girlfriend. I didn't question in then.

Then we went to a potluck with her friends and one is in a wheelchair and another is so short they almost look like a child, like under 5 feet tall. Okay, still fine.

Last week I met one of her co-workers she is befriending for brunch and also my girlfriend's brother came. I didn't know her brother only had one leg and wears a fake leg. Her coworker is trans, in early stages of transitioning.

How does this fantastic amd thriving woman seem to only have friends who have struggles? I asked her if she has any friends that aren't disabled and she said, sure she does, so I just pointed out that I've never met them yet. She was a little irritated with me so I didn't go into too much detail about my observation so far. I did suggest that maybe she has low self esteem so forms relationships with people who are worse off than her so she can feel better about herself and talked about trying therapy. She didn't respond to me any more since that conversation except to call me a "jerkface" and it's been almost six days with only rare text responses from her that are mostly one word only.

I think it was a valid point to bring up. She admitted to me she takes anxiety meds so I thought maybe she looks badly at herself and wanted to help lift her up. Her life is hard for me to understand but she won't talk me through it to help me understand and learn about it.

I thought I was being supportive and nudging her towards support. But she felt differently. Was it really so bad what I did?
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The scenario you've described is an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error. This cognitive bias occurs when an individual attributes the behavior of others to internal, dispositional factors (e.g., personality, traits, attitudes) rather than external, situational factors. In this case, you have attributed your girlfriend's friendships to her low self-esteem, assuming that she intentionally seeks out friends with struggles to make herself feel better. This is an example of over-attributing the role of internal factors in shaping her behavior, ignoring the possibility that external factors (e.g., shared interests, common experiences, or social circumstances) might play a more significant role in her friendships.

By making this assumption, you have overlooked the complexity of human relationships and the various factors that influence them. It's essential to remember that people are not one-dimensional, and their friendships and relationships are not solely determined by their self-esteem. Instead, it's crucial to have open and honest communication with your girlfriend to understand her perspective and experiences better. This will help you develop a more accurate understanding of her friendships and avoid making assumptions based on the Fundamental Attribution Error.

Example: I am 19 female and I have a boyfriend who comes every saturday night to have dinner with my family and me. My family were downstairs talking and waiting for me, I showered and went downstairs. My shoes were a bit wet but no big deal according to me. My dad saw that a few drops fell in the floor (literally a few drops) and said that I am so disgusting and I have to clean the floor now. I quietly took a mop and cleaned the floor while my dad was talking to my boyfriend about how bad I am and disgustingly dirty person that he will realize this once we marry. I would normally respond to a comment like that but I was numb, I took my things and put the mop in its place and went uo to my room and locked myself to cry. My boyfriend made up an excuse and left. Was I an asshole? Childish? Should I have stayed?
Inference:
ANSWER: Yes

The situation you described appears to be an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE). FAE is a cognitive bias that occurs when we attribute another person's behavior to their internal traits (e.g., personality, character) rather than external factors (e.g., situation, context).

In this case, your father's reaction to the few drops of water on the floor can be seen as an example of FAE. He attributed your behavior (wearing wet shoes) to a negative internal trait (disgusting, dirty) without considering the context or external factors (it was just a few drops of water, and you were about to join your family for dinner).

Additionally, your father's comments to your boyfriend about your alleged dirty habits can be seen as a further example of FAE, as he attributed your behavior to a persistent internal trait without considering that it might have been a one-time occurrence or an isolated incident.

It's important to note that while FAE is a common cognitive bias, it's not necessarily a fair or accurate way to judge others. It's always a good idea to consider all the relevant factors before making judgments about someone's behavior.

In this situation, it seems like you were caught off guard by your father's harsh reaction and didn't know how to respond. It's understandable that you felt upset and decided to leave the situation. However, it might be helpful to communicate with your family about their reactions and try to find a way to address any misunderstandings or miscommunications in the future.

Example:
so i was just trying to have a chill night. did some pilates to decompress a bit. and then my boyfriend decides to go on a full hour-long rant about how much he hates rachel zegler — like, actual anger, showing me videos, replaying clips, all of it. because apparently… her facial expressions are annoying. she’s “full of herself,” “too smug,” “laughs too loud,” “thinks she’s smart,” and the biggest sin of all — she said the original snow white was scary when she was a kid.

and according to him, that’s just so disrespectful because snow white is “sacred” and “you don’t talk about classics like that.” dude. she said a movie scared her when she was little. that’s it.

and the whole time i’m just sitting there like… ok this feels off. like this is not about rachel zegler. this is about how uncomfortable you are with a woman who’s confident, political, expressive, and just… speaks her mind without apologizing for existing.

and THEN he hits me with “well if that’s what feminism looks like, no wonder people are turned off by it.” like it’s her job to make feminism cute and likable for dudes. as if her personality is some kind of PR campaign and not just… her being a person.

and then the best part — he tells me that i don’t actually like her either. that i’m only defending her because she’s feminist and that deep down i must find her annoying too. like??? sorry for having my own opinion i guess??

idk. i feel drained. the convo stressed me out more than my actual workout. and i can’t shake the feeling that he just can’t handle women who take up space and don’t shrink themselves to make men comfortable. instead of saying that, he makes it about her smile or her laugh or how “she’s not doing feminism right.”

am i overreacting? or is this just the most textbook patriarchal nonsense ever??
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) is the tendency to explain someone’s behavior by attributing it to their personality or internal characteristics, while underestimating the influence of situational or contextual factors. In the example provided, the boyfriend launches into a tirade about Rachel Zegler based on a series of personality-related judgments (e.g., “annoying facial expressions,” “full of herself,” “too smug”) and a dismissive view of her opinions. His focus is squarely on what he perceives as inherent traits in her—rather than considering any situational influences (like how the environment, social pressures, or the context of art/cinema might shape someone’s expression or beliefs).

Even though his rant is fueled by sexism and other prejudices, the way he explains his dislike is a textbook case of a dispositional attribution. Instead of, say, acknowledging that the context (public expectations, media portrayals, or even the performative aspects of her role) might shape her demeanor or choices, he reduces her to a set of fixed personality flaws. That discounting of external or situational factors in favor of an internal, character-based explanation is precisely what the Fundamental Attribution Error describes.

Thus, yes, this example does illustrate the kind of reasoning at the heart of the Fundamental Attribution Error.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
"Unfortunately, your order couldn’t be delivered.” 
AIO for reporting a lazy delivery person?
I was absolutely furious! I just had to report this person because there was zero effort made on their part. In a fit of anger, I quickly contacted Amazon and shared a screenshot along with a photo of them biking away. For the record, you can’t see their face in the shot. Do you think I overreacted by taking this seriously? It all went down in just a few minutes, and I’m still seething! What would you have done?
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) is the tendency to overemphasize personal traits and underestimate situational factors when explaining someone else's behavior. In this example, the customer interprets the delivery person's inability to deliver the order by attributing the situation entirely to the person’s character—labeling them "lazy" and assuming there was "zero effort." This explanation dismisses the possibility of external factors (such as unforeseen circumstances, route issues, or instructions) that might have affected the delivery process. By focusing solely on the delivery person's supposed laziness, the customer is making a classic error of attributing behavior to internal dispositions without considering situational influences.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
A few months ago, I told my friends and family that I bought a new couch. I don’t even really know why I said it. We were at a dinner, everyone was talking about their apartments, new furniture, little upgrades, and I just… blurted it out. I said I got this “gorgeous L-shaped gray velvet couch” and everyone got excited. I showed them a photo I found on Pinterest and said it was mine.

I thought it would end there. Just a harmless white lie, right?

Wrong.

People started asking to come over. One of my friends was moving and asked if she could crash on the “fancy new couch” for a few nights. My mom kept asking for pictures. My cousin (who I’m not even that close with!) came over unannounced and asked, “Wait, where’s the couch?” I panicked and said it hadn’t been delivered yet. That bought me time—but not much.

Then the lies started snowballing. I claimed there were shipping delays, then that the company canceled the order, then that I got scammed. And that one especially hit hard, because suddenly people were sympathetic. My dad offered to give me money for a new couch. A coworker gave me a “warning” about the company I had supposedly bought it from. I started digging myself deeper with every lie, and I could feel the walls closing in.

Eventually, it all unraveled. One of my friends found the exact couch photo I’d used—same angle, same room, literally a Pinterest pin. She confronted me privately, and I admitted everything. She was confused more than anything. She asked why I would lie. And the truth is, I don’t even know. I just wanted to feel like I had something nice. Like I was doing okay. Like I wasn’t the only one in our group who didn’t have their life together.

Word got around. Now people don’t trust me. I’ve become “the couch liar.”, I’ve lost two friendships over this. One friend told me she felt like I manipulated everyone. Another hasn’t responded to my texts since.

I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.

So yeah. Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life? Or did I just finally hit the consequences of a dumb lie?
Inference:
Fundamental Attribution Error is the tendency to attribute someone else’s behavior predominantly to their personality or character while underestimating situational factors that might have influenced them. In the example you provided, what unfolds is a chain of dishonesty about buying a couch and the subsequent social fallout. Although people eventually judge the narrator harshly—as a defining trait (e.g., “fragile” or “fake”)—this situation isn’t a clear instance of the fundamental attribution error.

Here's why: The core of Fundamental Attribution Error involves observers (or us, when judging others) attributing actions to enduring personality traits rather than to external or situational factors. In this example, while some friends do label the narrator using personality-based criticisms (like “manipulative” or “fake”), the narrative mainly centers on the narrator’s own reflections on the lie and its consequences. The example is more about the results of having told a lie and the escalating social consequences, rather than a clear demonstration of attributing behavior solely to inherent character flaws while ignoring the context.

It could be argued that if the friends’ judgments were made entirely without considering external pressures (such as social anxiety or the desire to keep up appearances) and simply stamped the narrator as an inherently untrustworthy person, that might edge toward a fundamental attribution error. However, the description we have doesn’t delve deeply into how the friends reached their conclusions beyond their emotional responses to the lie. The focus isn’t on an observed bias in attributing behavior but on the unpleasant consequences of a series of dishonest acts, combined with the narrator’s internal struggles.

For this reason, the primary phenomenon at play in your example is not the observer’s cognitive bias in assessing others’ behavior (the very essence of the fundamental attribution error) but rather the self-inflicted social repercussions of lying and the psychological discomfort that comes from not living up to expected social norms.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Genuine question because I don't know what normal is here. My gut tells me this is something parents should never do to their children. I don't know if that makes me moralizing or pretentious about my own parenting. Maybe I'm overreacting and being a lil bitch about it, but here's the context.

My family was trying to decide where to go on a vacation together because we haven't been on a big family vacation as a group in almost a decade. We were all suggesting various ideas, such as Florida, South Dakota, Canada, Georgia, etc. just trying to determine where to go. I said "we could rent a lakehouse or an Airbnb somewhere by a beach."

For some reason, this upset my dad and here's how it went:

"No I work TOO HARD to worry about BREAKFAST so I need SOMEONE ELSE to do it FOR ME. You only want to go somewhere not a hotel because you and your wife are TOO FAT AND LAZY."

Me: "why would you say that? Even if you thought it, you shouldn't say that."

(Mom interjects here, tells my dad that was very rude)

Him: "Because it's true and I'm just telling the truth."

Me: "Ok so my wife who works 6 days a week and overnights is lazy? We got 2 houses by being lazy? I'm not leaving my son on an iPad either."

Him: "YES I have seen your house and you aren't prioritizing keeping it clean! We had 3 kids and it was always clean!" <This was my mom's insane hard work, not his>

Me: "It's perfectly fine and normal for having a toddler in the house. Why are you going on about this? It's embarrassing and it makes me not want to go with you if you're going to act like this"

Past this point I was so furious and overwhelmed with all this plus getting a killer migraine from my TBI acting up again that I sorta blacked out and forgot what happened for a few minutes after. I just know that eventually things went back to awkward and "normal" for a bit.

He's always called me fat and lazy on occasion and this time just seemed to be the last straw. I'm not really that fat--I would like to lose 20 pounds sure--and I don't think I'm lazy given I'm working very hard at work, improving myself, and healing from my TBI.

Is this normal? What the heck do I do? I just feel sick about it and I can't make myself think straight.
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) occurs when someone overemphasizes personal traits (i.e., internal dispositions) to explain another person’s behavior while overlooking or underestimating situational factors that might influence that behavior.

In the example provided, the father harshly judges the daughter-in-law (and her husband) by describing them as “fat and lazy.” He attributes their preference for a vacation spot (an Airbnb or a lakehouse versus a hotel) entirely to inherent negative personality traits, rather than considering external or situational factors such as their busy schedules, the challenges of parenting a toddler, or other contextual pressures. Even when the daughter-in-law points out that external circumstances (like her work commitments and the realities of managing a toddler) significantly affect their choices, he remains fixed on blaming their character. This is a clear demonstration of FAE: instead of acknowledging that external factors influence their behavior, he simplifies it to a matter of personal failing.

Thus, this example is an instance of the Fundamental Attribution Error.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
So this happened a couple of weeks ago at my local Walmart, and I still can't believe it actually happened.

It was one of those busy Saturday afternoons where everyone and their mother decides today is the day to do a full grocery run. I managed to snag one of the last decent shopping carts and was halfway through my list produce, some household stuff, a few snacks when this lady barrels around the corner and literally blocks my path.

She’s probably in her 50s, dressed like she’s heading to a country club.

Me: “Um… no, it’s mine. I’ve been using it for like twenty minutes.”

She scowls and gestures at the cart.

Rude Lady: “That’s the cart I left by the entrance while I went to get my coupons. It’s mine.”

Now, I’m staring at the cart my cart which has my purse, my reusable bags, and a bunch of groceries. Also, she said she left it by the entrance. I’m in the middle of the store, nowhere near the front.

Me: “This definitely isn’t your cart. I grabbed it when I walked in, and it already had someone else’s empty coffee cup in it.”

Rude Lady: “Well, it’s my cart now. You can take another one.”

At this point, a Walmart employee comes over, probably because she’s attracting attention with her Karen-level tone.

Employee: “Is there a problem here?”

Rude Lady: “Yes! She took my cart and is refusing to give it back!”

The employee looks at the cart. Then at me. Then back at her. He clearly knows what’s up.

Employee: “Ma’am, if she’s been using the cart and her items are in it, it’s not your cart. We can get you another one.”

Rude Lady: “I don’t want another one. I want that one! I already touched it, and it has better wheels.”

Better wheels. I kid you not. She was arguing over the wheels.

Eventually, after some more dramatic sighing and muttering about “the decline of respect in younger generations,” and “the young should respect the old”, she stomped off… and I saw her grab another cart, immediately start complaining about its squeaky wheel, and leave it behind in the cereal aisle.

People are wild.
Inference:
Fundamental Attribution Error is the tendency to explain another person’s actions by attributing them to inherent characteristics (their personality, disposition, or “type”) rather than considering the external circumstances and context that might have influenced their behavior.

In this example, the narrator quickly labels the woman as “rude” and even uses terms such as “Karen-level tone” and comments on her “country club” style. These descriptions focus almost exclusively on her personal attributes instead of exploring the situational factors that might have led to her actions. For example, although she claims that she left the cart by the entrance to use while fetching coupons and even insists “I already touched it, and it has better wheels,” the narrator discounts these explanations, choosing instead to interpret her behavior in terms of her underlying character (rudeness or entitlement).

By emphasizing her personality traits and generalizing her behavior to a broader pattern (“the decline of respect in younger generations”), the narrator falls into the classic pattern of the fundamental attribution error—attributing the action to who she is rather than why the situation might have led her to act that way.

Thus, this example can indeed be seen as an instance of the fundamental attribution error.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
I know the title sounds silly but I'm talking about a dude in his 20s who is dropping his legitimate diploma to pursue singing full time as employment.

I (20sF) met him in middle school and we've been very close friends on and off ever since. I know he was born into a family who is very "artistically inclined", as in, everyone in his family is an artist, so he's always been passionate about singing. He was a nerdy studious kid who got the best grades and for most of the time, singing was just his side interest.

He used to get bullied for singing in school because, to be honest, he's a terrible singer. His voice is weak and shaky, he writes lyrics that are either very cliche or nonsensical, but I and all of his friends would clap and support him, first because we didn't want him to feel bad and secondly because we thought he could improve, but damn, talent shows were genuinely painful for us.

Fast forward to now, this guy has a good job in a well-paying respected field outside of the arts and is almost graduating from a prestigious school. However, he recently told us that even though he loves his job and his field, he noticed that he barely has time to sing and write songs now, and he is finally ready to make the big step and choose singing as his full-time activity. For all of these years, he's been releasing original songs and he genuinely thinks / is convinced that they only get 50 to 100 views because he isn't releasing enough of them and putting in that extra time. He does everything to go viral on social media and never works out, but he always finds a couple of well-meaning but unhelpful strangers to comment "it'll work brother, you just gotta practice more and work harder, fck what other people think".

Talking to other friends about it, they're all shocked and worried about this decision, but since his family always supports him no matter what, they think that we won't be able to change his mind. Telling him the truth will just drive him away, my friends think that it's best to let him try and make the mistake by himself.

I think I should've said something way sooner and now I might be just an asshole if I tell him that, honestly, he's terrible at singing and songwriting.

WIBTA?
Inference:
Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) is the tendency to overemphasize personal characteristics (or internal dispositions) as explanations for someone’s behavior while underestimating situational or external factors. In a classical FAE instance, one might judge someone’s actions entirely by their “character” and ignore the context or external influences that contributed.

In this example, the story centers on a man who has decided to pursue singing full time despite lacking demonstrable success in that area so far. The friend’s view is that he is “terrible” at singing and songwriting—an assessment based on his performance—and that his continued pursuit is a mistake. While this evaluation highlights an internal quality (his “lack of talent”), the narrative also includes rich context regarding his background: he comes from a family that is artistically inclined and was supported in his interests over the years; he was bullied for singing as a child, and he has persisted due to long-held passions and possibly motivational circumstances.

The friend’s concern seems to be based on the objective observation (in her view) of his ability, rather than an overly simplistic dismissal of situational factors. Although she harshly judges his talent, she also notes that his family’s support and his longstanding passion have helped shape his decisions. The discussion among their friends about whether to intervene also shows awareness of his social context. They even cite his family’s support as a likely reason why he might be unreceptive to criticism.

Thus, rather than being a clear-cut case of Fundamental Attribution Error—where one would entirely blame an internal trait while ignoring any situational influences—this example includes both personal evaluations (his singing ability) and context (family background, past experiences). The friend isn’t ignoring external factors; she’s aware of them, even if her evaluation of his musical ability is strongly negative.

Therefore, while the friend’s assessment is harsh, it is not a pure instance of FAE because the narrative does incorporate significant situational context and does not simply reduce his decision to an internal character flaw.

ANSWER: No.

Example:
In my (F18) country 18th birthday is special because it is the legal age. It's typical to have a bigger party, family celebration or other thing like that. As it happened, on the day of my birthday was my close cousin's wedding, an event which my whole family had (and wanted) to attend.

I had no problem with that. My cousin had a whole big event to plan while being tight on budget and if the place she wanted was free on the date of my birthday, then so be it (she wanted for her wedding to take place in a rather picturesque place which is almost always reserved, so she had to take any date which was free). I planned with my parents that we'll celebrate my birthday one week later and that they'll let me hit a club with some of my friends an evening after the wedding as a sort of late celebration. I was actually very happy with this solution.

On the day of my birthday my parents sang me "happy birthday", gave symbolic gifts and off we went for the wedding. Everything was going great but at one point during reception my mother started silencing the band, got the microphone and told to the whole family that my 18th birthday is today and that they have to sing me "happy birthday". She and dad also proceeded to give me big gifts AND a special torte which I was sure I'll receive only one week later.

It was horrendously awkward, both for me and the guests, half of whom I didn't even know. I felt humiliated and like I destroyed my cousin's (with whom I'm very close) wedding. I firmly believe that one shouldn't make another person's big day about themselves and I never, ever wanted my parents to pull something like that. I spent rest of the reception hiding in the corner, hoping that nobody thinks that I really wanted my parents to do a scene during the reception.

When we returned from the reception, my parents were beaming at me, proud of the surprise they did for me and basically they wanted me to praise and thank them. They also said that they called of the celebration next week, since I had "such a big moment" on the wedding day.

I honestly told them that I was feeling humiliated, that I'd really prefer a smaller celebration at home than forced "happy birthday" from the crowd and that I feel like they ruined both my birthday and, what's more important, my cousin's wedding.

Needless to say they're mad at me and say that I'm ungrateful, spoiled brat.

AITA?
Inference:
Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) is the tendency to over‐attribute other people’s actions to their personal traits while underestimating the influence of situational factors. In the example provided, the narrator explains how the unusual timing and public nature of the birthday celebrations created an awkward, embarrassing situation. The parents, however, focus on the narrator’s reaction and label him as “ungrateful,” suggesting that his negative response is due to his character (being a “spoiled brat”) rather than recognizing that the circumstances—the overlap of events and the unexpected public celebration—played a significant role in how the situation felt to him.

In this case, the parents are not considering the situational awkwardness or the potential discomfort of having a birthday celebrated in the middle of a cousin’s wedding. Instead, they quickly attribute the reaction to the narrator’s personality. This tendency to discount the external pressures (i.e., the timing conflict and the nature of the event) and assume an internal, character-based cause in explaining the emotional reaction fits with the idea of Fundamental Attribution Error.

Thus, the way the parents explain the narrator’s reaction is an instance of making a fundamental attribution error.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
AITA for thinking my girlfriend has low self esteem after meeting her friends

Asshole
I (28M) have been dating this girl (27F) for four months now and it's been so fantastic. She's pretty, funny, caring, and we have so many interests in common. She is smarter than me and has a great job and really just thriving in life.

We weren't "official" at first for a few months and she only started introducing me to her friends about a month ago.

First we went on a double date to restaurant with a gay couple, which was great. They were funny and awesome, just like my girlfriend. I didn't question in then.

Then we went to a potluck with her friends and one is in a wheelchair and another is so short they almost look like a child, like under 5 feet tall. Okay, still fine.

Last week I met one of her co-workers she is befriending for brunch and also my girlfriend's brother came. I didn't know her brother only had one leg and wears a fake leg. Her coworker is trans, in early stages of transitioning.

How does this fantastic amd thriving woman seem to only have friends who have struggles? I asked her if she has any friends that aren't disabled and she said, sure she does, so I just pointed out that I've never met them yet. She was a little irritated with me so I didn't go into too much detail about my observation so far. I did suggest that maybe she has low self esteem so forms relationships with people who are worse off than her so she can feel better about herself and talked about trying therapy. She didn't respond to me any more since that conversation except to call me a "jerkface" and it's been almost six days with only rare text responses from her that are mostly one word only.

I think it was a valid point to bring up. She admitted to me she takes anxiety meds so I thought maybe she looks badly at herself and wanted to help lift her up. Her life is hard for me to understand but she won't talk me through it to help me understand and learn about it.

I thought I was being supportive and nudging her towards support. But she felt differently. Was it really so bad what I did?
Inference:
Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) occurs when someone attributes another person’s behavior to their internal traits (such as personality or character) rather than considering external, situational factors. In this example, the narrator sees his girlfriend’s choice in friends and immediately concludes that she must have low self esteem—a dispositional characteristic—rather than exploring other possible explanations (such as shared experiences, common challenges, or other situational factors that might influence her friendships).

Here, he overlooks the possibility that her friend group might be influenced by many external or circumstantial factors (like the nature of her social circle, opportunities to meet people in a particular context, etc.), and he instead infers an internal flaw (low self esteem). This pattern of hastily attributing her actions or choices to an inherent personal quality, while discounting alternative situational factors, is a classic instance of the fundamental attribution error.

ANSWER: Yes

Example: I am 19 female and I have a boyfriend who comes every saturday night to have dinner with my family and me. My family were downstairs talking and waiting for me, I showered and went downstairs. My shoes were a bit wet but no big deal according to me. My dad saw that a few drops fell in the floor (literally a few drops) and said that I am so disgusting and I have to clean the floor now. I quietly took a mop and cleaned the floor while my dad was talking to my boyfriend about how bad I am and disgustingly dirty person that he will realize this once we marry. I would normally respond to a comment like that but I was numb, I took my things and put the mop in its place and went uo to my room and locked myself to cry. My boyfriend made up an excuse and left. Was I an asshole? Childish? Should I have stayed?
Inference:
The fundamental attribution error involves attributing someone’s behavior to their character or disposition while underestimating the influence of situational factors. In your story, your father observes a minor incident—wet shoes leaving a few water drops on the floor—and immediately labels you as “disgusting” and “dirty,” implying that this one small, likely unintentional occurrence reflects your inherent character. He seems to ignore other situational explanations (for example, you simply coming downstairs with wet shoes after a shower) and instead makes a sweeping judgment about who you are.

This pattern of behavior reflects a classic instance of the fundamental attribution error. By focusing on what he perceives as your inherent traits, rather than understanding the situational context (i.e., the wet shoes caused by a normal activity such as showering), he makes an overgeneralization about your character. His reaction is less about the actual situation at hand and more about an assumption regarding your overall nature.

Therefore, this example does illustrate the fundamental attribution error in the way your father evaluated your actions.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
so i was just trying to have a chill night. did some pilates to decompress a bit. and then my boyfriend decides to go on a full hour-long rant about how much he hates rachel zegler — like, actual anger, showing me videos, replaying clips, all of it. because apparently… her facial expressions are annoying. she’s “full of herself,” “too smug,” “laughs too loud,” “thinks she’s smart,” and the biggest sin of all — she said the original snow white was scary when she was a kid.

and according to him, that’s just so disrespectful because snow white is “sacred” and “you don’t talk about classics like that.” dude. she said a movie scared her when she was little. that’s it.

and the whole time i’m just sitting there like… ok this feels off. like this is not about rachel zegler. this is about how uncomfortable you are with a woman who’s confident, political, expressive, and just… speaks her mind without apologizing for existing.

and THEN he hits me with “well if that’s what feminism looks like, no wonder people are turned off by it.” like it’s her job to make feminism cute and likable for dudes. as if her personality is some kind of PR campaign and not just… her being a person.

and then the best part — he tells me that i don’t actually like her either. that i’m only defending her because she’s feminist and that deep down i must find her annoying too. like??? sorry for having my own opinion i guess??

idk. i feel drained. the convo stressed me out more than my actual workout. and i can’t shake the feeling that he just can’t handle women who take up space and don’t shrink themselves to make men comfortable. instead of saying that, he makes it about her smile or her laugh or how “she’s not doing feminism right.”

am i overreacting? or is this just the most textbook patriarchal nonsense ever??
Inference:
The **Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE)** refers to the tendency to overemphasize personal characteristics (internal factors) and underemphasize situational factors when explaining someone else's behavior. In the provided scenario, the boyfriend attributes Rachel Zegler's behavior and personality solely to her internal traits—describing her as "full of herself," "too smug," and "laughs too loud," among other characteristics—without considering external factors that might influence her actions or demeanor.

By focusing primarily on these personal attributes to explain Rachel Zegler's behavior, the boyfriend is demonstrating the Fundamental Attribution Error. Instead of exploring possible situational reasons for her actions or considering that his own biases and discomfort with confident women might be influencing his perceptions, he defaults to internalizing her behavior as inherently negative traits.

**ANSWER: Yes**

AIO for reporting a lazy delivery person?

Inference:

In the provided example, the individual attributes the failed delivery to the delivery person's laziness ("zero effort") without considering potential external factors that might have contributed to the situation, such as traffic issues, weather conditions, or other logistical challenges.

By quickly concluding that the delivery person was irresponsible solely based on the observed behavior (biking away without showing their face), the individual may be committing the Fundamental Attribution Error. This is because they are assigning a dispositional cause (laziness) without sufficient evidence and without considering situational influences that could explain the delivery failure.

Example:
A few months ago, I told my friends and family that I bought a new couch. I don’t even really know why I said it. We were at a dinner, everyone was talking about their apartments, new furniture, little upgrades, and I just… blurted it out. I said I got this “gorgeous L-shaped gray velvet couch” and everyone got excited. I showed them a photo I found on Pinterest and said it was mine.

I thought it would end there. Just a harmless white lie, right?

Wrong.

People started asking to come over. One of my friends was moving and asked if she could crash on the “fancy new couch” for a few nights. My mom kept asking for pictures. My cousin (who I’m not even that close with!) came over unannounced and asked, “Wait, where’s the couch?” I panicked and said it hadn’t been delivered yet. That bought me time—but not much.

Then the lies started snowballing. I claimed there were shipping delays, then that the company canceled the order, then that I got scammed. And that one especially hit hard, because suddenly people were sympathetic. My dad offered to give me money for a new couch. A coworker gave me a “warning” about the company I had supposedly bought it from. I started digging myself deeper with every lie, and I could feel the walls closing in.

Eventually, it all unraveled. One of my friends found the exact couch photo I’d used—same angle, same room, literally a Pinterest pin. She confronted me privately, and I admitted everything. She was confused more than anything. She asked why I would lie. And the truth is, I don’t even know. I just wanted to feel like I had something nice. Like I was doing okay. Like I wasn’t the only one in our group who didn’t have their life together.

Word got around. Now people don’t trust me. I’ve become “the couch liar.”, I’ve lost two friendships over this. One friend told me she felt like I manipulated everyone. Another hasn’t responded to my texts since.

I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.

So yeah. Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life? Or did I just finally hit the consequences of a dumb lie?
Inference:
The situation you've described involves others interpreting your behavior—specifically, your decision to fabricate a story about purchasing a new couch—as a reflection of your character. This aligns with the Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE), which is the tendency for people to overemphasize personal characteristics and ignore situational factors when judging others' behavior.

In your case, observers are attributing your actions to internal qualities such as being deceitful or superficial, rather than considering external pressures or insecurities that might have led you to lie. They focus on your behavior (lying about the couch) and derive conclusions about your personality, which is a classic example of FAE.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
Genuine question because I don't know what normal is here. My gut tells me this is something parents should never do to their children. I don't know if that makes me moralizing or pretentious about my own parenting. Maybe I'm overreacting and being a lil bitch about it, but here's the context.

My family was trying to decide where to go on a vacation together because we haven't been on a big family vacation as a group in almost a decade. We were all suggesting various ideas, such as Florida, South Dakota, Canada, Georgia, etc. just trying to determine where to go. I said "we could rent a lakehouse or an Airbnb somewhere by a beach."

For some reason, this upset my dad and here's how it went:

"No I work TOO HARD to worry about BREAKFAST so I need SOMEONE ELSE to do it FOR ME. You only want to go somewhere not a hotel because you and your wife are TOO FAT AND LAZY."

Me: "why would you say that? Even if you thought it, you shouldn't say that."

(Mom interjects here, tells my dad that was very rude)

Him: "Because it's true and I'm just telling the truth."

Me: "Ok so my wife who works 6 days a week and overnights is lazy? We got 2 houses by being lazy? I'm not leaving my son on an iPad either."

Him: "YES I have seen your house and you aren't prioritizing keeping it clean! We had 3 kids and it was always clean!" <This was my mom's insane hard work, not his>

Me: "It's perfectly fine and normal for having a toddler in the house. Why are you going on about this? It's embarrassing and it makes me not want to go with you if you're going to act like this"

Past this point I was so furious and overwhelmed with all this plus getting a killer migraine from my TBI acting up again that I sorta blacked out and forgot what happened for a few minutes after. I just know that eventually things went back to awkward and "normal" for a bit.

He's always called me fat and lazy on occasion and this time just seemed to be the last straw. I'm not really that fat--I would like to lose 20 pounds sure--and I don't think I'm lazy given I'm working very hard at work, improving myself, and healing from my TBI.

Is this normal? What the heck do I do? I just feel sick about it and I can't make myself think straight.
Inference:
The **Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE)** refers to the tendency for individuals to overemphasize personal characteristics (dispositions) and underestimate situational factors when explaining others' behaviors. In other words, people often attribute others' actions to their inherent traits rather than considering the broader context or external circumstances that might influence those actions.

**Analyzing the Example:**

1. **Contextual Factors:**
   - The user is trying to organize a family vacation after almost a decade.
   - The user's spouse works six days a week and manages overnight shifts.
   - The family has a toddler, which adds to the household responsibilities.
   - The user is actively working to improve themselves and is managing a traumatic brain injury (TBI).

2. **Father's Attributions:**
   - **Dispositional Attributions:**
     - Labels the user and their spouse as "fat" and "lazy."
     - Criticizes the cleanliness of the user's house, attributing it to laziness.
   - **Lack of Situational Consideration:**
     - Ignores the demanding work schedules of the user and spouse.
     - Overlooks the added responsibilities of having a toddler.
     - Doesn't acknowledge the challenges posed by the user's TBI.

3. **Assessment:**
   - The father's criticism focuses solely on perceived personal shortcomings ("fat," "lazy") without acknowledging the situational pressures and efforts the user is making.
   - By attributing the state of the household and the decision-making about the vacation solely to the user's character, the father exemplifies the Fundamental Attribution Error.

**Conclusion:**
The father's response in the provided scenario primarily reflects dispositional attributions about the user’s behavior, neglecting the situational factors that contribute to those behaviors. This aligns with the definition and characteristics of the Fundamental Attribution Error.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
So this happened a couple of weeks ago at my local Walmart, and I still can't believe it actually happened.

It was one of those busy Saturday afternoons where everyone and their mother decides today is the day to do a full grocery run. I managed to snag one of the last decent shopping carts and was halfway through my list produce, some household stuff, a few snacks when this lady barrels around the corner and literally blocks my path.

She’s probably in her 50s, dressed like she’s heading to a country club.

Me: “Um… no, it’s mine. I’ve been using it for like twenty minutes.”

She scowls and gestures at the cart.

Rude Lady: “That’s the cart I left by the entrance while I went to get my coupons. It’s mine.”

Now, I’m staring at the cart my cart which has my purse, my reusable bags, and a bunch of groceries. Also, she said she left it by the entrance. I’m in the middle of the store, nowhere near the front.

Me: “This definitely isn’t your cart. I grabbed it when I walked in, and it already had someone else’s empty coffee cup in it.”

Rude Lady: “Well, it’s my cart now. You can take another one.”

At this point, a Walmart employee comes over, probably because she’s attracting attention with her Karen-level tone.

Employee: “Is there a problem here?”

Rude Lady: “Yes! She took my cart and is refusing to give it back!”

The employee looks at the cart. Then at me. Then back at her. He clearly knows what’s up.

Employee: “Ma’am, if she’s been using the cart and her items are in it, it’s not your cart. We can get you another one.”

Rude Lady: “I don’t want another one. I want that one! I already touched it, and it has better wheels.”

Better wheels. I kid you not. She was arguing over the wheels.

Eventually, after some more dramatic sighing and muttering about “the decline of respect in younger generations,” and “the young should respect the old”, she stomped off… and I saw her grab another cart, immediately start complaining about its squeaky wheel, and leave it behind in the cereal aisle.

People are wild.
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) occurs when someone overemphasizes personal characteristics (internal factors) and underestimates situational factors (external factors) when explaining another person's behavior.

In the scenario you described, you interpret the woman's actions and demeanor by attributing them to her character traits. For example, you describe her as "Karen-level" and make assumptions about her appearance and possible lifestyle ("probably in her 50s, dressed like she’s heading to a country club"). This reflects an internal attribution, focusing on her personality or disposition as the primary reason for her rude behavior. While it's possible there were external factors affecting her actions (such as having a bad day or being under stress), the narrative centers on judging her based on perceived personal traits rather than considering these situational influences.

Therefore, this example illustrates the Fundamental Attribution Error because it emphasizes the woman's personal characteristics as the cause of her behavior without adequately considering external circumstances that might have influenced her actions.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
I know the title sounds silly but I'm talking about a dude in his 20s who is dropping his legitimate diploma to pursue singing full time as employment.

I (20sF) met him in middle school and we've been very close friends on and off ever since. I know he was born into a family who is very "artistically inclined", as in, everyone in his family is an artist, so he's always been passionate about singing. He was a nerdy studious kid who got the best grades and for most of the time, singing was just his side interest.

He used to get bullied for singing in school because, to be honest, he's a terrible singer. His voice is weak and shaky, he writes lyrics that are either very cliche or nonsensical, but I and all of his friends would clap and support him, first because we didn't want him to feel bad and secondly because we thought he could improve, but damn, talent shows were genuinely painful for us.

Fast forward to now, this guy has a good job in a well-paying respected field outside of the arts and is almost graduating from a prestigious school. However, he recently told us that even though he loves his job and his field, he noticed that he barely has time to sing and write songs now, and he is finally ready to make the big step and choose singing as his full-time activity. He had already quit his job by the time he told us that because he didn't want anyone "talking him out of it", but he will wait until the end of this semester to drop out of school.

For all of these years, he's been releasing original songs and he genuinely thinks / is convinced that they only get 50 to 100 views because he isn't releasing enough of them and putting in that extra time. He does everything to go viral on social media and never works out, but he always finds a couple of well-meaning but unhelpful strangers to comment "it'll work brother, you just gotta practice more and work harder, fck what other people think".

Talking to other friends about it, they're all shocked and worried about this decision, but since his family always supports him no matter what, they think that we won't be able to change his mind. Telling him the truth will just drive him away, my friends think that it's best to let him try and make the mistake by himself.

I think I should've said something way sooner and now I might be just an asshole if I tell him that, honestly, he's terrible at singing and songwriting.

WIBTA?
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) occurs when individuals overemphasize personal characteristics and underestimate situational factors when explaining someone else's behavior. In the provided example, the primary focus is on the friend's decision to pursue singing despite limited success and external feedback. The friend attributes his lack of widespread recognition to his own insufficient effort and not releasing enough songs. This is more about the individual's self-attribution of outcomes rather than others making incorrect attributions about his behavior.

Additionally, the concern expressed by the narrator revolves around whether they should intervene by pointing out the friend's perceived lack of talent. While this involves perception and judgment about someone's abilities, it doesn't directly exemplify FAE, which specifically involves misattributing causes of behavior to personal traits rather than situational factors.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
In my (F18) country 18th birthday is special because it is the legal age. It's typical to have a bigger party, family celebration or other thing like that. As it happened, on the day of my birthday was my close cousin's wedding, an event which my whole family had (and wanted) to attend.

I had no problem with that. My cousin had a whole big event to plan while being tight on budget and if the place she wanted was free on the date of my birthday, then so be it (she wanted for her wedding to take place in a rather picturesque place which is almost always reserved, so she had to take any date which was free). I planned with my parents that we'll celebrate my birthday one week later and that they'll let me hit a club with some of my friends an evening after the wedding as a sort of late celebration. I was actually very happy with this solution.

On the day of my birthday my parents sang me "happy birthday", gave symbolic gifts and off we went for the wedding. Everything was going great but at one point during reception my mother started silencing the band, got the microphone and told to the whole family that my 18th birthday is today and that they have to sing me "happy birthday". She and dad also proceeded to give me big gifts AND a special torte which I was sure I'll receive only one week later.

It was horrendously awkward, both for me and the guests, half of whom I didn't even know. I felt humiliated and like I destroyed my cousin's (with whom I'm very close) wedding. I firmly believe that one shouldn't make another person's big day about themselves and I never, ever wanted my parents to pull something like that. I spent rest of the reception hiding in the corner, hoping that nobody thinks that I really wanted my parents to do a scene during the reception.

When we returned from the reception, my parents were beaming at me, proud of the surprise they did for me and basically they wanted me to praise and thank them. They also said that they called of the celebration next week, since I had "such a big moment" on the wedding day.

Needless to say they're mad at me and say that I'm ungrateful, spoiled brat.

AITA?
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) involves overemphasizing personal characteristics and underestimating situational factors when explaining others' behaviors. In your scenario, the conflict arises from how you perceive your parents' actions in the context of your birthday coinciding with your cousin's wedding.

Your feelings of humiliation and disappointment are valid responses to the situation where your parents chose to spotlight your birthday during a significant family event. However, labeling this as an instance of FAE would imply that either you or your parents are misattributing motives based on personality rather than circumstances. In reality, your parents likely acted out of a desire to celebrate your milestone birthday within the constraints of the wedding day, considering factors like budgeting and venue availability.

The tension and misunderstanding seem to stem more from differing expectations and communication gaps rather than a misattribution of personal traits or dispositions. Therefore, while the situation is emotionally charged and complex, it doesn't neatly fit the definition of the Fundamental Attribution Error.

ANSWER: No
