I thought I was being supportive and nudging her towards support. But she felt differently. Was it really so bad what I did?
Inference:
The Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE) refers to the tendency to attribute others' behaviors to their inherent personality traits while underestimating the influence of situational factors. In the scenario provided, the boyfriend observes that his girlfriend's friends include individuals with disabilities or challenges and concludes that she might have low self-esteem, suggesting that she forms relationships with people who are "worse off" to boost her own self-image. This interpretation primarily attributes her behavior to her internal characteristics (low self-esteem) without fully considering external factors that might influence her choice of friends, such as shared interests, compassion, or meaningful connections beyond what the boyfriend perceives.

By making an assumption about her self-esteem based solely on the nature of her friends, the boyfriend exhibits the FAE by focusing on an internal explanation rather than exploring potential situational reasons for her social circle.

ANSWER: Yes

Example: I am 19 female and I have a boyfriend who comes every saturday night to have dinner with my family and me. My family were downstairs talking and waiting for me, I showered and went downstairs. My shoes were a bit wet but no big deal according to me. My dad saw that a few drops fell in the floor (literally a few drops) and said that I am so disgusting and I have to clean the floor now. I quietly took a mop and cleaned the floor while my dad was talking to my boyfriend about how bad I am and disgustingly dirty person that he will realize this once we marry. I would normally respond to a comment like that but I was numb, I took my things and put the mop in its place and went uo to my room and locked myself to cry. My boyfriend made up an excuse and left. Was I an asshole? Childish? Should I have stayed?
Inference:
The **Fundamental Attribution Error (FAE)** refers to the tendency of individuals to overemphasize personal characteristics and ignore situational factors when judging others' behavior. In the provided scenario, your father notices that your shoes are a bit wet—a minor and likely situational detail. Instead of considering that your shoes might have been wet due to harmless reasons (like a spill or unexpected weather), he attributes your wet shoes to a negative trait, calling you "disgusting" and a "dirty person."

Here's how this aligns with FAE:

1. **Situational Factor Ignored:** The wet shoes could be due to various benign reasons that are out of your control or simply an accident.
2. **Dispositional Attribution:** Your father immediately links the wet shoes to your character, labeling you negatively without considering external factors.
3. **Overgeneralization:** From a minor incident, he makes a sweeping judgment about your character and even extends it to future predictions about your relationship.

By focusing solely on the observable behavior (wet shoes) and ignoring the possible situational explanations, your father exemplifies the Fundamental Attribution Error.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
On Mother’s Day I got and treated my mom to some of her favorite things and places while we spent the whole day together. I went to church with her along with the Mother’s Day Brunch. I also took her shopping and to her favorite expensive restaurant for dinner. In between stops, I gifted her a card, her favorite candies, favorite flowers, and a $200 gc to her favorite spa.

Sometime during the day, I posted on Facebook with a gif photo of an animated mother hugging her child that said “Happy Mother’s Day to all Moms. We love and appreciate everything you do.” I also wrote a paragraph about how thankful and grateful I am for my own mother and I wouldn’t be who I am without her.

About an hour after I get home from dinner, my mom texts me that she didn’t see her Facebook post from me. I told her that I did post to Facebook about Mother’s Day. She then says that she wants her own Facebook post and that if I don’t do it, she must not mean all that much to me. When she texted that I was taken aback. I responded are you serious? I took you out and treated you all day and gave you gifts all day, but none of that matters because of a Facebook post. I called her ungrateful and said we’re going to have another “time out” period. Since then she’s been calling everyone about how disrespectful of a daughter I am. Even my dad is trying to tell me that it’s okay for her to be upset and that I should just get over and excuse it because of what all shes done for me in the past.

Side note: I have had several time out periods with my mother. My mother had the tendency to say something rude or a dig at a person, but when she’s called out on it, she will play like she doesn’t remember what she said. Or will use tears to make it seem like you’re being mean to her.
Inference:
The example does show elements of black-and-white thinking. Black-and-white thinking, or dichotomous thinking, is a cognitive distortion where situations are viewed in extremes—either completely right or completely wrong, with no middle ground. In this instance, the mother’s reaction to the Facebook post represents an either/or mindset: if the daughter hadn’t made a Facebook post praising her on Mother’s Day, then the daughter must not truly care about her at all. This rigid, extreme perspective ignores the many nuances and other loving gestures that took place throughout the day.

Similarly, the daughter’s reaction—framing the day’s efforts as being completely devalued by the lack of a Facebook post—demonstrates a similar kind of all-or-nothing thinking. Both parties are caught up in a mindset where one small aspect (a social media post) becomes the sole barometer for the entire relationship or the totality of affection between them, rather than recognizing the complexity of their interactions and caregiving over time.

While there are many layers to their interaction and history, this specific exchange shows how, in the heat of the moment, both mother and daughter resort to extreme judgments rather than discussing the situation in a more balanced and nuanced way.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
Husband and I have been together for overn year, married for 25. He has always been blunt to the point of rude, calling a spade a f***ing spade.

His father passed away a month ago, and during the funeral planning and preparation I made a few gaffes.

He has a brother, whose wife is anything BUT incompetent. She works as an event organiser so she took on the task of organising the funeral book. I offered to organise the music, and slideshow. When giving my number to the Funeral director, I went blank and forgot it, looking quite foolish.

The following week, I sent a message to the WhatsApp chat that I hadn't checked and was full of spelling mistakes. I also missed the autocorrect that changed "slideshow" into "sideshow". However the service was beautiful and went off without an issue.

A couple of weeks later, my husband was angry because we were having issues starting my daughter's car. I was unable to start it causing more issues (battery) and he screamed about bring surrounded by "f***ing incompetent" people. When I asked if meant me, he ranted about my issues during the funeral planning.

I was upset at being spoken to that way and let him know it. He said sorry and put it down to stress and grief. This was two weeks ago. Last night he called me incompetent again because I had to get a password reset to access my work personnel file (it's a website that we hardly ever use, I may login once a year).

While all this does make me sound like a complete idiot, it should be said that we have 3 kids, and i take on most of the responsibilities for the household (except the bills). Out daughter are now grown, but when they were younger he travelled a lot and I was on my own for weeks at a time.

I am also good at my job, and have been given more responsibilities in the last year including being made a mentor to other employees.

However I can be a bit of an airhead and ditzy.

In the past, people have noted the way my husband speaks to me, and have said he is too harsh and I deserve better.

I tried to leave a couple of years ago, but he convinced me to give him another chance. But I wonder this time did I deserve to be called incompetent?

If you made it this far, thank you. I just can't tell what is fair criticism and verbal abuse anymore.
Inference:
Black-and-white thinking (also known as dichotomous thinking) is the tendency to see situations, people, or behaviors in only extreme terms—good or bad, competent or incompetent—without acknowledging any gray area or nuance in between. In the example provided, the husband repeatedly labels the wife as "incompetent" for isolated mistakes rather than considering context, external factors (like the stress and grief from recent losses), or her overall performance and contributions. His language does not allow for the possibility that everyone can have lapses or make slips, especially under stress. 

Furthermore, when something goes wrong—whether it’s forgetting a phone number or a minor issue with a car—the husband immediately ties these incidents to an overall assessment of the wife’s competence. This rigid evaluation exemplifies black-and-white thinking because it reduces her behavior to one extreme (incompetence), ignoring the many areas where she is effective (e.g., taking on most household responsibilities, managing a demanding job, and being entrusted with mentoring duties).

In summary, the husband’s use of absolute terms, his dismissal of any nuance regarding her abilities or circumstances, and his unwillingness to view her in a more balanced light are all indicative of black-and-white thinking.

ANSWER: Yes

Example: So my partner has always struggled with words and don’t have a way with words. He’s always said he admired my way with words. I studied literature and poetry. I’ve always tried to introduce him to the literature and poetry and tried to find ones I thought he would like. He still struggles but I never mind, I have only showed him those things for his enjoyment not to change him. To me they way is speaks is simply how she speaks. Recently he has discovered chat GBT and uses it to help with some things that need to sound more put together like resumes or letters to a boss (I used to help him with these). However yesterday when I got my birthday card I could tell most of it was ai generated. There was only one bit at the end that included a line that we say to each other that I knew was him. I don’t know how to feel. I’m sad that the card didn’t feel genuine or real. I felt like there was no effort into me. I wouldn’t have minded if it was completely all over the place with no proper grammar if it was from the heart. But it was a long heartfelt whole card long thing that I know was from chat GBT. He wasn’t home to see me open the card and I’m relieved because he was so excited for me to read it and now I feel like it’s because he was hoping I would think he improved but my face would have said it all. AIO. I feel like the reason he used it was to try and make me happy and maybe I should take that and appreciate it at the same time I would’ve preferred something that came from him.
Inference:
Black-and-white thinking is when someone views situations or ideas in extremes: something is either entirely good or entirely bad with no room for the gray areas in between. In this example, the narrator does compare two forms of expression—a genuine, human “messiness” filled with personality versus a polished, AI-generated note—and seems to imply that the human effort, even if imperfect, holds more emotional value. However, the narrator also acknowledges the good intentions behind using AI ("I feel like the reason he used it was to try and make me happy") and expresses conflicting feelings about the experience. Their internal conflict shows a recognition of both the value of the effort and the disappointment of lacking personal authenticity, rather than simply categorizing the situation as wholly one way or the other.

This blend of acknowledgment for the partner’s attempt to please while also mourning the loss of a truly personal touch displays nuance. Because the narrator is grappling with mixed feelings and appreciates multiple facets of the situation, it isn’t a clear-cut instance of black-and-white thinking.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I (39M), love giving gifts, I really enjoy putting thought and consideration into gifts for siblings, in-laws, nieces/nephews, and coworkers. For me, giving gifts isn’t about the price tag, it’s about showing the other person positive regard.

This evening, I visited my mother’s home for the family holiday (siblings, mother, in-laws, nieces/nephews). Just a sample of what I brought for people: stained glass window art, handmade porcelain bowls, and handmade silver jewelry.

I wasn’t expecting much tbh, I honestly do enjoy giving gifts, but if I had received no gifts, I’d have been fine with that. While I do enjoy receiving gifts, it isn’t a quid pro quo situation.

But these fricking family members did something worse. Like, a Starbucks gift card and a hot chocolate gift basket. The kind of presents that say “I put zero time/effort into this.” At best, I can bring these things to an office party or something like that.

When I noticed the incongruence, I just started feeling like a complete fool. As soon as I could slip away, I drove home. I didn’t flip out or say anything dumb, but I feel like I was being laughed at, the butt of some joke.

Now I’m home, just feel shitty and frustrated.

If someone reading this post has an alternative narrative that I can use, I’d love to hear it.

Thanks.
Inference:
The post shows a tendency to see things in an overly dichotomous way. The writer clearly distinguishes between two categories of gift-giving: one that involves a lot of thought, care, and even handmade or unique items, and another that’s seen as utterly lacking effort—a mere token gesture appropriate only for more impersonal occasions like an office party. This binary view overlooks any nuance regarding why someone might choose a simpler gift. For instance, there could be many reasons behind the selection of a Starbucks gift card or a hot chocolate basket that aren’t necessarily reflective of a lack of care or thoughtfulness. The perception here is that if a gift isn’t elaborate enough according to the writer’s personal standards, it automatically equates to disrespect or ridicule.

This sort of all-or-nothing judgment is a textbook example of black and white thinking. Instead of acknowledging a spectrum of possibilities and motivations behind gift choices, the writer opts for an extreme evaluation where gifts fall into two clear-cut and mutually exclusive categories. He doesn’t seem to entertain the idea that a person might have a different yet genuine way of expressing care or that circumstances might influence what gift they can give.

In summary, the post exemplifies black and white thinking by categorizing gifts into just two types—high-effort versus low-effort—with no room for any middle ground or alternative interpretations.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
AITA For causing a scene when my mom threw away my teddy bear?

Not the A-hole
Throwaway since I definitely don't want this to be linked to my main, even though I know my parents won't see it.

Edit: Thank you for the advice on how to clean stuff bears! If I'm unable to do it myself, I'll look in a company that can renew/restore stuffed animals:) Also, I'm asking if my overreaction makes me an asshole. Not for having a stuffed animal at my age and that I should "grow up." I will be disgrading those comments.

I(19f) am in college. I'm just finishing up my first year. 10 years ago, my first childhood friend gifted me a white teddy bear with a cute little black dress and a bow on her right ear. I always had her on my bed and I would take her on any vacations whenever I'm staying the night. It's been well known in my family that she's a sentimental item to me. My old friend and I don't speak anymore and we have lost touched, but I still kept the teddy bear.

In 5th grade, I was gifted a red, fluffy jacket from my grandma and I almost wore it everyday. That, too, became a sentimental item. However, after middle school, my mom decided to throw it away. I was extremely mad at her and didn't speak to her for a day or two. So this isn't the first time she threw away a sentimental item.

Now, yesterday, I noticed my bear wasn't on my bed as normal. I searched around and just couldn't find her. She didn't fall underneath my bed and she didn't get up and just walk away. I asked my sister, but she didn't know. So then I asked my mom and she said she threw it away. I instantly panicked. I went over to the trash and saw its been taken it. I went into the garage and looked through the garbage bin and found it inside a trash bag. I ripped it open and took her out. She was so dirty, gross, and smelled so horrible. There was a lot of liquid all over her furr. I started to break down and went back upstairs. I yelled at my mom for doing this. She knew how special she was to me and she thought it was a good idea to throw it away since I was too old to be having stuffed animals. I cleaned her off in the bathroom sink, but she's still gross. Her white coat is now stained and I'm absolutely furious. She isn't the same anymore. I was ranting, crying, and slamming doors shut. My mom called my dad and after he got home from work, he yelled at me for screaming at my mother. I got grounded and they took my laptop away. I only managed to convince them to keep my phone was because of work and I needed my boss and co-workers to text me. My sister even commented on how I overreacted.

The whole ordeal lasted a fee hours of me sobbing and trying to clean her to the best of my abilities. She's back on my bed, but my sister is annoyed, my mom is crying, and my dad is angry at me. I'm not too sure if I did overreact or not. Everyone in the household is annoyed at the tantrum I threw. I texted one of my friends and he has my back, but my whole family doesn't like me right now. I don't know what to do. I'm tired and exhausted from the judgemental stares. Did I overreact? AITA for causing an unnecessary scene and making it bigger than it is?
Inference:
Black and white thinking is a cognitive distortion where things are seen in only extreme terms, with no middle ground. It involves judging situations, people, or objects as either completely good or completely bad with no nuance.

In the scenario described, the individual places very high value on the sentimental object by remembering its pristine, original state—a cherished reminder of a special past. When the teddy bear is damaged (dirty, stained, and “not the same anymore”), the response is as if the object has lost all of its positive value, rather than acknowledging that it might still hold sentimental worth despite its imperfections. The idea that “if it isn’t perfect, then it’s ruined” is a form of dichotomous thinking. The emotional reaction is based on viewing the object in an all-or-nothing way—either it is exactly as it once was, or it has become entirely unacceptable.

Thus, by insisting on a binary evaluation of the teddy bear’s worth (pristine vs. ruined) without room for any middle ground, the example does exhibit characteristics of black and white thinking.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
So, my wife has this thing when she gets home from something special for example, a girls night out or a special occasion, and she wants me to ask her how it went as soon as she gets home.

Thing is.. it doesn’t cross my mind to ask right away but i’ll eventually ask maybe that night after kids go to sleep.

I told her that i’d try harder but that it’s hard for me to program myself to remember to ask as soon as she gets home. She told me that I shouldn’t have to try and that it’s “normal” to just ask. She feels like I’m inconsiderate.

I don’t get it… any thoughts? Does she deserve an apology?

UPDAT: We have good communication and a healthy relationship. It just seems that she wants me to ask about specifics the very first moment I see her almost as a reaction.
Inference:
In this example there is an element of rigidity in expectation. The wife seems to hold an “all-or-nothing” standard: either the husband asks about her special outing immediately upon her arrival, or he is seen as inconsiderate. By viewing the situation in these extremes, she leaves little room for nuance or individual differences in behavior (in this case, his natural way of processing or “programming” his own responses).

Black and white (or dichotomous) thinking is a cognitive pattern in which people categorize events, behaviors, or people into one of two categories with no gray area in between. Here the wife’s expectation—that asking immediately is not only desirable but the only acceptable way to show care—can be seen as a kind of black-and-white stance. If her husband does not act in that very specific moment, her conclusion is that he is inconsiderate, without entertaining the possibility that the caring intent might simply be expressed on a slightly different timeline (such as later that evening).

That said, the scenario might also simply be a difference in habits and communication styles. However, if she strictly adheres to the notion that “if it’s not immediate, then it’s inconsiderate” with no room for context or flexibility, it does align with the pattern of black and white thinking.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
I (F21) and my boyfriend (M23) of five years went to my favorite restaurant a few weeks ago. The meal was great and we both really enjoyed ourselves. It was perfect, a completely perfect dinner. I paid the $60 check and we went out to the parking lot to the car. I live in a huge college town along with that Saturday night being a senior ball so the town was busy.

We get back to the car and the cars surrounding it was parked exactly the same as they were when we went in. There were cars to each side of his car along with a truck parallel parked behind him at least two car lengths away. In front of him was the wall of the restaurant and behind him was the roadway in the parking lot then the parallel parked truck at a distance to clarify.

He starts to back out of the space and after a few tries he says he can’t do it. I say instantly I can spot him so he can get out. He says no and that it won’t help him because the truck behind him wasn’t there when he pulled into the spot and he was scared of hitting it. (It was there when he pulled into the spot.) He also added he doesn’t want others to see me spotting him like he can’t handle his vehicle. I say okay, I’ll go into the restaurant and find the owner of one of the car and ask if there was any way they would move so he could get out, didn’t want to but it was the only choice. He says no and kinda flips his shit (throwing his hat and sunglasses into the dash in frustration and also flooring it as if he’s going to hit the building then slamming on the break before he does so.) He calls his parents screaming about not being able to get out of the spot and even locked my door when I tried to get out of the vehicle to go get someone else to help/spot him.

Also when he is on the phone the owner of one of the neighboring cars comes outside. I try to tell him that we talk to her but he ignored me and kept complaining to his parents how there was no way we were getting out of the spot. The owner of the neighboring car gets in another car and leaves while my boyfriend gets off the phone and says: “guess we’re stuck.”

The screaming and me begging him to just let me spot him continues for 20 minutes and he makes a few jabs that I don’t have a license so I wouldn’t understand how he feels. At that point I was really upset and in tears. I had just taken him out to dinner and spent a pretty good amount of money for him to show his ass? Finally he lets me out of the car to spot him and within 2 minutes we are out of the spot.

Later that night I told him that he ruined the night and the dinner I paid for for absolutely no reason. I also added that he always has to find away to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks. He said that what happened was my fault because I should’ve have not spoken to him because it made him more frustrated when he was trying to find a “solution to the problem.” AITA here?
Inference:
Black and White Thinking involves viewing situations, behaviors, or people in extremes—for example, labeling an entire experience as entirely negative because of one problematic occurrence—and typically uses words like "always," "never," or "completely." In the provided narrative, the girlfriend states after the incident that her boyfriend "always has to find a way to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks." This sweeping generalization overlooks the complexities of their relationship and the specific context of that night. Rather than considering that this might have been an isolated or context-dependent incident, she moves to a more black-and-white evaluation of his behavior on dates in general.

This particular expression demonstrates black and white thinking because it reduces the boyfriend's behavior to a pattern of "always ruining things" without acknowledging any positive qualities or the multifaceted nature of his reactions. Instead of recognizing that the stressful situation might have provoked an extreme response, and that there could be nuances or maybe even valid feelings on his part, it all gets labeled in an all-encompassing, negative way.

Thus, yes, this example illustrates a cognitive style characterized by black and white thinking.

ANSWER: Yes

We love and appreciate everything you do.” I also wrote a paragraph about how thankful and grateful I am for my own mother and I wouldn’t be who I am without her.

About an hour after I get home from dinner, my mom texts me that she didn’t see her Facebook post from me. I told her that I did post to Facebook about Mother’s Day. 1. **Your Mother's Perspective**: She equates the lack of a Facebook post with a complete disregard for her, disregarding the considerable effort, time, and gifts you provided throughout the day. This perspective ignores the positive actions and focuses solely on the absence of a social media acknowledgment.

2. **Your Response**: You labeled your mother as ungrateful and decided to take a "time out," which is an extreme reaction that doesn't consider the complexity of emotions or the possibility of a misunderstanding.

Both sides are simplifying a multifaceted relationship and the day's events into binary judgments—either the Facebook post exists or it doesn't matter, leading to escalating tensions and misunderstandings.

**ANSWER: Yes**

However, they also acknowledge that the partner's use of AI might have been an attempt to make them happy and recognizes the presence of a personal touch in the final line.

This reflection shows a mix of emotions and an understanding that the situation isn't entirely one-sided. The individual doesn't completely dismiss the gesture but grapples with the balance between authenticity and effort. Therefore, the example does not strictly fit the definition of Black and White Thinking, as it doesn't solely view the situation in extreme terms but rather acknowledges its complexity.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
I (39M), love giving gifts, I really enjoy putting thought and consideration into gifts for siblings, in-laws, nieces/nephews, and coworkers. For me, giving gifts isn’t about the price tag, it’s about showing the other person positive regard.

This evening, I visited my mother’s home for the family holiday (siblings, mother, in-laws, nieces/nephews). Just a sample of what I brought for people: stained glass window art, handmade porcelain bowls, and handmade silver jewelry.

I wasn’t expecting much tbh, I honestly do enjoy giving gifts, but if I had received no gifts, I’d have been fine with that. While I do enjoy receiving gifts, it isn’t a quid pro quo situation.

But these fricking family members did something worse. Like, a Starbucks gift card and a hot chocolate gift basket. The kind of presents that say “I put zero time/effort into this.” At best, I can bring these things to an office party or something like that.

When I noticed the incongruence, I just started feeling like a complete fool. As soon as I could slip away, I drove home. I didn’t flip out or say anything dumb, but I feel like I was being laughed at, the butt of some joke.

Now I’m home, just feel shitty and frustrated.

If someone reading this post has an alternative narrative that I can use, I’d love to hear it.

Thanks.
Inference:
Yes, the example provided illustrates Black and White Thinking. This cognitive distortion is characterized by viewing situations, people, or events in extreme, all-or-nothing terms without recognizing any middle ground or nuances.

In the scenario, the individual places high value on giving thoughtful, handmade gifts, emphasizing the time and effort invested. When receiving gifts that are more generic, like Starbucks gift cards and hot chocolate gift baskets, he interprets them as a complete lack of effort and considers them inferior. This binary perspective dismisses the possibility that his family members may have different constraints, preferences, or intentions behind their gift choices. Instead of acknowledging that the gifts, while different, still hold value, he categorizes them as entirely inadequate. This all-or-nothing thinking leads to feelings of being undervalued and frustrated, without considering any positive aspects or alternative explanations for the choice of gifts.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
AITA For causing a scene when my mom threw away my teddy bear?

Not the A-hole
Throwaway since I definitely don't want this to be linked to my main, even though I know my parents won't see it.

Edit: Thank you for the advice on how to clean stuff bears! If I'm unable to do it myself, I'll look in a company that can renew/restore stuffed animals:) Also, I'm asking if my overreaction makes me an asshole. Not for having a stuffed animal at my age and that I should "grow up." I will be disgrading those comments.

I(19f) am in college. I'm just finishing up my first year. 10 years ago, my first childhood friend gifted me a white teddy bear with a cute little black dress and a bow on her right ear. I always had her on my bed and I would take her on any vacations whenever I'm staying the night. It's been well known in my family that she's a sentimental item to me. My old friend and I don't speak anymore and we have lost touched, but I still kept the teddy bear.

In 5th grade, I was gifted a red, fluffy jacket from my grandma and I almost wore it everyday. That, too, became a sentimental item. However, after middle school, my mom decided to throw it away. I was extremely mad at her and didn't speak to her for a day or two. So this isn't the first time she threw away a sentimental item.

Now, yesterday, I noticed my bear wasn't on my bed as normal. I searched around and just couldn't find her. She didn't fall underneath my bed and she didn't get up and just walk away. I asked my sister, but she didn't know. So then I asked my mom and she said she threw it away. I instantly panicked. I went over to the trash and saw its been taken it. I went into the garage and looked through the garbage bin and found it inside a trash bag. I ripped it open and took her out. She was so dirty, gross, and smelled so horrible. There was a lot of liquid all over her furr. I started to break down and went back upstairs. I yelled at my mom for doing this. She knew how special she was to me and she thought it was a good idea to throw it away since I was too old to be having stuffed animals. I cleaned her off in the bathroom sink, but she's still gross. Her white coat is now stained and I'm absolutely furious. She isn't the same anymore. I was ranting, crying, and slamming doors shut. My mom called my dad and after he got home from work, he yelled at me for screaming at my mother. I got grounded and they took my laptop away. I only managed to convince them to keep my phone was because of work and I needed my boss and co-workers to text me. My sister even commented on how I overreacted.

The whole ordeal lasted a fee hours of me sobbing and trying to clean her to the best of my abilities. She's back on my bed, but my sister is annoyed, my mom is crying, and my dad is angry at me. I'm not too sure if I did overreact or not. Everyone in the household is annoyed at the tantrum I threw. I texted one of my friends and he has my back, but my whole family doesn't like me right now. I don't know what to do. I'm tired and exhausted from the judgemental stares. Did I overreact? AITA for causing an unnecessary scene and making it bigger than it is?
Inference:
Black and White Thinking refers to a cognitive distortion where individuals perceive situations, people, or events in absolute terms—either all good or all bad—without acknowledging the nuances or middle ground. This type of thinking often overlooks the complexities of a situation and can lead to misunderstandings or heightened emotional reactions.

In the provided example, the individual is deeply upset about her mother throwing away her sentimental teddy bear. While her reaction is intense, it doesn't necessarily exemplify Black and White Thinking. Instead, it highlights a strong emotional attachment to a cherished object and the hurt caused by its disposal. She acknowledges that the bear was a significant part of her past and understands her parents' perspective to some extent, even if she disagrees with their action. Her struggle revolves more around emotional expression and managing differing viewpoints within her family rather than categorizing actions or people in absolutes.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
So, my wife has this thing when she gets home from something special for example, a girls night out or a special occasion, and she wants me to ask her how it went as soon as she gets home.

Thing is.. it doesn’t cross my mind to ask right away but i’ll eventually ask maybe that night after kids go to sleep.

I told her that i’d try harder but that it’s hard for me to program myself to remember to ask as soon as she gets home. She told me that I shouldn’t have to try and that it’s “normal” to just ask. She feels like I’m inconsiderate.

I don’t get it… any thoughts? Does she deserve an apology?

UPDAT: We have good communication and a healthy relationship. It just seems that she wants me to ask about specifics the very first moment I see her almost as a reaction.
Inference:
Black and White Thinking, also known as all-or-nothing thinking, involves perceiving situations in extreme, absolute terms without recognizing the middle ground or nuances. In the scenario you've described, your wife expects you to ask about her day immediately upon her return, viewing it as a "normal" and necessary gesture. While her expectation is clear and strong, it doesn't necessarily reflect Black and White Thinking. Instead, it highlights a specific communication preference within your relationship.

Your wife's reaction may stem from a desire for immediate connection and acknowledgment after her experiences, rather than viewing the situation in absolute terms of right or wrong. Additionally, you both acknowledge the effort and communicate openly about the issue, indicating a willingness to find a middle ground rather than seeing things in extremes.

Therefore, this example does not exemplify Black and White Thinking but rather showcases a common communication discrepancy that can be addressed through mutual understanding and compromise.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I (F21) and my boyfriend (M23) of five years went to my favorite restaurant a few weeks ago. The meal was great and we both really enjoyed ourselves. It was perfect, a completely perfect dinner. I paid the $60 check and we went out to the parking lot to the car. I live in a huge college town along with that Saturday night being a senior ball so the town was busy.

We get back to the car and the cars surrounding it was parked exactly the same as they were when we went in. There were cars to each side of his car along with a truck parallel parked behind him at least two car lengths away. In front of him was the wall of the restaurant and behind him was the roadway in the parking lot then the parallel parked truck at a distance to clarify.

He starts to back out of the space and after a few tries he says he can’t do it. I say instantly I can spot him so he can get out. He says no and that it won’t help him because the truck behind him wasn’t there when he pulled into the spot and he was scared of hitting it. (It was there when he pulled into the spot.) He also added he doesn’t want others to see me spotting him like he can’t handle his vehicle. I say okay, I’ll go into the restaurant and find the owner of one of the car and ask if there was any way they would move so he could get out, didn’t want to but it was the only choice. He says no and kinda flips his shit (throwing his hat and sunglasses into the dash in frustration and also flooring it as if he’s going to hit the building then slamming on the break before he does so.) He calls his parents screaming about not being able to get out of the spot and even locked my door when I tried to get out of the vehicle to go get someone else to help/spot him.

Also when he is on the phone the owner of one of the neighboring cars comes outside. I try to tell him that we talk to her but he ignored me and kept complaining to his parents how there was no way we were getting out of the spot. The owner of the neighboring car gets in another car and leaves while my boyfriend gets off the phone and says: “guess we’re stuck.”

The screaming and me begging him to just let me spot him continues for 20 minutes and he makes a few jabs that I don’t have a license so I wouldn’t understand how he feels. At that point I was really upset and in tears. I had just taken him out to dinner and spent a pretty good amount of money for him to show his ass? Finally he lets me out of the car to spot him and within 2 minutes we are out of the spot.

Later that night I told him that he ruined the night and the dinner I paid for for absolutely no reason. I also added that he always has to find away to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks. He said that what happened was my fault because I should’ve have not spoken to him because it made him more frustrated when he was trying to find a “solution to the problem.” AITA here?
Inference:
Black and White Thinking, also known as all-or-nothing thinking, involves viewing situations, people, or outcomes in extreme, absolute terms without acknowledging the nuances or middle ground. In the provided example, several elements suggest the presence of Black and White Thinking:

1. **Generalizations and Absolutes**: The individual states, "he always has to find a way to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks." This is a sweeping generalization, implying that the boyfriend invariably reacts negatively in all situations, which is characteristic of Black and White Thinking.

2. **Extreme Emotional Responses**: The boyfriend's reaction to a relatively minor issue (difficulty parking) escalates to throwing items, slamming brakes, and locking the door. Such extreme responses can indicate a tendency to perceive situations in extremes rather than seeing a spectrum of possible reactions.

3. **Lack of Middle Ground**: Both parties seem to adopt a stance where there's no compromise or understanding. The boyfriend refuses assistance outright, and the individual labels his behavior as ruining the entire evening, leaving little room for nuanced perspectives or acknowledgments of each other's feelings.

4. **Self-Defeating Narratives**: The boyfriend claims that her speaking to him exacerbated the situation, placing all the blame on her actions without considering his own role in escalating the conflict.

While the situation involves clear misunderstandings and emotional reactions, the use of absolute terms and the absence of balanced viewpoints align with the characteristics of Black and White Thinking.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example: My husband (M27) and I (F28) have been married for almost 4 years now, been together for 6 years. Do I have a roommate or husband? As more and more days go by I feel like I have a roommate more that a husband. I am and have been the sole income for our relationship and I come home and have to be the one who has to cleans, cooks, and take care of the animals. All while he is sleeping all day and chooses to play video games all night. I have asked for more help with the responsibilities of the house and he says he will but it only last for a week before we are in the same routine all over again. He did manage to get a job after 5 years into the relationship but all the responsibilities at home have still falling into my lap. I am still the only one paying our bills and don't ever have money for myself while anything he makes is used how he pleases. And on top of all that we are not intimate and any way anymore. It has gotten to the point if I try to initiate something in the bedroom and shrugs me off. I won't lie and say that doesn't hurt and has caused me to feel like I am the problem or no longer attractive in his eyes. But it has been almost 3 years now and I don't even think I would want to anymore even if he tried. I have gone back and forth about if I should stay in the marriage but have been to scared of the unknown of leaving to take the leap.
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy is the tendency to continue a course of action because you’ve already invested resources (such as time, money, or effort), even if that course isn’t leading to a positive outcome. In many cases, someone might argue, “I’ve put so much into this already, I can’t abandon it now,” which can keep them stuck in a situation that no longer benefits them.

In the example, the person explains that despite numerous issues with her husband and the household responsibilities that overwhelmingly fall on her, she has “gone back and forth” about whether to leave. Her hesitation about leaving is not based on an objective evaluation of current benefits versus future possibilities but rather on a fear of the unknown that comes with leaving a long-term commitment. Implicitly, her reference to how long the relationship has lasted – spending six years together with four years of marriage – suggests that she may be holding on partly because of the time already invested, even though the situation is no longer working for her.

This is a classic hallmark of the sunk cost fallacy: remaining in a decision or relationship simply because of the “sunk” investments (time, money, emotional energy) that have already been made, rather than assessing whether the current path is the best one moving forward. Even though a rational look would show that continuing in an unfulfilling, one-sided relationship is likely to have negative consequences, the weight of past time and effort makes it hard for her to break out of this cycle.

Thus, because her reluctance to leave seems influenced by not wanting her previous years together to “go to waste” and her fear of starting over (the unknown), this example does illustrate an instance of the sunk cost fallacy.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
so i was just trying to have a chill night. did some pilates to decompress a bit. and then my boyfriend decides to go on a full hour-long rant about how much he hates rachel zegler — like, actual anger, showing me videos, replaying clips, all of it. because apparently… her facial expressions are annoying. she’s “full of herself,” “too smug,” “laughs too loud,” “thinks she’s smart,” and the biggest sin of all — she said the original snow white was scary when she was a kid.

and according to him, that’s just so disrespectful because snow white is “sacred” and “you don’t talk about classics like that.” dude. she said a movie scared her when she was little. that’s it.

and the whole time i’m just sitting there like… ok this feels off. like this is not about rachel zegler. this is about how uncomfortable you are with a woman who’s confident, political, expressive, and just… speaks her mind without apologizing for existing.

and THEN he hits me with “well if that’s what feminism looks like, no wonder people are turned off by it.” like it’s her job to make feminism cute and likable for dudes. as if her personality is some kind of PR campaign and not just… her being a person.

and then the best part — he tells me that i don’t actually like her either. that i’m only defending her because she’s feminist and that deep down i must find her annoying too. like??? sorry for having my own opinion i guess??

idk. i feel drained. the convo stressed me out more than my actual workout. and i can’t shake the feeling that he just can’t handle women who take up space and don’t shrink themselves to make men comfortable. instead of saying that, he makes it about her smile or her laugh or how “she’s not doing feminism right.”

am i overreacting? or is this just the most textbook patriarchal nonsense ever??
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy happens when someone continues an endeavor or remains committed to a decision based solely on the resources (time, money, effort) they’ve already invested, even when new evidence suggests that the cost outweighs the benefits. In the example provided, the situation is a relationship conversation where the boyfriend is expressing anger and prejudice against a celebrity based on his own reasons. There isn’t an element in which someone is “throwing good money after bad” or refusing to change course simply because of past investments. Instead, the issue is about a problematic viewpoint driven by prejudices, not about continuing a course of action because of earlier investments.

Therefore, the example does not represent the sunk cost fallacy.

ANSWER: No

Example:
So we talked, and I cried a bit but explained how I felt, asked how he felt and if there was any more to this than he was telling me. He assured me there wasn’t, and he is just worried because he wants us & our kids especially to have the best possible day, and he just feels these things are red flags that we could be paying for a wedding that is sub par and he feels I deserve the best.

He isn’t always the best at communicating verbally, sometimes just saying stuff in a way that sounds really blunt and doesn’t realise at the time that some people (like me) won’t understand the meaning behind his words unless he says it which sometimes causes panic in me bc I need context.

My fiancé is very sweet, but he just kind of assumes that bc I know him, I must of course know that he would never get cold feet about marrying me and that he wants to give me the moon on a stick- and therefore there is no possible way I could misunderstand the words ‘I need to think about if I want to get married there’ as him suggesting we postpone due to cold feet…

Chat I love this big doofus :’) thank you for all your responses I appreciate them all

So, I will start by saying I love this man so much, for so many reasons. He is my muse, my confidant, he encourages me and builds my confidence, I have never felt so free as I do now bc he not only isn’t controlling but encourages me to go live my own life too so I go on holiday with my friends sometimes rather than just with him, plenty of nights out etc. He stands up for me, he is an amazing Dad to his and my kid, he is a bit fruity and gay which is great bc so am I, he is safe, he smells good, like I could list so many things I love about him. We don’t argue- we talk stuff out.

But last night he started looking through the latest email from the wedding venue that I forwarded and now- 3 months before the wedding, he is saying he’s unhappy with loads of stuff that he wishes he’d known before we booked it, such as the fact there aren’t toilets so they use portaloos (it is a historical site and listed so I understand this) and that the sound system only uses a spotify playlist. He asked how much I paid for the deposit (I paid that and he paid for other stuff we are going halves on the wedding) and suggested he might want to postpone it and find another venue. I feel like we’ve it’s too late to stop now because we’ve already put in so much. Chat I am DEVASTATED. I honestly don’t give a single care about the portaloos or the sound system. I just want to get married to him and have a great day. The kids are excited, I have invited guests, I have a suit, I have a photographer, everything is in place.

It’s a small budget wedding, it’s only our little family and some close friends.

I feel like he is being overly fussy, but he feels he’s being reasonable.
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy is when someone continues a course of action just because they have already invested time, money, or effort—even if the current benefits no longer justify that decision. In this example, the writer expresses that “it’s too late to stop now because we’ve already put in so much.” This phrase reveals the idea that previous investments (the deposits, preparations, contracts, etc.) are driving the decision to stick with the wedding plans, despite potential issues (like the lack of proper facilities and the sound system problems) that might warrant rethinking the event.

A clear hallmark of the sunk cost fallacy is the temptation to let irrecoverable past expenditures (both emotional and financial) dictate current decisions, rather than evaluating the future costs and benefits independently. In the narrative, the focus on the investments already made is used as a reason to proceed, even though it might be more rational to consider whether continuing with the wedding as planned will actually deliver the best outcome for everyone involved.

Therefore, this example does demonstrate the sunk cost fallacy because it shows a decision (or an inclination to decide) that is being influenced by how much has already been invested, rather than solely by what might be best going forward.

ANSWER: Yes

Example: Just like the title says. My husband invited over his friends for the previous Saturday. Only one person ended up attending. I spent Friday after work finishing the Tres Leches cake to go with the dinner he asked for. I sent home the guy with two pieces for himself and his fiancé. So far, it's Tuesday, and my husband hasn't even tried a piece. We were supposed to have some Sunday night while we watched our show. He kept putting it off, and then bed time came, so I asked him if I should just start the dishwasher or if we were going to have cake now, he said to just start the dishwasher. Last night we were going to have some after dinner. I went and got my own and some for my son, husband still won't try any. Not even a bite. I made almost a sheet cake for his friends, and he won't even try it. I told him last night how that made me feel after working so hard on it and he was apologetic and I asked him if he just didn't want any then I would stop offering, it's a soaked cake so it has to be eaten fairly quickly. He said that wasn't the case and that he just hadn't been hungry on Sunday or Saturday. I still don't quite understand why he couldn't have had a bite over the last 3 days that it's been made since he is eating the snickerdoodle cookies I made on Sunday no problem. Is this me having unrealistic expectations? I'm not wanting him to eat every piece, but he hasn't even had a bite since I made it, and I'm feeling very crestfallen. Thanks in advance, I guess.
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy refers to the irrational behavior of continuing with a decision or endeavor because of the resources (time, money, effort) that have already been invested, even when the current circumstances would warrant a change in course. Essentially, it is when past investments—which cannot be recovered—influence ongoing commitment, even if that commitment might not be logically justified.

In this example, the wife is upset because she put significant effort into making a Tres Leches cake and other baked goods, yet her husband hasn’t taken any of it, even though it was made for their planned time together. Her frustration stems from feeling that her work isn’t appreciated and that her husband is not reciprocating or even trying the items she prepared.

However, this situation does not clearly demonstrate sunk cost behavior. The sunk cost fallacy would typically involve someone continuing to invest in or do something solely because of the resources already spent, irrespective of the current benefits or desire to continue. For instance, if the wife were insisting on serving or eating the cake just because she already made it, even though she doesn’t want to (or even if it were unpalatable now), that might lean toward sunk cost reasoning. Likewise, if the husband were forcing himself to eat the cake just to avoid "wasting" the effort, that could be an example. 

In this case, the husband simply isn’t interested in tasting the cake because he wasn’t hungry or had other preferences, and he is making a rational decision based on his current state. The wife’s disappointment arises from unmet expectations and feelings of being underappreciated rather than from an irrational insistence on continuing something due to sunk costs. There isn’t a clear instance where either party is making decisions solely to justify previous investments.

Therefore, this example isn’t an instance of the sunk cost fallacy.

ANSWER: No

Example:
AITA for backing out of a 15-minute favor when it suddenly turned into an hour-plus-long ordeal?
Context: I work from home two days per week; today is one of those days. My wife's workday ends at 4:00, mine ends at 5:30.

Today, when my wife got home (about 4:15), she called me downstairs pretty much as soon as she came in the front door, to tell me that she's left her car running and would I please take it over to Discount Tire (DT) because one of the tires is low. (For those not aware, DT provides complementary inflation and (non-sidewall) tire repairs.) Without complaint, I agree because it's only a 5-minute drive each way, so I can just take a quick 15-minute break from work. I drive her car down there, and the guy tops up 3 tires, but on the 4th his machine won't dispense any air. I see him check it with a manual pressure gauge and then he comes up to the window and tells me that the tire is under 15 PSI, so he can't inflate it, but he says they're not very busy right now, they could repair the tire after only about a half-hour wait. I let him know that I need to get back to work, is there any way he can add even a little bit of air so I can maybe have my wife bring it back and wait? He says no, because it's "basically flat".

I call my wife to let her know this - my intention is to ask her if I drive back home, would she want to drive it back to DT now since the wait is relatively short (when they're busy, it can be a 2+hour wait), or if not I can at least make an appointment while I'm here. But I don't even get that far; she just wants me to stay and wait for it (even though she's already done working for the day). I tell her I really need to get back to work, and she gets very upset. I ask DT Guy what exactly he meant by "basically flat" and he said I'm at 13 PSI. I confirm with him that this means I'm not at immediate risk of the rim tearing up the inside of the tire if I drive it back home right now, so I tell my wife that I'm coming back and I'll be there in 5 minutes. As I'm driving home I get a couple of texts, including "I'll just have you drive me to work tomorrow and my car can sit in the f***ing driveway for all I care", but of course I don't read them until I get home.

I go inside to make another attempt to explain the specifics of the situation (I haven't even been able to tell her that it's not actually flat flat, yet), but she refuses to listen to a word of it, telling me she isn't going to listen to anything I have to say for the next week, and that I've "ruined everything".

I don't recall every word exchanged, but I know I did tell her that she was acting like a child, and in the end saying "Fine, I'll go back there and I'll just have to work until 8pm tonight!" to which she responded with "Good, I don't want to see you!"

I did go back to DT, and started composing this post while waiting.

AITA?

Editing to answer some common questions.

We do own a portable air compressor, it takes about 5 minutes for it to fill one tire, and it's in the trunk of her car.
Taking care of car things is my chore, but every time she's asked me to inflate her tires I have done so - I wasn't neglecting them. Also, the last time I put air in, I told her that she needs to make a trip to DT after work ASAP (because I work until 5:30 and DT closes at 6:00) to get that tire checked for damage, since it loses air faster than the others.
She is generally in charge of discretionary spending, so if the tire had needed to be replaced (repairs are free at DT), she would need to be there to compare the options available.
DT is the opposite direction from home as her work, that's probably why she didn't go there on her way home from work.
She didn't drive my car to DT because we only have one key for it, and it didn't occur to me to take it out of my pocket before leaving.
No, she is not like this all the time.
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy is a cognitive bias in which someone continues a course of action based primarily on the amount they've already invested—be it time, money, or effort—instead of reassessing their current best option. It’s when you “throw good money after bad” because you don’t want what you’ve already invested to go to waste, even though abandoning the endeavor would be the more rational decision.

In the example you provided, the husband initially agreed to do a quick 15‐minute favor. However, despite his clear work obligations and the increased inconvenience once the situation took longer than expected, he only decided to return to DT because his wife insisted and because it might have been socially or relationally necessary. His decision wasn’t driven by a deep-seated “I’ve already invested the time, so I must continue” mentality. Rather, it was more about trying to manage conflicting priorities: his need to work and his wife’s expectation.

There isn’t really evidence that he continued simply because he’d already invested time and energy. Instead, he was reluctant (knowing his work obligations were at stake) and communicated his needs. The pressure to stay came from his wife’s reaction, not from an internal, sunk-cost–based rationale.

Thus, this example doesn’t neatly fit the concept of the sunk cost fallacy. His behavior reflects a tension between responsibilities and relational dynamics rather than an irrational justification based solely on what he had already invested.

ANSWER: No

Example:
First off English is not my first language so forgive my mistakes if any.

Long story short, I have a friend let's call her H who proposed we get together, I was down and started saving up for Money to contribute. She told me we'd be 12 girls in total, most are her friends I've met before but we're not close but I was fine with it since I was looking forward to making new friends.

Days later we agreed on an amount to contribute per person, we also agreed that after everyone contributes we will make a budget together keeping in mind people's allergies or diet restrictions.

Then on Monday H texted me and sent a document of the budget? I was shocked but still opened it and I found a lot of the food there were things I cannot eat due to allergies and food restrictions. I asked her about it and she answered that the majority agreed with those things and that I should get over it and that i can just eat the other things there.

I thought about it and decided I wouldn't go, and here's were I was called the asshole,I asked for my money back since I wasn't going to be attending. H and her friends are calling me a petty person because me backing out will do damage to their budget and so on. But I don't see the problem here, so reddit am I really being unreasonable here??
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy is when someone persists with an endeavor or decision because they’ve already invested significant resources (time, money, effort) in it—even if continuing is not beneficial—simply because the cost is “sunk” and cannot be recovered. In this case, the person chose not to attend the event after discovering that the food items aren’t safe for their allergies, and they asked for their money back. This is a reasonable decision given that the arrangement changed in a crucial way for them, rather than sticking to the original plan solely because money was already spent.

On the other hand, the argument from H and her friends—that backing out and trying to recover the money will “damage their budget”—seems to imply that because the money has been gathered, the event should go on even if one person no longer benefits from it. This reasoning is closer to a sunk cost mindset, where the people involved are trying to force continuation because of the previously invested money, even though the original rationale (ensuring everyone’s dietary restrictions are respected) is now compromised.

However, the core decision you made (to withdraw and ask for a refund) is not an example of the sunk cost fallacy. You are not forcing yourself to continue solely because you’ve already put money into the plan. Instead, you’re acting on new information (that the event won’t suit your needs) and making a rational decision even if some of the money would now be “lost” to the overall budget if you continued. Thus, your decision is actually to avoid the sunk cost fallacy, not an instance of it. 

ANSWER: No

Example:
Recently, I [25m] was visiting some family, including my cousin [28f], who has a PhD in computer science— relevant later.

For some background info, growing up, I was always seen as the ‘smart’ one in the family, which she resented me for due to wanting that title herself. She was a lot more studious than I am, and got a PhD, whereas I ended my schooling after my bachelors due to not liking specialization. I’m currently a filmmaker that has been surprisingly successful, and she works at a hedge fund doing quant work.

Regarding my opinion on her, I think she’s quite smart in her niche. However, she lacks what I see as traits of a more generalized intelligence— being quick witted, adaptable, open minded, and exploratory. Every truly intelligent person I’ve ever met has been funny and a genuinely interesting person, and I don’t see that in her. She’s more what I would call a ‘sweat’— she works hard, and is talented in her niche, but lacking the originality to be truly intelligent.

Anyhow, when I visited my family, she began needling me about how now she has her PhD (the last time I had seen her, she was still in her program) I had to admit that she was smarter than me. I shrugged it off mostly, but she began demanding that I ‘admit’ she’s smarter than her, so I responded that PhD or no PhD, I don’t think she’s exceptionally intelligent or more intelligent than I am.

This caused her to fly off the handle, and she started yelling that I was just a jealous AH who couldn’t accept that a woman was smarter than her. She furthered that she was confident and secure in the fact she was more intelligent than I was.

I pointed out that if she was so secure in her own intelligence, my disputing it wouldn’t bother her that much, and the fact she needed me to validate her shows she’s not particularly confident. She just got angry again, called me an AH, and stormed off.

AITA? I think she shouldn’t have started a conversation about her intelligence if She just wanted me to sing her praises
Inference:
The sunk cost fallacy occurs when someone continues an endeavor or decision because of the cumulative prior investment (time, money, effort), even if continuing is not the most rational choice. In the story you provided, the exchange between you and your cousin revolves around issues of pride, validation, and differing views on intelligence. There is a dispute about who is smarter, with her seeking validation and you objecting to outright praise. Despite the emotional intensity, the discussion is about personal reputation and comparison—it isn’t about making a decision or persisting in an action solely because of past investments.

In this case, neither you nor your cousin is justifying your actions by referring to already invested resources or by insisting on continuing a behavior simply because you have previously committed to it. The disagreement is rooted in assumptions about intelligence and self-esteem rather than any form of economic or rational decision-making that would justify irrational continuation due to previous costs. Hence, this scenario does not illustrate the sunk cost fallacy.

ANSWER: No

The sunk cost fallacy involves continuing a course of action mainly because of the resources (time, money, effort) already invested, even if that course is no longer in one’s best interest. It’s about letting past investments dictate current or future decisions.

In the scenario you described, the issues arise from emotional abuse and conflict between family members, rather than from a decision based on past investments. Thus, this situation isn’t an example of the sunk cost fallacy—it’s a situation that involves complex interpersonal dynamics and the impact of emotional abuse.

Example: My husband (M27) and I (F28) have been married for almost 4 years now, been together for 6 years. Do I have a roommate or husband? As more and more days go by I feel like I have a roommate more that a husband. I am and have been the sole income for our relationship and I come home and have to be the one who has to cleans, cooks, and take care of the animals. All while he is sleeping all day and chooses to play video games all night. I have asked for more help with the responsibilities of the house and he says he will but it only last for a week before we are in the same routine all over again. He did manage to get a job after 5 years into the relationship but all the responsibilities at home have still falling into my lap. I am still the only one paying our bills and don't ever have money for myself while anything he makes is used how he pleases. And on top of all that we are not intimate and any way anymore. It has gotten to the point if I try to initiate something in the bedroom and shrugs me off. I won't lie and say that doesn't hurt and has caused me to feel like I am the problem or no longer attractive in his eyes. But it has been almost 3 years now and I don't even think I would want to anymore even if he tried. I have gone back and forth about if I should stay in the marriage but have been to scared of the unknown of leaving to take the leap.
Inference:
The **Sunk Cost Fallacy** occurs when individuals continue a behavior or endeavor as a result of previously invested resources (time, money, effort) rather than evaluating the current and future benefits and costs. This cognitive bias can lead to irrational decision-making, where past investments unduly influence present choices, even when those past investments are no longer relevant or recoverable.

In the scenario you've described, several elements suggest that the Sunk Cost Fallacy may be at play:

1. **Length of Relationship:** Being together for six years and married for almost four years represents a significant investment of time and emotional energy. This long-term commitment can make it challenging to consider ending the relationship, even if it isn't fulfilling.

2. **Fear of the Unknown:** You mention being scared of leaving due to the uncertainty of what lies beyond the current situation. This fear can cause individuals to cling to the relationship, focusing on the time already spent rather than assessing whether staying is beneficial for your well-being.

3. **Continuous Investment:** Despite ongoing issues—such as unequal distribution of responsibilities, financial strain, lack of intimacy, and declining relationship satisfaction—you've remained in the marriage. The continual hope that things will change ("he says he will but it only lasts for a week") indicates a persistent investment in the relationship's future, possibly overshadowing the present dissatisfaction.

4. **Emotional Attachment:** Emotional investments and the desire to maintain the relationship can make it difficult to objectively evaluate its viability. This attachment can lead to prioritizing the preservation of the relationship over personal happiness and fulfillment.

While it's natural to feel conflicted about leaving a long-term relationship, especially one with substantial shared history, it's essential to assess whether the decision to stay is based on the genuine hope for positive change or primarily on the desire to justify the time already invested. If the latter is true, it may indeed be an example of the Sunk Cost Fallacy.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
so i was just trying to have a chill night. did some pilates to decompress a bit. and then my boyfriend decides to go on a full hour-long rant about how much he hates rachel zegler — like, actual anger, showing me videos, replaying clips, all of it. because apparently… her facial expressions are annoying. she’s “full of herself,” “too smug,” “laughs too loud,” “thinks she’s smart,” and the biggest sin of all — she said the original snow white was scary when she was a kid.

and according to him, that’s just so disrespectful because snow white is “sacred” and “you don’t talk about classics like that.” dude. she said a movie scared her when she was little. that’s it.

and the whole time i’m just sitting there like… ok this feels off. like this is not about rachel zegler. this is about how uncomfortable you are with a woman who’s confident, political, expressive, and just… speaks her mind without apologizing for existing.

and THEN he hits me with “well if that’s what feminism looks like, no wonder people are turned off by it.” like it’s her job to make feminism cute and likable for dudes. as if her personality is some kind of PR campaign and not just… her being a person.

and then the best part — he tells me that i don’t actually like her either. that i’m only defending her because she’s feminist and that deep down i must find her annoying too. like??? sorry for having my own opinion i guess??

idk. i feel drained. the convo stressed me out more than my actual workout. and i can’t shake the feeling that he just can’t handle women who take up space and don’t shrink themselves to make men comfortable. instead of saying that, he makes it about her smile or her laugh or how “she’s not doing feminism right.”

am i overreacting? or is this just the most textbook patriarchal nonsense ever??
Inference:
The scenario you've described revolves around a heated conversation between you and your boyfriend regarding Rachel Zegler and broader issues related to feminism and personal expressions. The crux of the interaction seems to center on your boyfriend's inability to accept confident and expressive women, projecting his discomfort onto Rachel Zegler's personality and by extension, onto you.

**Sunk Cost Fallacy Explained:**
The sunk cost fallacy occurs when an individual continues a behavior or endeavor as a result of previously invested resources (time, money, effort), rather than cutting their losses because the current costs outweigh the benefits.

**Analysis of the Scenario:**
In the situation you presented, there is no indication that either you or your boyfriend are continuing a course of action based on previously invested resources. Instead, the interaction appears to be more about differing opinions, expectations regarding feminism, and personal discomfort with certain traits. Your boyfriend is expressing his frustrations and attempting to influence your perception of Rachel Zegler, but this doesn't involve continuing an endeavor due to past investments.

There might be other cognitive biases at play, such as confirmation bias or projection, but the sunk cost fallacy doesn't seem to fit this context.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
So we talked, and I cried a bit but explained how I felt, asked how he felt and if there was any more to this than he was telling me. He assured me there wasn’t, and he is just worried because he wants us & our kids especially to have the best possible day, and he just feels these things are red flags that we could be paying for a wedding that is sub par and he feels I deserve the best.

He isn’t always the best at communicating verbally, sometimes just saying stuff in a way that sounds really blunt and doesn’t realise at the time that some people (like me) won’t understand the meaning behind his words unless he says it which sometimes causes panic in me bc I need context.

My fiancé is very sweet, but he just kind of assumes that bc I know him, I must of course know that he would never get cold feet about marrying me and that he wants to give me the moon on a stick- and therefore there is no possible way I could misunderstand the words ‘I need to think about if I want to get married there’ as him suggesting we postpone due to cold feet…

Chat I love this big doofus :’) thank you for all your responses I appreciate them all

So, I will start by saying I love this man so much, for so many reasons. He is my muse, my confidant, he encourages me and builds my confidence, I have never felt so free as I do now bc he not only isn’t controlling but encourages me to go live my own life too so I go on holiday with my friends sometimes rather than just with him, plenty of nights out etc. He stands up for me, he is an amazing Dad to his and my kid, he is a bit fruity and gay which is great bc so am I, he is safe, he smells good, like I could list so many things I love about him. We don’t argue- we talk stuff out.

But last night he started looking through the latest email from the wedding venue that I forwarded and now- 3 months before the wedding, he is saying he’s unhappy with loads of stuff that he wishes he’d known before we booked it, such as the fact there aren’t toilets so they use portaloos (it is a historical site and listed so I understand this) and that the sound system only uses a spotify playlist. He asked how much I paid for the deposit (I paid that and he paid for other stuff we are going halves on the wedding) and suggested he might want to postpone it and find another venue. I feel like we’ve it’s too late to stop now because we’ve already put in so much. Chat I am DEVASTATED. I honestly don’t give a single care about the portaloos or the sound system. I just want to get married to him and have a great day. The kids are excited, I have invited guests, I have a suit, I have a photographer, everything is in place.

It’s a small budget wedding, it’s only our little family and some close friends.

I feel like he is being overly fussy, but he feels he’s being reasonable.
Inference:
The situation you described revolves around the dynamics between you and your fiancé concerning your upcoming wedding. The sunk cost fallacy occurs when individuals continue with a decision based on the cumulative prior investments (time, money, effort) rather than the current and future benefits or drawbacks. 

In your case, you feel devastated at the idea of postponing the wedding because you believe that you've already invested so much into the plans, such as deposits, invitations, and arrangements. This feeling can be indicative of the sunk cost fallacy because it suggests a reluctance to change plans due to past investments, even if those investments cannot be recovered and may not serve the best interests moving forward.

Your fiancé, on the other hand, is expressing concerns about the quality of the wedding venue and is considering postponing to ensure the day meets both of your expectations. His approach appears to be focused on the future quality of the wedding rather than being influenced by past investments.

Therefore, the example primarily illustrates you grappling with the sunk cost fallacy—feeling that stopping now would mean all the previous investments were in vain—even though it might be more beneficial for both of you to prioritize the quality and success of the wedding over past expenditures.

**ANSWER: Yes**

I still don't quite understand why he couldn't have had a bite over the last 3 days that it's been made since he is eating the snickerdoodle cookies I made on Sunday no problem.
