Example:
AITA for backing out of a 15-minute favor when it suddenly turned into an hour-plus-long ordeal?
Context: I work from home two days per week; today is one of those days. My wife's workday ends at 4:00, mine ends at 5:30.

Today, when my wife got home (about 4:15), she called me downstairs pretty much as soon as she came in the front door, to tell me that she's left her car running and would I please take it over to Discount Tire (DT) because one of the tires is low. (For those not aware, DT provides complementary inflation and (non-sidewall) tire repairs.) Without complaint, I agree because it's only a 5-minute drive each way, so I can just take a quick 15-minute break from work. I drive her car down there, and the guy tops up 3 tires, but on the 4th his machine won't dispense any air. I see him check it with a manual pressure gauge and then he comes up to the window and tells me that the tire is under 15 PSI, so he can't inflate it, but he says they're not very busy right now, they could repair the tire after only about a half-hour wait. I let him know that I need to get back to work, is there any way he can add even a little bit of air so I can maybe have my wife bring it back and wait? He says no, because it's "basically flat".

I call my wife to let her know this - my intention is to ask her if I drive back home, would she want to drive it back to DT now since the wait is relatively short (when they're busy, it can be a 2+hour wait), or if not I can at least make an appointment while I'm here. But I don't even get that far; she just wants me to stay and wait for it (even though she's already done working for the day). I tell her I really need to get back to work, and she gets very upset. I ask DT Guy what exactly he meant by "basically flat" and he said I'm at 13 PSI. I confirm with him that this means I'm not at immediate risk of the rim tearing up the inside of the tire if I drive it back home right now, so I tell my wife that I'm coming back and I'll be there in 5 minutes. As I'm driving home I get a couple of texts, including "I'll just have you drive me to work tomorrow and my car can sit in the f***ing driveway for all I care", but of course I don't read them until I get home.

I go inside to make another attempt to explain the specifics of the situation (I haven't even been able to tell her that it's not actually flat flat, yet), but she refuses to listen to a word of it, telling me she isn't going to listen to anything I have to say for the next week, and that I've "ruined everything".

I don't recall every word exchanged, but I know I did tell her that she was acting like a child, and in the end saying "Fine, I'll go back there and I'll just have to work until 8pm tonight!" to which she responded with "Good, I don't want to see you!"

I did go back to DT, and started composing this post while waiting.

AITA?

Editing to answer some common questions.

We do own a portable air compressor, it takes about 5 minutes for it to fill one tire, and it's in the trunk of her car.
Taking care of car things is my chore, but every time she's asked me to inflate her tires I have done so - I wasn't neglecting them. Also, the last time I put air in, I told her that she needs to make a trip to DT after work ASAP (because I work until 5:30 and DT closes at 6:00) to get that tire checked for damage, since it loses air faster than the others.
She is generally in charge of discretionary spending, so if the tire had needed to be replaced (repairs are free at DT), she would need to be there to compare the options available.
DT is the opposite direction from home as her work, that's probably why she didn't go there on her way home from work.
She didn't drive my car to DT because we only have one key for it, and it didn't occur to me to take it out of my pocket before leaving.
No, she is not like this all the time.
Inference:
The Sunk Cost Fallacy refers to the tendency to continue an endeavor or commit to a decision based on the cumulative prior investment (time, money, resources) rather than evaluating the current and future benefits versus costs. Essentially, it's about not wanting to "waste" what has already been invested, even if continuing isn't the most rational choice.

In the provided scenario, the individual initially agrees to take a brief 15-minute favor—moving his wife's car to Discount Tire. The situation unexpectedly escalates, leading to tension between him and his wife about staying longer than anticipated. The crux of the issue revolves around the desire to revert to work rather than being a direct example of the Sunk Cost Fallacy.

Here’s the breakdown:

1. **Initial Commitment**: The individual voluntarily agrees to help, viewing it as a short task.
2. **Unexpected Extension**: The task takes longer due to unforeseen circumstances (tires needing attention).
3. **Decision Point**: Instead of feeling compelled to stay longer because of the time already invested, he attempts to leave to return to work, which indicates he is not succumbing to the Sunk Cost Fallacy.
4. **Conflict**: The wife's insistence on his continued presence is more about her expectations and perhaps emotional investment rather than rationalizing his continued effort based on prior investment.

In essence, the individual is trying to avoid the Sunk Cost Fallacy by recognizing that the additional time spent doesn’t provide proportional benefits and is instead attempting to prioritize his work commitments.

**ANSWER: No**

Long story short, I have a friend let's call her H who proposed we get together, I was down and started saving up for Money to contribute. The situation you've described revolves around your decision to withdraw from a planned gathering due to specific dietary restrictions not being adequately addressed in the budget. The **Sunk Cost Fallacy** occurs when someone continues an endeavor solely because of previously invested resources (time, money, effort), rather than evaluating the current benefits and costs objectively.

In your case:

1. **Initial Investment**: You planned to contribute money and invest time to make new friends.
2. **Change in Circumstances**: The budget sent by H included foods that conflict with your allergies and dietary needs.
3. **Decision Point**: You chose to withdraw and requested your money back instead of continuing with the plan that no longer suited your needs.

This decision is based on the rational assessment that participating would not be beneficial or safe for you, and you sought to mitigate further loss by seeking a refund. Instead of letting past investments compel you to stay in a situation that isn't favorable, you took steps to address the issue appropriately.

Therefore, this example does **not** illustrate the Sunk Cost Fallacy.

Example:
I recently built a custom cabinet that doubles as an attic access door for a bathroom remodel. I’m fairly new to being a general contractor, with about a year of experience. The interior designer on the project simply told us to “do something with this” attic access. Wanting to go above and beyond, I decided to create something unique—a cabinet that opens into the attic.

I didn’t charge any extra for this feature, even though I could have just put up a piece of plywood and called it a day. I spent about 60 hours on this project, aiming to add value and a special touch. To ensure the cabinet door stayed shut properly, I installed a small mailbox lock. While it’s not the most visually appealing, it was necessary for the cabinet’s function.

Now, the interior designer has called the mailbox lock “unacceptable,” and the client insists we change it. After putting so much effort into this project, I’m frustrated that my work is being dismissed over a detail that was essential for functionality.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect is the cognitive bias where people tend to overvalue products or outcomes that they have put significant effort into creating or assembling, even if the objective quality might be no higher (or even lower) than that of a professionally made alternative. In your example, you spent around 60 hours building a custom cabinet with an attic access door, surpassing basic requirements and adding personal touches like the functional mailbox lock. Because you invested so much personal effort and creativity into the design, you naturally value this work highly. When external parties—namely, the interior designer and the client—disapprove of a detail that you included for functional reasons, your frustration stems not only from the rework but also from the fact that your own labor and design choices have been dismissed.

This situation aligns well with the concept of the IKEA Effect. You are experiencing a form of cognitive bias where the effort and time you invested into this unique, self-made product have increased your personal valuation of the work. Thus, when others do not appreciate or recognize the value of your assembled work, it leads to a disproportionate sense of loss or frustration. 

Therefore, considering that the personal investment of time and creativity has led you to overvalue your project—and the subsequent negative emotional reaction when that value is not recognized—it is accurate to say that this is an instance of the IKEA Effect.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
I hate it when I’m talking about something I really enjoy, something that I put a lot of emotion into explaining and talking about with someone, just for them to say something like “I wasn’t paying attention”. It just makes me feel like they don’t care about what I have to say even though I don’t do the same thing to them. Even when it’s just them looking away from me or doing something that you have to focus on to do makes me feel like they aren’t invested into the conversation like I am. I just wish that I had someone I could talk to that actually put as much effort into talking as I do. I feel like I pay attention most of the time to what people are saying especially when I know it’s something they like, so it kind of hurts when it feels like no one wants to do that for me.
I love watching movies. I know it’s nothing super duper serious that you have to pay attention to but it’s something I really like. I love being invested and watching franchises and stuff and being able to talk about it and express my thoughts and excitement around it. I know that not everyone I met will feel about it the way I do but I still would like to be able to talk about it without feeling like I’m forcing the other person to talk with me. I’m not sure if there’s something I’m doing wrong but I don’t act that way when they talk about something I don’t personally care for. I still listen and comment and let them talk about what they like. I just feel like every time I bring up movies in general that they don’t feel like watching everyone just turns their ears off and zone out on what I’m saying as if it doesn’t matter. And like I said it’s nothing super serious but I still like talking about things I enjoy like that. You don’t have to have viewed something to listen about someone talk about it. It might make it easier to understand but if there’s something you don’t get I know I could explain it. It just seems like nobody wants me to. I wish there was someone who actually wanted me to talk about this stuff. Someone who cared as much as I did. It would make things way easier and it wouldn’t make me feel like a burden or like the person I’m talking to doesn’t care about me when it’s just what I have to say. I’m not sure why things have to be this complicated. It’s just kind of upsetting and always degrading when they say they zoned out. I know that they probably aren’t doing it on purpose and that they probably think I just look at it like it’s a joke but sometimes it actually does hurt my feelings a bit. I wish I didn’t care this much but it’s hard not to.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to the cognitive bias where people assign greater value to things they have partially created or built themselves. This effect makes individuals appreciate even mediocre outcomes more because of the effort they invested in the creation process. In the provided example, the person is expressing feelings of frustration and hurt when their conversations about something they are emotionally invested in (movies) are met with a lack of attention by others. This discussion centers on interpersonal communication, validation, and emotional connection rather than on valuing something because of one's own labor or creation.

There is no element in the example that relates to building or assembling something oneself, which is key to the IKEA Effect. The person’s experience is more about the desire for reciprocated interest and deeper engagement rather than overvaluing something simply because they put time and effort into it.

ANSWER: No

Example: Just like the title says. My husband invited over his friends for the previous Saturday. Only one person ended up attending. I spent Friday after work finishing the Tres Leches cake to go with the dinner he asked for. I sent home the guy with two pieces for himself and his fiancé. So far, it's Tuesday, and my husband hasn't even tried a piece. We were supposed to have some Sunday night while we watched our show. He kept putting it off, and then bed time came, so I asked him if I should just start the dishwasher or if we were going to have cake now, he said to just start the dishwasher. Last night we were going to have some after dinner. I went and got my own and some for my son, husband still won't try any. Not even a bite. I made almost a sheet cake for his friends, and he won't even try it. I told him last night how that made me feel after working so hard on it and he was apologetic and I asked him if he just didn't want any then I would stop offering, it's a soaked cake so it has to be eaten fairly quickly. He said that wasn't the case and that he just hadn't been hungry on Sunday or Saturday. I still don't quite understand why he couldn't have had a bite over the last 3 days that it's been made since he is eating the snickerdoodle cookies I made on Sunday no problem. Is this me having unrealistic expectations? I'm not wanting him to eat every piece, but he hasn't even had a bite since I made it, and I'm feeling very crestfallen. Thanks in advance, I guess.
Inference:
The IKEA effect refers to the phenomenon where people tend to overvalue things that they have had a hand in creating or assembling, even if the finished product isn’t objectively superior. In other words, when individuals invest personal effort into making something, they subsequently assign it an increased value that isn’t always justified by its intrinsic qualities.

In the example provided, the situation revolves around a wife who made a Tres Leches cake with considerable effort, only to have her husband never sample it despite multiple opportunities. The issue here is more about her feelings of hurt and disappointment that her work isn’t being appreciated or shared by her husband—not about a situation where someone values something more simply because they made it. In fact, if the IKEA effect were at work, one might expect the person who put in the effort (or someone who also contributed to the creation) to have an inflated sense of value for the outcome. However, in this situation it is the wife whose creation is being undervalued by someone else, not an instance where the creator is valuing the product more because she built it herself.

Therefore, this example does not illustrate the IKEA effect, but rather a different dynamic concerning expectations, appreciation, and communication between the couple.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Genuine question because I don't know what normal is here. My gut tells me this is something parents should never do to their children. I don't know if that makes me moralizing or pretentious about my own parenting. Maybe I'm overreacting and being a lil bitch about it, but here's the context.

My family was trying to decide where to go on a vacation together because we haven't been on a big family vacation as a group in almost a decade. We were all suggesting various ideas, such as Florida, South Dakota, Canada, Georgia, etc. just trying to determine where to go. I said "we could rent a lakehouse or an Airbnb somewhere by a beach."

For some reason, this upset my dad and here's how it went:

"No I work TOO HARD to worry about BREAKFAST so I need SOMEONE ELSE to do it FOR ME. You only want to go somewhere not a hotel because you and your wife are TOO FAT AND LAZY."

Me: "why would you say that? Even if you thought it, you shouldn't say that."

(Mom interjects here, tells my dad that was very rude)

Him: "Because it's true and I'm just telling the truth."

Me: "Ok so my wife who works 6 days a week and overnights is lazy? We got 2 houses by being lazy? I'm not leaving my son on an iPad either."

Him: "YES I have seen your house and you aren't prioritizing keeping it clean! We had 3 kids and it was always clean!" <This was my mom's insane hard work, not his>

Me: "It's perfectly fine and normal for having a toddler in the house. Why are you going on about this? It's embarrassing and it makes me not want to go with you if you're going to act like this"

Past this point I was so furious and overwhelmed with all this plus getting a killer migraine from my TBI acting up again that I sorta blacked out and forgot what happened for a few minutes after. I just know that eventually things went back to awkward and "normal" for a bit.

He's always called me fat and lazy on occasion and this time just seemed to be the last straw. I'm not really that fat--I would like to lose 20 pounds sure--and I don't think I'm lazy given I'm working very hard at work, improving myself, and healing from my TBI.

Is this normal? What the heck do I do? I just feel sick about it and I can't make myself think straight.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect is a cognitive bias where people tend to give greater value to things they have helped create or assemble—even if the end product isn’t perfect—simply because they invested effort into it. For example, if you spend time putting together furniture from a kit, you might end up feeling especially attached to it and value it more highly than a similar, pre-assembled item.

In the situation you described, the core interaction involves family planning for a vacation and personal criticisms regarding laziness and housekeeping. This is more about interpersonal conflict and resentment rather than overvaluing something due to one’s own contribution. Although there is mention of the choices between renting a lake house or hotel accommodations, there is no element of assembling or creating something where someone would later value it more because of their personal input. The discussion and emotional conflict center on personal habits and attitudes rather than a scenario in which effort leads to overvaluation.

Thus, this isn’t an example of the IKEA Effect. 

ANSWER: No

Example:
So a bit of background first. Husband and I have been together for 9 years (since high school), married for 4. His sister is older, now in her early 30s and married with a 6 month old daughter. She's a teacher (I have total sympathy for teacher salaries sucking as I'm in education as well) and her husband has a good, salaried job in the automotive industry.

Ever since we've been together, and maybe even before then with her other family members, she always does handmade gifts- really terrible paintings. When she was in her early 20s and in college it was one thing. I get it, I've been a cash strapped college student before too, but it never stopped. We exchange Christmas lists or give indicators as to what we might like every year and we always spend at least a decent amount of money getting her what she asked for (averaging around $50 probably) as well as now for her husband and this year for her daughter. Even as a wedding gift she made us a painting which looked like an 8 year old could have done it. Not even like cool and abstract, just terrible wine and paint night type art. It's sitting in the closet now, never having been hung cause it's horrible but I feel like an asshole if I throw it away.

So we recently asked what they might like for Christmas this year and when she asked what we wanted my husband said "anything on my Amazon wishlist, I'll send you the link" she says "well I already know what I got you isn't on your wishlist cause I made it". Like why even ask us what we want then and UGH another painting!

Don't get me wrong, I think handmade things are great from kids or if you have a particular talent, but otherwise it's not fair to ask people for things that cost actual money and get them and give something unwanted and terrible in return. To be fair we've never expressed these feelings cause it seems mean but also isn't it a given that your adult brother and his wife don't want your terrible paintings? Even if we did want them and like them enough to hang, our house would now be covered in her paintings which is weird too!

To add to that, when we visit and by accounts of everyone else we know in their life, they spend ridiculous amounts of money eating out and buying whatever they want. She even confessed to me that she'd love to quit working and stay home but that they couldn't maintain their current lifestyle that way. No judgment (ok a little judgment)- but if you really want to stay home to raise your child you can't cut back on the other stuff a little?

So AITA if I say something or just continue getting horrible gifts for the rest of my life while spending our money on her and her family?
Inference:
The IKEA Effect describes the tendency for people to value items more highly when they have put effort into assembling or creating them, even if the final product isn’t objectively superior—or even if it’s flawed. It’s about the psychological bias in which we overvalue our own handiwork simply because we contributed to its creation.

In the example you provided, the sister makes handmade gifts (paintings) that are not well-received by you or your husband. Although she puts effort into creating these gifts and might personally value them more highly due to the time and energy invested, the focus of your commentary is on her repeated gifting of items you don't find appealing, rather than on you overvaluing something you assembled yourself. The phenomenon at work in your story is more about mismatched gift expectations and the awkward obligation to accept something that is not appreciated, rather than the IKEA Effect as it’s defined in psychological research.

Furthermore, the IKEA Effect would be at play if, for instance, you had built a piece of furniture yourself and then felt an inflated sense of attachment or satisfaction with it due to the effort you put into the assembly process—even if it wasn’t perfect. Here, however, the scenario is about the sister’s consistent choice to make gifts (and your resulting dissatisfaction), not about you or anyone else overvaluing your own work.

Thus, while the sister might personally feel that her handmade gifts are more special because she made them (which is loosely related to the spirit of the IKEA Effect), your issue is not about the valuation bias that the IKEA Effect explains. Instead, it revolves around gift preferences and the tension between her creative intentions and your expectations of receiving something more aligned with a typical, purchased gift that meets your needs or tastes.

ANSWER: No

Example:
(Trow away since some people I know in RL know my account)

My sister in law is a really crafty person. And for Christmas she DIYs many of the presents she gives out to other people. tbh I didn't really like any of the gifts she gave me.

some of them where:

Christmas ornaments with photos from our pets and our son (way too kitschy for my taste)
Whiskey based self made liqueur with a family photo as label (I love Whiskey, but pure and not in a cream liqueur)
a tote bag with a painted wolf(the design was nice and wolfes are one of my favourite animals, but I don't use tote bags)
I dropped a comment to my wife that I hope SIL doesn't gift me any more "DIYed shit" this year, because I really have no use for it. She lost her shit qt me and called me "a bitter and ungrateful person" because apparently everyone in her family loves the "thoughtful gifts" of SIL.

idk but I still feel DIYed stuff should only be an addition to a real present. And it's not like she's poor and couldn't buy presents. Am I the asshole here?
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to a cognitive bias where people tend to overvalue things they have created or assembled themselves, regardless of the actual quality of the finished product. In other words, when you put effort into making something, you’re likely to think it’s better than a similar item produced by someone else.

In the case you described, the sister-in-law makes gifts herself, and she (and apparently her family) appreciates the thought and effort behind the DIY presents. However, this situation isn’t an example of the IKEA Effect in its true form. The effect usually involves the person who has participated in the creation (or assembly) placing higher value on that object. In your example, while your sister-in-law might attach extra significance to her own creations, you (the recipient) are not the one who made the items, and you don’t seem to be influenced by the extra effort that went into them. Instead, you simply have different tastes and preferences regarding the type of gifts you like.

Thus, while the story does touch on the idea that handcrafted items can be seen as meaningful by their makers (which is related to the broader idea behind the IKEA Effect), your situation isn’t a clear-cut demonstration of that cognitive bias affecting your own valuation of items you have a hand in creating. It’s more about a difference in taste and the way people derive value from thoughtfulness rather than a bias stemming from personal labor invested.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Hi, for some background information, I am 19 and live on my own. I pay my rent from student loans in my name, I pay for my phone on the phone bill, and they pay for my car that was a "gift"

So, I've been on my own for almost a year in a half. I don't party, I don't go out much, and I work a 50 hour weeks to support myself. To treat myself to a job promotion, I decided to buy myself a new phone. My old phone was a iPhone, which had "find my friends", and my new phone is an android, where tracking isn't as easy.

When I lived with my mom all through high-school, she would track my phone to make sure I was going where I said I was. This was very frustrating because my mom has called me a bunch of names and we have a strained relationship as is. Because of this, I moved out. When I moved out, I told myself that I would turn off my GPS, but when I did, it caused a fight and she threatened to take away my car and called me a "ungrateful bitch", and then took my stimulus checks from me later down the road.

Upon getting my new phone, my stepmother looked at my mother and said "we won't be able to use find my friends anymors", and my mother started freaking out and having a panic attack. She kept trying to get me to change my mind on not getting a new phone, and told me I would understand when I have kids (bonus, I just got told I am infertile and will not be having kids). She also told me i was out of control, and that I was crazy and that I was hiding something. This isn't the case. At all. At this point, I was very frustrated and told her that I am a legal adult, and that it is very overbearing to act like that and that my friends parents don't track their phones.

She flipped her shit and called me ungrateful, an asshole, and accused me of doing something I don't want her to know about. Once again. I live on my own. I just don't want to be questioned anymore about what time I'm going to be home, or what time I'm going to be somewhere. I have found its toxic and gives me anxiety attacks.

So reddit, AITA for calling her overbearing? I've been trying to work on independency with my mother lately, but i might have been too rough.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to the cognitive bias where people place disproportionately high value on products or items they have partially created or assembled themselves. In this situation, however, no such self-creation or assembly is taking place; the individual is simply making a purchasing decision about a phone to gain autonomy and to avoid being tracked by their mother. The emotional and relational dynamics described are related to issues of control, independence, and boundary-setting rather than valuing something more because of personal effort or assembly.

Therefore, this example is not an instance of the IKEA Effect.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I recently built a custom cabinet that doubles as an attic access door for a bathroom remodel. I’m fairly new to being a general contractor, with about a year of experience. The interior designer on the project simply told us to “do something with this” attic access. Wanting to go above and beyond, I decided to create something unique—a cabinet that opens into the attic.

I didn’t charge any extra for this feature, even though I could have just put up a piece of plywood and called it a day. I spent about 60 hours on this project, aiming to add value and a special touch. To ensure the cabinet door stayed shut properly, I installed a small mailbox lock. While it’s not the most visually appealing, it was necessary for the cabinet’s function.

Now, the interior designer has called the mailbox lock “unacceptable,” and the client insists we change it. After putting so much effort into this project, I’m frustrated that my work is being dismissed over a detail that was essential for functionality.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to the cognitive bias where individuals place a higher value on products they have partially created or assembled themselves. This phenomenon often leads people to appreciate their own efforts and creations more than similar offerings produced by others, sometimes overlooking flaws or areas for improvement.

In the example provided, the general contractor invested significant time (60 hours) and effort into designing and building a custom cabinet that serves a dual purpose as an attic access door. By choosing to create something unique rather than opting for a simple, cost-effective solution like plywood, the contractor demonstrates a personal attachment and pride in his work. This investment likely leads him to value the custom cabinet more highly and feel frustrated when his efforts are criticized or dismissed, even over functional details like the mailbox lock.

This behavior aligns with the IKEA Effect, as the contractor's personal investment in creating the cabinet causes him to overvalue his work, making it harder for him to accept constructive feedback or alternative solutions.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
I hate it when I’m talking about something I really enjoy, something that I put a lot of emotion into explaining and talking about with someone, just for them to say something like “I wasn’t paying attention”. It just makes me feel like they don’t care about what I have to say even though I don’t do the same thing to them. Even when it’s just them looking away from me or doing something that you have to focus on to do makes me feel like they aren’t invested into the conversation like I am. I just wish that I had someone I could talk to that actually put as much effort into talking as I do. I feel like I pay attention most of the time to what people are saying especially when I know it’s something they like, so it kind of hurts when it feels like no one wants to do that for me.
I love watching movies. I know it’s nothing super duper serious that you have to pay attention to but it’s something I really like. I love being invested and watching franchises and stuff and being able to talk about it and express my thoughts and excitement around it. I know that not everyone I met will feel about it the way I do but I still would like to be able to talk about it without feeling like I’m forcing the other person to talk with me. I’m not sure if there’s something I’m doing wrong but I don’t act that way when they talk about something I don’t personally care for. I still listen and comment and let them talk about what they like. I just feel like every time I bring up movies in general that they don’t feel like watching everyone just turns their ears off and zone out on what I’m saying as if it doesn’t matter. And like I said it’s nothing super serious but I still like talking about things I enjoy like that. You don’t have to have viewed something to listen about someone talk about it. It might make it easier to understand but if there’s something you don’t get I know I could explain it. It just seems like nobody wants me to. I wish there was someone who actually wanted me to talk about this stuff. Someone who cared as much as I did. It would make things way easier and it wouldn’t make me feel like a burden or like the person I’m talking to doesn’t care about me when it’s just what I have to say. I’m not sure why things have to be this complicated. It’s just kind of upsetting and always degrading when they say they zoned out. I know that they probably aren’t doing it on purpose and that they probably think I just look at it like it’s a joke but sometimes it actually does hurt my feelings a bit. I wish I didn’t care this much but it’s hard not to.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect is a cognitive bias where individuals place a higher value on things they have partially created or assembled themselves. This effect is named after the furniture company IKEA, which is known for its self-assembly products. The key aspect of the IKEA Effect is the increased appreciation and perceived value of an item due to the effort and personal investment involved in its creation or assembly.

In the example provided, the individual is expressing frustration about feeling that others do not reciprocate the emotional investment they put into conversations about their interests, such as movies. While the person is indeed investing emotional effort and seeking a deeper connection in their interactions, this scenario does not align with the IKEA Effect. The IKEA Effect specifically relates to the valuation of tangible items that one has assembled or created, not emotional or conversational investments between people.

Therefore, the situation described illustrates feelings of unreciprocated emotional investment and a desire for more engaged interactions, but it does not exemplify the IKEA Effect.

**ANSWER: No**

Example: Just like the title says. My husband invited over his friends for the previous Saturday. Only one person ended up attending. I spent Friday after work finishing the Tres Leches cake to go with the dinner he asked for. I sent home the guy with two pieces for himself and his fiancé. So far, it's Tuesday, and my husband hasn't even tried a piece. We were supposed to have some Sunday night while we watched our show. He kept putting it off, and then bed time came, so I asked him if I should just start the dishwasher or if we were going to have cake now, he said to just start the dishwasher. Last night we were going to have some after dinner. I went and got my own and some for my son, husband still won't try any. Not even a bite. I made almost a sheet cake for his friends, and he won't even try it. He said that wasn't the case and that he just hadn't been hungry on Sunday or Saturday. I still don't quite understand why he couldn't have had a bite over the last 3 days that it's been made since he is eating the snickerdoodle cookies I made on Sunday no problem. In the provided example, the wife dedicates significant time and effort to bake a Tres Leches cake for her husband's friends. However, her husband consistently avoids trying the cake, despite his willingness to consume other treats like snickerdoodle cookies he made. This situation doesn't illustrate the IKEA Effect because the husband isn't valuing or appreciating the effort put into creating the cake. Instead, it highlights a lack of recognition or appreciation for the wife's hard work.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
Genuine question because I don't know what normal is here. My gut tells me this is something parents should never do to their children. I don't know if that makes me moralizing or pretentious about my own parenting. Maybe I'm overreacting and being a lil bitch about it, but here's the context.

My family was trying to decide where to go on a vacation together because we haven't been on a big family vacation as a group in almost a decade. We were all suggesting various ideas, such as Florida, South Dakota, Canada, Georgia, etc. just trying to determine where to go. I said "we could rent a lakehouse or an Airbnb somewhere by a beach."

For some reason, this upset my dad and here's how it went:

"No I work TOO HARD to worry about BREAKFAST so I need SOMEONE ELSE to do it FOR ME. You only want to go somewhere not a hotel because you and your wife are TOO FAT AND LAZY."

Me: "why would you say that? Even if you thought it, you shouldn't say that."

(Mom interjects here, tells my dad that was very rude)

Him: "Because it's true and I'm just telling the truth."

Me: "Ok so my wife who works 6 days a week and overnights is lazy? We got 2 houses by being lazy? I'm not leaving my son on an iPad either."

Him: "YES I have seen your house and you aren't prioritizing keeping it clean! We had 3 kids and it was always clean!" <This was my mom's insane hard work, not his>

Me: "It's perfectly fine and normal for having a toddler in the house. Why are you going on about this? It's embarrassing and it makes me not want to go with you if you're going to act like this"

Past this point I was so furious and overwhelmed with all this plus getting a killer migraine from my TBI acting up again that I sorta blacked out and forgot what happened for a few minutes after. I just know that eventually things went back to awkward and "normal" for a bit.

He's always called me fat and lazy on occasion and this time just seemed to be the last straw. I'm not really that fat--I would like to lose 20 pounds sure--and I don't think I'm lazy given I'm working very hard at work, improving myself, and healing from my TBI.

Is this normal? What the heck do I do? I just feel sick about it and I can't make myself think straight.
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to the cognitive bias where individuals place a higher value on products they have partially created or assembled themselves. This effect highlights how personal investment and effort in building or crafting something can lead to an increased perceived value of that item. 

In the scenario you've described, the conflict revolves around family dynamics, specifically regarding vacation planning and personal criticisms from your father. The situation involves interpersonal disagreements and emotional responses rather than the valuation of a self-created or assembled product. There isn't an element of personal investment in creating or building something that leads to an increased sense of value, which is central to the IKEA Effect.

Therefore, this example does not align with the concept of the IKEA Effect.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
So a bit of background first. Husband and I have been together for 9 years (since high school), married for 4. His sister is older, now in her early 30s and married with a 6 month old daughter. She's a teacher (I have total sympathy for teacher salaries sucking as I'm in education as well) and her husband has a good, salaried job in the automotive industry.

Ever since we've been together, and maybe even before then with her other family members, she always does handmade gifts- really terrible paintings. When she was in her early 20s and in college it was one thing. I get it, I've been a cash strapped college student before too, but it never stopped. We exchange Christmas lists or give indicators as to what we might like every year and we always spend at least a decent amount of money getting her what she asked for (averaging around $50 probably) as well as now for her husband and this year for her daughter. Even as a wedding gift she made us a painting which looked like an 8 year old could have done it. Not even like cool and abstract, just terrible wine and paint night type art. It's sitting in the closet now, never having been hung cause it's horrible but I feel like an asshole if I throw it away.

So we recently asked what they might like for Christmas this year and when she asked what we wanted my husband said "anything on my Amazon wishlist, I'll send you the link" she says "well I already know what I got you isn't on your wishlist cause I made it". Like why even ask us what we want then and UGH another painting!

Don't get me wrong, I think handmade things are great from kids or if you have a particular talent, but otherwise it's not fair to ask people for things that cost actual money and get them and give something unwanted and terrible in return. To be fair we've never expressed these feelings cause it seems mean but also isn't it a given that your adult brother and his wife don't want your terrible paintings? Even if we did want them and like them enough to hang, our house would now be covered in her paintings which is weird too!

To add to that, when we visit and by accounts of everyone else we know in their life, they spend ridiculous amounts of money eating out and buying whatever they want. She even confessed to me that she'd love to quit working and stay home but that they couldn't maintain their current lifestyle that way. No judgment (ok a little judgment)- but if you really want to stay home to raise your child you can't cut back on the other stuff a little?

So AITA if I say something or just continue getting horrible gifts for the rest of my life while spending our money on her and her family?
Inference:
The IKEA Effect refers to a cognitive bias where people place a higher value on products they have partially created themselves. This phenomenon is named after IKEA's furniture, which requires customers to assemble it. The act of building something can lead individuals to develop a greater appreciation and attachment to the end product, even if it isn't perfect.

In the scenario you've described, the sister-in-law consistently creates handmade paintings as gifts. While her intention is likely to provide something personal and heartfelt, the IKEA Effect specifically involves the creator valuing the product more because they had a hand in making it. However, in this case, the primary issue seems to be the recipient's (your and your husband's) dissatisfaction with the quality and desirability of the gifts, rather than the value the sister-in-law places on her creations.

Additionally, the IKEA Effect mainly pertains to how the creator values their own creations, not necessarily how the recipients perceive them. Your frustration stems from the mismatch between the effort she puts into making the gifts and the actual value they provide to you, rather than an overvaluation from her side due to the act of creating.

**ANSWER: No**

Hi, for some background information, I am 19 and live on my own. I pay my rent from student loans in my name, I pay for my phone on the phone bill, and they pay for my car that was a "gift"

So, I've been on my own for almost a year in a half. I don't party, I don't go out much, and I work a 50 hour weeks to support myself. To treat myself to a job promotion, I decided to buy myself a new phone. My old phone was a iPhone, which had "find my friends", and my new phone is an android, where tracking isn't as easy.

When I lived with my mom all through high-school, she would track my phone to make sure I was going where I said I was. This was very frustrating because my mom has called me a bunch of names and we have a strained relationship as is. Because of this, I moved out. When I moved out, I told myself that I would turn off my GPS, but when I did, it caused a fight and she threatened to take away my car and called me a "ungrateful bitch", and then took my stimulus checks from me later down the road.

Upon getting my new phone, my stepmother looked at my mother and said "we won't be able to use find my friends anymors", and my mother started freaking out and having a panic attack. She kept trying to get me to change my mind on not getting a new phone, and told me I would understand when I have kids (bonus, I just got told I am infertile and will not be having kids). She also told me i was out of control, and that I was crazy and that I was hiding something. This isn't the case. At all. At this point, I was very frustrated and told her that I am a legal adult, and that it is very overbearing to act like that and that my friends parents don't track their phones.

She flipped her shit and called me ungrateful, an asshole, and accused me of doing something I don't want her to know about. Once again. I live on my own. I just don't want to be questioned anymore about what time I'm going to be home, or what time I'm going to be somewhere. I have found its toxic and gives me anxiety attacks.

So reddit, AITA for calling her overbearing? I've been trying to work on independency with my mother lately, but i might have been too rough.

I have asked for more help with the responsibilities of the house and he says he will but it only last for a week before we are in the same routine all over again. I have gone back and forth about if I should stay in the marriage but have been to scared of the unknown of leaving to take the leap.

The pseudocertainty effect is a cognitive bias observed in decision-making under risk where people give excessive weight to outcomes that are presented as certain, even when there are other uncertain aspects or when the certainty is only apparent due to how the decision is framed. It generally appears in contexts like gambling, investment decisions, or any scenario where a guaranteed outcome competes directly with probabilistic outcomes.

In the example provided, the narrative is primarily about a relationship dynamic and the feelings of emotional and financial imbalance between spouses. The concerns raised—about household responsibilities, intimacy, and financial independence—are not framed in terms of explicitly risky decisions with clearly defined probabilities or outcomes that are certain versus uncertain. Instead, the decision at hand is whether to stay in the marriage or leave, and while there is fear of the unknown when considering separation, the situation does not involve a clear-cut transformation of uncertain outcomes into a seemingly "certain" outcome due to framing effects. The issue here is more about emotional ambivalence, relationship dissatisfaction, and inertia caused by comfort with the known, despite its negative aspects, rather than the pseudocertainty bias driving the decision.

Thus, while the fear of the unknown might reflect a kind of risk aversion or status quo bias, it does not represent the pseudocertainty effect as it is typically defined and understood in the context of decision theory.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I know the title sounds silly but I'm talking about a dude in his 20s who is dropping his legitimate diploma to pursue singing full time as employment.

I (20sF) met him in middle school and we've been very close friends on and off ever since. I know he was born into a family who is very "artistically inclined", as in, everyone in his family is an artist, so he's always been passionate about singing. He was a nerdy studious kid who got the best grades and for most of the time, singing was just his side interest.

He used to get bullied for singing in school because, to be honest, he's a terrible singer. His voice is weak and shaky, he writes lyrics that are either very cliche or nonsensical, but I and all of his friends would clap and support him, first because we didn't want him to feel bad and secondly because we thought he could improve, but damn, talent shows were genuinely painful for us.

Fast forward to now, this guy has a good job in a well-paying respected field outside of the arts and is almost graduating from a prestigious school. However, he recently told us that even though he loves his job and his field, he noticed that he barely has time to sing and write songs now, and he is finally ready to make the big step and choose singing as his full-time activity. He had already quit his job by the time he told us that because he didn't want anyone "talking him out of it", but he will wait until the end of this semester to drop out of school.

For all of these years, he's been releasing original songs and he genuinely thinks / is convinced that they only get 50 to 100 views because he isn't releasing enough of them and putting in that extra time. He does everything to go viral on social media and never works out, but he always finds a couple of well-meaning but unhelpful strangers to comment "it'll work brother, you just gotta practice more and work harder, fck what other people think".

Talking to other friends about it, they're all shocked and worried about this decision, but since his family always supports him no matter what, they think that we won't be able to change his mind. Telling him the truth will just drive him away, my friends think that it's best to let him try and make the mistake by himself.

I think I should've said something way sooner and now I might be just an asshole if I tell him that, honestly, he's terrible at singing and songwriting.

WIBTA?
Inference:
The pseudocertainty effect is a decision‐making bias where a person treats an outcome as if it were guaranteed—even though it isn’t—simply because it is presented in a way that makes it appear inevitable. Usually, this happens in situations where a particular choice “locks in” one part of the outcome as certain, even if other parts remain uncertain.

In the example you provided, the young man decides to drop a stable academic and professional track to focus on singing. His reasoning seems to be based on the belief that if he simply “puts in the extra work” (i.e., releasing more songs, practicing more) his lack of current success can be overcome, and he’ll eventually succeed. While this does involve a degree of overconfidence in his ability to change his fortunes, it isn’t quite the pseudocertainty effect. 

Here’s why:
• The pseudocertainty effect typically occurs when a decision option includes an element framed as “certain” even though the overall outcome is still risky. In such cases, that certain-seeming part leads the decision-maker to favor the option, often ignoring the underlying risks.
• In this case, his belief that “if I practice harder and release more songs, I will go viral” is not anchored on an element framed as completely guaranteed by the structure of the choice; rather, it is more an overestimation of his future abilities and the effectiveness of his hard work.
• Therefore, while he may be underestimating the risks associated with his decision (and overestimating his potential to “fix” his situation through increased effort), he isn’t necessarily falling for the classic structure of pseudocertainty (where a portion of the result is presented as a sure gain).

So, his decision appears to be driven more by overconfidence and perhaps optimism about his potential improvement than by the mechanism typically described as the pseudocertainty effect.

ANSWER: No

In high school, I dated a guy, who we'll call Dan. Just to be clear, this is not my husband. I cannot remember exactly how long the relationship lasted, but it was no more than a year. We did a lot during the time we were together, a lot of our first experiences with some things were together. Things did not work out in the end as we both wanted different things in life so we ended the relationship and moved on from eachother.

My sister, 29F, ended up befriending Dan in college and they have gotten very close. Since it's been so long since our relationship ended, I really do not care, neither does Dan. He is very close with my family because he gets invited to so many of the family gatherings.

Last weekend it was my mothers birthday and there was a party thrown for her, which my entire family attended, along with family friends. Of course, my sister invited Dan. My husband and I usually do not attend birthday parties, but I insisted that we go to this one seeing as it was for my own mother. My husband agreed.


My husband works a very demanding job so he is normally unable to attend family gatherings, and so he's never met Dan, nor have I told him about my history with him.


At the party, Dan was introduced to my husband as my ex. It was my sister who introduced them while I was in the kitchen speaking to family. When I came back, my husband seemed a little off and when I asked him what was wrong he just brushed it off and wouldn't answer me.


During the dinner, my husband seemed distant and so I asked him again if he was feeling okay. He immediately stood up from his seat and seemed upset that I hadn't told him about Dan. I tried to explain to him that I didn't feel the need to but he didn't listen. He completely lost it and started to call me names that he has never called me before and he even said he didn't know if he could trust me anymore. This was all in front of my entire family and family friends.

AITA?

In typical examples of the effect, people are swayed by a decision frame that makes one outcome seem guaranteed—even though, logically, the options might involve risk tradeoffs.

In the scenario you described, the issue is an interpersonal conflict that arises from miscommunication and unmet expectations regarding disclosure of past relationships. The husband becomes upset when he learns about the ex, feeling that he was deceived, which triggers hurt feelings and a public argument. The decision-making process here involves trust, communication, and managing emotions in relationships rather than choices being influenced by the framing of a certain versus uncertain outcome.

There’s no indication in the scenario that either spouse was making a decision based on a superficially “certain” outcome when comparing it to a probabilistic alternative. The dynamics revolve around emotional, relational, and trust issues rather than the type of risk evaluation that the pseudocertainty effect describes.

Therefore, this example does not illustrate a case of the pseudocertainty effect.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Husband and I have been together for overn year, married for 25. He has always been blunt to the point of rude, calling a spade a f***ing spade.

His father passed away a month ago, and during the funeral planning and preparation I made a few gaffes.

He has a brother, whose wife is anything BUT incompetent. She works as an event organiser so she took on the task of organising the funeral book. I offered to organise the music, and slideshow. When giving my number to the Funeral director, I went blank and forgot it, looking quite foolish.

The following week, I sent a message to the WhatsApp chat that I hadn't checked and was full of spelling mistakes. I also missed the autocorrect that changed "slideshow" into "sideshow". However the service was beautiful and went off without an issue.

A couple of weeks later, my husband was angry because we were having issues starting my daughter's car. I was unable to start it causing more issues (battery) and he screamed about bring surrounded by "f***ing incompetent" people. When I asked if meant me, he ranted about my issues during the funeral planning.

I was upset at being spoken to that way and let him know it. He said sorry and put it down to stress and grief. This was two weeks ago. Last night he called me incompetent again because I had to get a password reset to access my work personnel file (it's a website that we hardly ever use, I may login once a year).

While all this does make me sound like a complete idiot, it should be said that we have 3 kids, and i take on most of the responsibilities for the household (except the bills). Out daughter are now grown, but when they were younger he travelled a lot and I was on my own for weeks at a time.

I am also good at my job, and have been given more responsibilities in the last year including being made a mentor to other employees.

However I can be a bit of an airhead and ditzy.

In the past, people have noted the way my husband speaks to me, and have said he is too harsh and I deserve better.

I tried to leave a couple of years ago, but he convinced me to give him another chance. But I wonder this time did I deserve to be called incompetent?

If you made it this far, thank you. I just can't tell what is fair criticism and verbal abuse anymore.
Inference:
The Endowment Effect describes a cognitive bias in which people assign more value to things merely because they own them. It typically emerges in contexts involving possessions, choices, or even abstract items like ideas, where ownership increases worth in the owner’s eyes.

In the example you provided, the discussion centers on relationship dynamics, criticism, and feelings regarding one’s abilities and treatment within a marriage. It involves conflicts over perceived incompetence and verbal abuse rather than a scenario where someone overvalues something simply because it belongs to them. The bias is about valuing possessions or statuses, not justifying personal shortcomings or handling interpersonal conflicts.

Thus, the situation described does not illustrate the Endowment Effect. It is more related to issues of marital interaction, self-esteem, and possibly abusive behaviors, rather than a cognitive bias concerning the value of owned items.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Ok, I (28f) went over to my boyfriend’s (25m) house for the first time (been dating about a month), and I had somehow never noticed his pillow situation before. When I noticed, I made a comment about how long he’s had the pillows and apparently he’s been using them since he was a kid.

So, I asked him if he had any other pillows and he said he just had the pillow on the left of the first picture, but that his cat usually sleeps on it. I said I don’t really want to sleep on those pillows, and id prefer to sleep at my own place (with clean pillows).

His response? He waited for a minute and then said he would be sad to see that I would choose something as small as pillows come between us spending the night together, but that if I needed to go, that he understood.

I ended up going home and spending the night at my own house instead. I asked if I could bring my own pillows and gently suggested he get rid of his. He said it was totally fine for me to bring a pillow, but that he wouldn’t get rid of his, as they are ‘sentimental’.

Thoughts? I feel like I can’t even kiss him or anything while we’re sleeping because I don’t want him to get his gross pillowness all over me and my clean pillows. 😂
Inference:
The endowment effect is a cognitive bias in which people ascribe more value to things simply because they own them. In the classical experiments, individuals are typically asked to assign a higher selling price to an object they own compared to the price they’d be willing to pay for the same object if they didn’t own it. In your example, the boyfriend is attached to his pillows purely because of his personal history with them—they're “sentimental” and have been with him since childhood—even though, objectively, the pillows might have little practical or monetary value.

His reluctance to part with or replace his sentimental pillows, despite their drawbacks (like the fact that the cat uses one and that they might be considered "gross" by you), demonstrates that he values them much more just because they are his. His heightened emotional attachment to these items, to the point where it affects how the two of you share a living space, is consistent with the endowment effect. Essentially, his ownership of the pillows inflates their perceived value and importance, even when a more practical alternative (like your own clean pillows) exists.

Thus, this example does illustrate a form of the endowment effect in a real-life relational setting.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
I (39M), love giving gifts, I really enjoy putting thought and consideration into gifts for siblings, in-laws, nieces/nephews, and coworkers. For me, giving gifts isn’t about the price tag, it’s about showing the other person positive regard.

This evening, I visited my mother’s home for the family holiday (siblings, mother, in-laws, nieces/nephews). Just a sample of what I brought for people: stained glass window art, handmade porcelain bowls, and handmade silver jewelry.

I wasn’t expecting much tbh, I honestly do enjoy giving gifts, but if I had received no gifts, I’d have been fine with that. While I do enjoy receiving gifts, it isn’t a quid pro quo situation.

But these fricking family members did something worse. Like, a Starbucks gift card and a hot chocolate gift basket. The kind of presents that say “I put zero time/effort into this.” At best, I can bring these things to an office party or something like that.

When I noticed the incongruence, I just started feeling like a complete fool. As soon as I could slip away, I drove home. I didn’t flip out or say anything dumb, but I feel like I was being laughed at, the butt of some joke.

Now I’m home, just feel shitty and frustrated.

If someone reading this post has an alternative narrative that I can use, I’d love to hear it.

Thanks.
Inference:
The Endowment Effect is a cognitive bias where people assign a higher value to things simply because they own them. In this example, however, the frustration comes not from overvaluing possessions solely because they are one’s own, but rather from a mismatch between the effort and thought put into giving gifts and the perceived token nature of the gifts received. The poster's disappointment seems to stem from expectations about reciprocal thoughtfulness and social respect, rather than from a bias that comes from owning an item.

In the Endowment Effect, if someone were to, say, overvalue a mug just because it was in their possession, that would be a direct example of the effect. Here, the poster is upset because his deliberate, emotionally invested choices in gift-giving were met with gifts that he perceives as lacking care or effort. This reaction is more about social exchange or perceived inequity rather than an overvaluation of an owned item because of ownership per se.

So, while the poster may be inadvertently placing a higher subjective value on his own gifts due to the effort he invested in them, the heart of his grievance lies in feeling undervalued or disrespected by the token gifts he received. This is not the typical mechanism underlying the Endowment Effect.

ANSWER: No

Example:
AITA For causing a scene when my mom threw away my teddy bear?

Not the A-hole
Throwaway since I definitely don't want this to be linked to my main, even though I know my parents won't see it.

Edit: Thank you for the advice on how to clean stuff bears! If I'm unable to do it myself, I'll look in a company that can renew/restore stuffed animals:) Also, I'm asking if my overreaction makes me an asshole. Not for having a stuffed animal at my age and that I should "grow up." I will be disgrading those comments.

I(19f) am in college. I'm just finishing up my first year. 10 years ago, my first childhood friend gifted me a white teddy bear with a cute little black dress and a bow on her right ear. I always had her on my bed and I would take her on any vacations whenever I'm staying the night. It's been well known in my family that she's a sentimental item to me. My old friend and I don't speak anymore and we have lost touched, but I still kept the teddy bear.

In 5th grade, I was gifted a red, fluffy jacket from my grandma and I almost wore it everyday. That, too, became a sentimental item. However, after middle school, my mom decided to throw it away. I was extremely mad at her and didn't speak to her for a day or two. So this isn't the first time she threw away a sentimental item.

Now, yesterday, I noticed my bear wasn't on my bed as normal. I searched around and just couldn't find her. She didn't fall underneath my bed and she didn't get up and just walk away. I asked my sister, but she didn't know. So then I asked my mom and she said she threw it away. I instantly panicked. I went over to the trash and saw its been taken it. I went into the garage and looked through the garbage bin and found it inside a trash bag. I ripped it open and took her out. She was so dirty, gross, and smelled so horrible. There was a lot of liquid all over her furr. I started to break down and went back upstairs. I yelled at my mom for doing this. She knew how special she was to me and she thought it was a good idea to throw it away since I was too old to be having stuffed animals. I cleaned her off in the bathroom sink, but she's still gross. Her white coat is now stained and I'm absolutely furious. She isn't the same anymore. I was ranting, crying, and slamming doors shut. My mom called my dad and after he got home from work, he yelled at me for screaming at my mother. I got grounded and they took my laptop away. I only managed to convince them to keep my phone was because of work and I needed my boss and co-workers to text me. My sister even commented on how I overreacted.

The whole ordeal lasted a fee hours of me sobbing and trying to clean her to the best of my abilities. She's back on my bed, but my sister is annoyed, my mom is crying, and my dad is angry at me. I'm not too sure if I did overreact or not. Everyone in the household is annoyed at the tantrum I threw. I texted one of my friends and he has my back, but my whole family doesn't like me right now. I don't know what to do. I'm tired and exhausted from the judgemental stares. Did I overreact? AITA for causing an unnecessary scene and making it bigger than it is?
Inference:
The endowment effect refers to the psychological phenomenon where people assign more value to things merely because they own them. In other words, once we own something, we tend to overvalue it relative to its market or objective worth. In the example provided, the individual is emotionally attached to her teddy bear because of its sentimental value—it was gifted by a childhood friend and has been with her during many important moments. This attachment leads her to react very strongly when her mother throws the bear away, to the point where she is distraught over its altered state (dirty, stained, not the same as before).

In this instance, her intense emotional reaction and refusal to let go of the object, despite its physical condition or the fact that it could simply be cleaned or restored, aligns with the concept of the endowment effect. The bear is valued far more by her simply because she owns it and because it represents memories and emotions. The irrational overvaluation—feeling that the bear is now “not the same” after being thrown away—illustrates how ownership can amplify perceived value.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
AITA for telling my girlfriend she 'ruined' my night by insisting she comes along?

My girlfriend and I (both 20f) have been dating for a year. My girlfriend-Jane and I have separate friend groups. Jane doesn't get along with my friends, yet insists she is brought along to our nights out/in. It's incredibly uncomfortable because whilst she's also a woman, these get-togethers are no-partners allowed parties. Plus, she doesn't get along with anyone so it's super awkward. I was invited out to one of their parties, and Jane got upset that I'm going without her. I'll be gone from 10am Friday to afternoon on Saturday. She has no issue with both of us going, but without her, it's an issue.
I said I'd leave later and try to get back earlier, but she wouldn't have it either. I ended up bringing her along and it was a nightmare. The mood was brought down and no one really had fun as all my friends seemed to be walking on eggshells around her.

When we got back, she kept gloating about how much fun she had, but I felt the opposite. I said 'well, I'm glad someone had fun.'. She got upset and asked what I meant. I explained that it was a friend night in, and she wasn't invited. She got super upset and pulled some crap about how it's 'toxic' that I want to have a night out without her. She says she's hurt that I 1) didn't want her there and 2) that I said she ruined the night.

I just wanted to spend time with my friends, 1 on 1. AITA?
Inference:
The endowment effect is a phenomenon from behavioral economics where people tend to value things more highly simply because they own them. Essentially, when individuals “own” an item, they demand a higher price to give it up than they would be willing to pay to acquire it if they didn't have it. Common examples include experiments where participants who are given a mug (for instance) are less willing to trade it for a bar of chocolate than someone who does not own it.

In the situation described in the post, the conflict revolves around the girlfriend insisting on being included during outings, while the narrator feels that her presence creates an uncomfortable atmosphere with his friends. The dispute is more about boundary issues and personal preferences within the relationship rather than an instance of the endowment effect.

There is no clear indication that either party is overvaluing something purely because it belongs to them. The girlfriend’s insistence on being included may stem from her own insecurities or expectations in the relationship, but it isn’t an example of valuing something more simply because it is “owned” (which is the essence of the endowment effect).

Therefore, while the situation touches on themes of value and personal entitlement, it does not illustrate the endowment effect as defined in behavioral economics.

ANSWER: No

Example:

Asshole
So earlier today I was sitting in my car waiting for my wife. I’m a 32 year old man and my wife is 31. But as I was waiting for my wife I saw a girl that looked to be about 14 years old walking with her little sister. This girl lives in our building with her family. But because we live in New York City there’s concrete practically everywhere and it was wet. And in our building we have a parking lot for the whole complex, but the ground was wet because they had been cleaning. The girl was carrying her little sister who’s about 3, and she slipped and fell on the concrete. She landed on what looked to be her butt and lower back, while she made sure her sister didn’t hit the ground.

I had my windows down and could hear the girl yelp as she hit the ground, and you could hear her hit the ground. She then stayed where she was for about 45 seconds all the while making sure her sister was okay. She then helped her sister up and then got up off the ground. But when she started walking she had a noticeable limp that wasn’t there before she fell. I then went back to minding my own business after the girl wasn’t in my line of sight anymore. My wife then got back in the car and told me she had seen the girl fall and that she spoke to her to make sure she was okay. And then she asked me why I hadn’t said anything to make sure she wasn’t seriously injured seeing that her parents weren’t with her. And I told her that I didn’t care because she wasn’t my kid.

My wife then told me the least I could’ve done was warn her about the ground being wet. So again I told her not my kid not my problem. She then said how if that was our kid then we would’ve wanted someone to warn her, but seeing as she’s not my kid I don’t care what happens to her. So AITA for not asking the girl if she was okay?
Inference:
The Endowment Effect is a behavioral economics concept that refers to the tendency for people to assign more value to things merely because they own them. It typically manifests in contexts where ownership raises the subjective value of an object, so that people demand more money to give up an item than they would be willing to pay to acquire it in the first place. 

In contrast, the scenario in the provided story is about whether the person should have intervened or checked on a young girl who fell, and his indifference seems to be tied to the fact that the child is not his own. The behavior described relates more to a kind of parental favoritism or selective responsibility rather than the overvaluation of something one owns. While his perspective—that he cares more about his own child—might hint at a bias toward those he feels a connection to, that bias is not the same as the Endowment Effect. The Endowment Effect deals with the irrational escalation in valuation that occurs when people view possessed objects as more valuable than equivalent non-owned objects. 

Thus, the scenario provided does not fit as an example of the Endowment Effect.
