She then stayed where she was for about 45 seconds all the while making sure her sister was okay. She then helped her sister up and then got up off the ground. But when she started walking she had a noticeable limp that wasn’t there before she fell. I then went back to minding my own business after the girl wasn’t in my line of sight anymore. My wife then got back in the car and told me she had seen the girl fall and that she spoke to her to make sure she was okay. And then she asked me why I hadn’t said anything to make sure she wasn’t seriously injured seeing that her parents weren’t with her. And I told her that I didn’t care because she wasn’t my kid.

My wife then told me the least I could’ve done was warn her about the ground being wet. So again I told her not my kid not my problem. She then said how if that was our kid then we would’ve wanted someone to warn her, but seeing as she’s not my kid I don’t care what happens to her. So AITA for not asking the girl if she was okay?
Inference:
The scenario described involves a man choosing not to intervene or show concern for a girl who isn't his child after she falls. The core concept at play here centers around selective empathy or prioritizing individuals based on their relationship to oneself. This behavior might be influenced by factors such as in-group favoritism, where individuals give preferential treatment to those they perceive as part of their own group (in this case, his immediate family) over others.

The **Endowment Effect**, on the other hand, is a principle from behavioral economics which suggests that people assign more value to things merely because they own them. It typically pertains to the valuation of possessions or assets and how ownership increases their perceived worth, even without any objective reason for the increased value.

In the given example, the man's actions are more about the disparity in care between his own family and strangers, rather than valuing something more simply because he owns it. Therefore, his behavior doesn't align directly with the Endowment Effect.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
so i was just trying to have a chill night. did some pilates to decompress a bit. and then my boyfriend decides to go on a full hour-long rant about how much he hates rachel zegler — like, actual anger, showing me videos, replaying clips, all of it. because apparently… her facial expressions are annoying. she’s “full of herself,” “too smug,” “laughs too loud,” “thinks she’s smart,” and the biggest sin of all — she said the original snow white was scary when she was a kid.

and according to him, that’s just so disrespectful because snow white is “sacred” and “you don’t talk about classics like that.” dude. she said a movie scared her when she was little. that’s it.

and the whole time i’m just sitting there like… ok this feels off. like this is not about rachel zegler. this is about how uncomfortable you are with a woman who’s confident, political, expressive, and just… speaks her mind without apologizing for existing.

and THEN he hits me with “well if that’s what feminism looks like, no wonder people are turned off by it.” like it’s her job to make feminism cute and likable for dudes. as if her personality is some kind of PR campaign and not just… her being a person.

and then the best part — he tells me that i don’t actually like her either. that i’m only defending her because she’s feminist and that deep down i must find her annoying too. like??? sorry for having my own opinion i guess??

idk. i feel drained. the convo stressed me out more than my actual workout. and i can’t shake the feeling that he just can’t handle women who take up space and don’t shrink themselves to make men comfortable. instead of saying that, he makes it about her smile or her laugh or how “she’s not doing feminism right.”

am i overreacting? or is this just the most textbook patriarchal nonsense ever??
Inference:
Naive cynicism is a term used in some psychological discussions to capture a particular kind of belief: the idea that other people’s actions are driven primarily by hidden self-interest or ulterior motives—even when they appear to be reasonable or straightforward. It suggests that people generally assume others are being disingenuous or manipulative while often considering one’s own behavior as more genuine or “noble.” In contexts where naive cynicism comes up, the focus is on this discrepancy between how we view ourselves versus how we view others’ motivations.

In this example, the boyfriend’s rant about Rachel Zegler is largely an expression of sexist, reactionary views and a dismissal of a woman’s agency and expression. His comments become a vehicle to criticize not just the actress, but what she represents—confidence, self-expression, and a kind of unapologetic femininity that he finds threatening. Rather than attributing his discontent to hidden self-serving motives in Rachel Zegler’s behavior (or even in his girlfriend’s defense of her), his speech is rooted in a broader misogynistic and patriarchal framework. He isn’t necessarily engaging in naive cynicism about the nature of human motives (i.e., assuming that all or most people act out of pure self-interest) but is rather projecting discomfort with women who don’t conform to his expectations.

Also, his later claim—suggesting that his girlfriend must secretly share his negative view of Rachel Zegler—does reflect a kind of projection and misinterpretation of her motives. However, even this twist isn’t quite what is meant by naive cynicism. It’s more about assuming that her support is not genuine, instead of entertaining the idea that others might have impure motives behind their support. Rather, his argument is less about a general belief that people hide ulterior motives and more about enforcing a prejudiced view of what women should be.

Therefore, while elements of his thinking are cynical (in a general sense) about women’s behavior and feminism, they do not precisely match the academic or theoretical concept of naive cynicism, which is about the assumption that others are inherently self-interested in ways that they are not for oneself.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Ok, I (28f) went over to my boyfriend’s (25m) house for the first time (been dating about a month), and I had somehow never noticed his pillow situation before. When I noticed, I made a comment about how long he’s had the pillows and apparently he’s been using them since he was a kid.

So, I asked him if he had any other pillows and he said he just had the pillow on the left of the first picture, but that his cat usually sleeps on it. I said I don’t really want to sleep on those pillows, and id prefer to sleep at my own place (with clean pillows).

His response? He waited for a minute and then said he would be sad to see that I would choose something as small as pillows come between us spending the night together, but that if I needed to go, that he understood.

I ended up going home and spending the night at my own house instead. I asked if I could bring my own pillows and gently suggested he get rid of his. He said it was totally fine for me to bring a pillow, but that he wouldn’t get rid of his, as they are ‘sentimental’.

Thoughts? I feel like I can’t even kiss him or anything while we’re sleeping because I don’t want him to get his gross pillowness all over me and my clean pillows. 😂
Inference:
Naïve cynicism refers to the tendency to expect that other people’s judgments or actions are inherently self-interested or biased—often more so than our own—and to assume that any deviation from our expectations is due to ulterior motives or a kind of universal human duplicity. In many examples of naïve cynicism, the focus is on suspecting that others are acting in bad faith or under hidden influences while not applying the same skepticism to one’s own actions.

In the case presented, the conflict centers on a seemingly trivial issue—the boyfriend’s sentimental attachment to his old pillows—and the girlfriend’s discomfort with using them. The boyfriend’s comment about being sad if pillows were allowed to come between them does have an emotional or even mildly manipulative tone, but it doesn’t clearly reflect an underlying belief that all others are generally biased or self-interested. Rather, it appears to be a moment of personal quirkiness or a display of sentimentality, rather than evidence that either party believes that all people are acting out of calculated self-interest. 

Though one might be tempted to read a kind of cynicism into either the boyfriend’s response (by assuming he expects her to capitulate) or the girlfriend’s reaction (by reducing his attachment to pillows to something irrational or even “gross”), this scenario is more about individual idiosyncrasies and interpersonal negotiation than about an overarching worldview that all human motives are suspect. There’s no clear indication that either side is projecting a generalized bias onto others that would typify naïve cynicism.

Thus, while emotions and subtle power plays are at work here, the situation does not constitute an instance of naïve cynicism.

ANSWER: No

They’re trying to gradually extract info from me cuz I know where the aliens are, that info I ain’t disclosing to them whatever secret organization they’re with I know they’ve already have a ton of Intel on me as it is. It involves a general distrust in the genuineness or goodwill of others’ actions, often without considering more complex or benign explanations.

In the text you provided, the speaker is not merely expressing a cynical view that others are motivated by selfish or hidden agendas. Instead, the text is a detailed narrative of paranoid conspiracy theories—with the speaker claiming that undercover agents are surveilling them, that secret organizations are at work, and even attributing roles to aliens and secret messages from “voices in my head.” This is more aligned with a paranoiac delusional framework rather than simple naive cynicism. Here, the narrative isn’t a generalized distrust or cynical reinterpretation of everyday actions; rather, it is an intricate, self-reinforcing conspiracy belief system built upon hallucinated evidence and claimed revelations.

Thus, the example illustrates paranoid delusions and conspiratorial thinking rather than the type of generalized, oversimplified distrust in others that is characteristic of naive cynicism.

Example:
AITA for backing out of a 15-minute favor when it suddenly turned into an hour-plus-long ordeal?
Context: I work from home two days per week; today is one of those days. My wife's workday ends at 4:00, mine ends at 5:30.

Today, when my wife got home (about 4:15), she called me downstairs pretty much as soon as she came in the front door, to tell me that she's left her car running and would I please take it over to Discount Tire (DT) because one of the tires is low. (For those not aware, DT provides complementary inflation and (non-sidewall) tire repairs.) Without complaint, I agree because it's only a 5-minute drive each way, so I can just take a quick 15-minute break from work. I drive her car down there, and the guy tops up 3 tires, but on the 4th his machine won't dispense any air. I see him check it with a manual pressure gauge and then he comes up to the window and tells me that the tire is under 15 PSI, so he can't inflate it, but he says they're not very busy right now, they could repair the tire after only about a half-hour wait. I let him know that I need to get back to work, is there any way he can add even a little bit of air so I can maybe have my wife bring it back and wait? He says no, because it's "basically flat".

I call my wife to let her know this - my intention is to ask her if I drive back home, would she want to drive it back to DT now since the wait is relatively short (when they're busy, it can be a 2+hour wait), or if not I can at least make an appointment while I'm here. But I don't even get that far; she just wants me to stay and wait for it (even though she's already done working for the day). I tell her I really need to get back to work, and she gets very upset. I ask DT Guy what exactly he meant by "basically flat" and he said I'm at 13 PSI. I confirm with him that this means I'm not at immediate risk of the rim tearing up the inside of the tire if I drive it back home right now, so I tell my wife that I'm coming back and I'll be there in 5 minutes. As I'm driving home I get a couple of texts, including "I'll just have you drive me to work tomorrow and my car can sit in the f***ing driveway for all I care", but of course I don't read them until I get home.

I go inside to make another attempt to explain the specifics of the situation (I haven't even been able to tell her that it's not actually flat flat, yet), but she refuses to listen to a word of it, telling me she isn't going to listen to anything I have to say for the next week, and that I've "ruined everything".

I don't recall every word exchanged, but I know I did tell her that she was acting like a child, and in the end saying "Fine, I'll go back there and I'll just have to work until 8pm tonight!" to which she responded with "Good, I don't want to see you!"

I did go back to DT, and started composing this post while waiting.

AITA?

Editing to answer some common questions.

We do own a portable air compressor, it takes about 5 minutes for it to fill one tire, and it's in the trunk of her car.
Taking care of car things is my chore, but every time she's asked me to inflate her tires I have done so - I wasn't neglecting them. Also, the last time I put air in, I told her that she needs to make a trip to DT after work ASAP (because I work until 5:30 and DT closes at 6:00) to get that tire checked for damage, since it loses air faster than the others.
She is generally in charge of discretionary spending, so if the tire had needed to be replaced (repairs are free at DT), she would need to be there to compare the options available.
DT is the opposite direction from home as her work, that's probably why she didn't go there on her way home from work.
She didn't drive my car to DT because we only have one key for it, and it didn't occur to me to take it out of my pocket before leaving.
No, she is not like this all the time.
Inference:
Naive cynicism is the idea that other people’s behavior is predominantly driven by self-interest, even when they might have good reasons or external constraints that explain what they do. It’s the assumption that people’s actions are insincere or that they hide self-serving motives behind their actions. A person exhibiting naive cynicism would quickly conclude that others’ decisions are merely masking selfish objectives.

In the example given, the husband’s account mainly focuses on a frustrating chain of events during what was supposed to be a short errand that turned into an extended ordeal. His frustration is directed at the sudden change in the nature of the favor, and his criticism of his wife (“acting like a child”) reflects a personal, emotional response to what he perceives as an unreasonable demand from his partner. Rather than interpreting his wife’s behavior as motivated by hidden self-interest or insincerity, he is simply irritated by the situation and her emotional response. He focuses on the tangible details (the tire’s PSI level, the turnaround time, his work schedule) and is upset that his practical considerations aren’t acknowledged.

While he does express resentment and judgement, his account isn’t essentially about assuming that everyone has ulterior motives or that people’s expressed concerns or requests are concealing self-serving reasons. Instead, it appears to be a reaction to a miscommunication and differing expectations between him and his wife. That is, it’s more about exasperation with how things escalated unexpectedly rather than a preconceived bias that his wife’s (or anyone’s) actions are inherently selfish or insincere.

Thus, the situation described isn’t an instance of naive cynicism; it’s an interpersonal discrepancy and frustration with how a simple favor turned into a prolonged hassle, compounded by a breakdown in communication.

ANSWER: No

Example:
My(19M) girlfriend(19F) is a very private person. She never posts anything on social media, and usually she tends to be very secretive, like I found that she kind of drives conversations towards talking about me, and my interests. But it’s really hard to learn more about her because she doesn’t let me. She’s like this everyone except for her best friend Marie.

Above all else, she is super super possessive about her phone, she’s never showed me any of her photos or anything, she always takes her phone with her, she has one of those advanced passcodes, and she always turns her phone away from my direction, and just acts a little sus in general.

This has caused me lots of mental torture, as I don’t know what’s going on, if she even likes me, I keep on thinking I’m not good enough for her, and it just feels weird that she’s so cautious around me.
Inference:
Naive cynicism refers to the tendency to interpret others’ ambiguous behaviors as being driven by self-interest or hidden motives—even when a benign explanation is just as likely. That is, rather than considering that someone’s actions might be due to personality, situational factors, or personal preferences, a naively cynical person immediately assumes there is an ulterior, usually negative, intent behind what they observe.

In the example provided, the narrator focuses on his girlfriend’s preference for privacy and secretiveness, immediately interpreting these behaviors as signs that she might be hiding something or perhaps not genuinely interested in him. He infers that her secretiveness—like not sharing her photos or turning away her phone—is driven by suspicious motivations. In doing so, he dismisses alternative explanations (such as valuing privacy or simply not being comfortable with sharing personal details widely) and instead reads into her behavior an intentional effort to keep him out of the loop, which makes him feel inadequate and tormented.

This pattern of thought is a classic case of assuming negative, self-serving motives in someone else’s actions without compelling evidence. The narrator’s emotional distress (mental torture, feeling not good enough) is linked to this interpretation, suggesting that his mindset might be tainted by an overly cynical view of her intentions. He has taken what might be normal individual differences in how people handle privacy and turned them into a personal indictment of her character.

Given the definition of naive cynicism and the way the narrator projects a negative, self-interest–based motive on his girlfriend’s behavior, it is reasonable to regard this as an instance of naive cynicism.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
Before you ask no, this is not the teacher's perspective on the 'AITA for screaming at my son's teacher an making her cry?' post.

Last Wednesday I was teaching my class when a student approached me and told me he had a migrane, he asked if he could go to the nurse and ask to go home because he felt really bad. I assumed that the kid was either just trying to get out of class, especially because this was in math which he doesn't do particularly well in or he just had a headache and was over exaggerating as kids do ( he is 8, I honestly didn't think he even knew what a migrane is). I told him to drink some water and sit back down and if he still felt bad after the lesson then I would take him to the nurse during break and he could have some Calpol. I figured this would work with both options, since he still had to stay in maths and if he actually was sick he wouldn't mind missing his break, we would also need to call his mum to give him Calpol, who would confirm if he actually had a migrane or was just over exaggerating.

However about 10 minutes later I heard a loud thud and turned around to see he had fainted and was now lying on the floor unconscious. I immediately sent another student to get the nurse and began trying to wake him up. He regained consciousness after about 2 minutes and we got him some water. The receptionist rung his mum and she picked him up around 10 minutes later. The next 2 days he wasn't present in class and I began to grow concerned. On Monday before school started his mum came in and began to scream at me, threatening to call the police on me for criminal negligence and get me fired, she also said some other things which I won't repeat, she then told me her son will no longer be present in my class and she would get him moved to another class.

At the time my reasoning made sense but now I'm starting to think I'm in the wrong. AITA?
Inference:
Naive cynicism is the tendency to assume that other people's behaviors or reported experiences are driven by selfish, manipulative, or deceitful motives, often underestimating the possibility that those behaviors can be honest, inadvertent, or even genuine. In the example provided, the teacher initially evaluates his student's claim of having a migraine in a way that dismisses the possibility of genuine illness. Instead of considering that the student might really be in need of help, he immediately categorizes the account as either an attempt to escape a subject he dislikes or as a case of exaggeration typical of children. 

This interpretation reflects naive cynicism because the teacher's first impulse is to see a hidden agenda (i.e., a plan to avoid class or a tendency to exaggerate) rather than acknowledging the chance that the student’s distress might be authentic. The teacher’s reasoning implicitly assumes that the student's statement is not trustworthy and must be carefully manipulated to meet the teacher’s own goals of maintaining order in class, rather than prioritizing the student's potential need for assistance.

Thus, while the teacher later questions his own judgment after the situation escalates, his initial approach clearly exhibits the hallmark of naive cynicism by attributing a duplicitous motive to the student’s simple request. 

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
Bit of a stupid question but I just want to see if I'm wrong.

Background: my girlfriend and I do long distance. We see each other 4-5 times a year for a week or two each time. We have been dating for 1.5 years.

As the title suggests, my girlfriend woke up and was quiet. I tried talking to her but she didn't respond. She quietly made her food while I was helping her pack. She ate the food and then told me im an inconsiderate person for not helping her (make food for her) when she had low blood sugar. I could not tell since she was walking around normally (or that's what I thought). I asked her to communicate this but she thinks I should be able to tell because she can't speak when she has low blood sugar. She is currently mad at me. This has happened once before so maybe I should have picked up on it but somehow didn't.

So AITA or should she have given some sort of a clue to let me know she's feeling unwell?
Inference:
Naive cynicism is a cognitive bias in which someone assumes that other people’s judgments, decisions, or behaviors are largely driven by biases or self-interest, while often failing to recognize similar influences on their own thinking. A person exhibiting naive cynicism tends to believe that others are less insightful, more misled by their experiences, or more influenced by external factors than oneself.

Looking at the provided example—it describes a situation in a long-distance relationship where a girlfriend, affected by low blood sugar, did not communicate her condition in a way that her partner could easily detect, and then later criticized him for not “picking up on” her state. The dilemma here revolves around miscommunication and differing expectations in the relationship regarding expressing or detecting signs of feeling unwell. The boyfriend wonders whether his girlfriend should have given clearer signals.

This situation does not clearly illustrate the pattern of naive cynicism. Instead of attributing her actions to hidden self-serving motives or assuming that her nonverbal cues were the result of a biased or manipulative state, the boyfriend is just trying to understand whether she should clarify her condition better. His reasoning process in this instance appears to be focused on the potential need for better communication rather than assuming that she is purposefully misrepresenting her state or that others (including him) are systematically less capable of understanding subtle cues.

Therefore, the example is not an instance of naive cynicism—it’s more about expectations in communication rather than a cognitive bias where one assumes others’ thoughts or actions are significantly flawed by bias while exempting one’s own understanding.

ANSWER: No

Example:
AITA for backing out of a 15-minute favor when it suddenly turned into an hour-plus-long ordeal?
Context: I work from home two days per week; today is one of those days. My wife's workday ends at 4:00, mine ends at 5:30.

Today, when my wife got home (about 4:15), she called me downstairs pretty much as soon as she came in the front door, to tell me that she's left her car running and would I please take it over to Discount Tire (DT) because one of the tires is low. (For those not aware, DT provides complementary inflation and (non-sidewall) tire repairs.) Without complaint, I agree because it's only a 5-minute drive each way, so I can just take a quick 15-minute break from work. I drive her car down there, and the guy tops up 3 tires, but on the 4th his machine won't dispense any air. I see him check it with a manual pressure gauge and then he comes up to the window and tells me that the tire is under 15 PSI, so he can't inflate it, but he says they're not very busy right now, they could repair the tire after only about a half-hour wait. I let him know that I need to get back to work, is there any way he can add even a little bit of air so I can maybe have my wife bring it back and wait? He says no, because it's "basically flat".

I call my wife to let her know this - my intention is to ask her if I drive back home, would she want to drive it back to DT now since the wait is relatively short (when they're busy, it can be a 2+hour wait), or if not I can at least make an appointment while I'm here. But I don't even get that far; she just wants me to stay and wait for it (even though she's already done working for the day). I tell her I really need to get back to work, and she gets very upset. I ask DT Guy what exactly he meant by "basically flat" and he said I'm at 13 PSI. I confirm with him that this means I'm not at immediate risk of the rim tearing up the inside of the tire if I drive it back home right now, so I tell my wife that I'm coming back and I'll be there in 5 minutes. As I'm driving home I get a couple of texts, including "I'll just have you drive me to work tomorrow and my car can sit in the f***ing driveway for all I care", but of course I don't read them until I get home.

I go inside to make another attempt to explain the specifics of the situation (I haven't even been able to tell her that it's not actually flat flat, yet), but she refuses to listen to a word of it, telling me she isn't going to listen to anything I have to say for the next week, and that I've "ruined everything".

I don't recall every word exchanged, but I know I did tell her that she was acting like a child, and in the end saying "Fine, I'll go back there and I'll just have to work until 8pm tonight!" to which she responded with "Good, I don't want to see you!"

I did go back to DT, and started composing this post while waiting.

AITA?

Editing to answer some common questions.

We do own a portable air compressor, it takes about 5 minutes for it to fill one tire, and it's in the trunk of her car.
Taking care of car things is my chore, but every time she's asked me to inflate her tires I have done so - I wasn't neglecting them. Also, the last time I put air in, I told her that she needs to make a trip to DT after work ASAP (because I work until 5:30 and DT closes at 6:00) to get that tire checked for damage, since it loses air faster than the others.
She is generally in charge of discretionary spending, so if the tire had needed to be replaced (repairs are free at DT), she would need to be there to compare the options available.
DT is the opposite direction from home as her work, that's probably why she didn't go there on her way home from work.
She didn't drive my car to DT because we only have one key for it, and it didn't occur to me to take it out of my pocket before leaving.
No, she is not like this all the time.
Inference:
The scenario you've described revolves around a misunderstanding and escalating frustration between a husband and wife due to a favor taking longer than expected. "Naive Cynicism" typically refers to a simplistic and somewhat mistrusting view of others' motives, often assuming selfishness without sufficient evidence.

In this situation, the conflict arises from unexpected delays and miscommunication rather than a fundamental mistrust or cynical worldview. Both parties are reacting to the inconvenience and stress of the situation rather than displaying a pervasive cynical attitude towards each other's intentions or character.

Therefore, this example does not exemplify "Naive Cynicism."

ANSWER: No

Example:
My(19M) girlfriend(19F) is a very private person. She never posts anything on social media, and usually she tends to be very secretive, like I found that she kind of drives conversations towards talking about me, and my interests. But it’s really hard to learn more about her because she doesn’t let me. She’s like this everyone except for her best friend Marie.

Above all else, she is super super possessive about her phone, she’s never showed me any of her photos or anything, she always takes her phone with her, she has one of those advanced passcodes, and she always turns her phone away from my direction, and just acts a little sus in general.

This has caused me lots of mental torture, as I don’t know what’s going on, if she even likes me, I keep on thinking I’m not good enough for her, and it just feels weird that she’s so cautious around me.
Inference:
The scenario you've described appears to reflect elements of **Naive Cynicism**. Naive cynicism involves making negative assumptions or interpretations about others' motives or behaviors without sufficient evidence. In this case, the boyfriend is interpreting his girlfriend's privacy and secretiveness as potentially indicative of negative intentions or lack of genuine feelings, which may not necessarily be true. His assumptions lead to feelings of insecurity and mistrust, even though there might be other explanations for her behavior, such as personality traits or personal boundaries.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
Before you ask no, this is not the teacher's perspective on the 'AITA for screaming at my son's teacher an making her cry?' post.

Last Wednesday I was teaching my class when a student approached me and told me he had a migrane, he asked if he could go to the nurse and ask to go home because he felt really bad. I assumed that the kid was either just trying to get out of class, especially because this was in math which he doesn't do particularly well in or he just had a headache and was over exaggerating as kids do ( he is 8, I honestly didn't think he even knew what a migrane is). I told him to drink some water and sit back down and if he still felt bad after the lesson then I would take him to the nurse during break and he could have some Calpol. I figured this would work with both options, since he still had to stay in maths and if he actually was sick he wouldn't mind missing his break, we would also need to call his mum to give him Calpol, who would confirm if he actually had a migrane or was just over exaggerating.

However about 10 minutes later I heard a loud thud and turned around to see he had fainted and was now lying on the floor unconscious. I immediately sent another student to get the nurse and began trying to wake him up. He regained consciousness after about 2 minutes and we got him some water. The receptionist rung his mum and she picked him up around 10 minutes later. The next 2 days he wasn't present in class and I began to grow concerned. On Monday before school started his mum came in and began to scream at me, threatening to call the police on me for criminal negligence and get me fired, she also said some other things which I won't repeat, she then told me her son will no longer be present in my class and she would get him moved to another class.

At the time my reasoning made sense but now I'm starting to think I'm in the wrong. AITA?
Inference:
The concept of **Naive Cynicism** involves making unfounded negative assumptions about others' motives or behaviors without adequate evidence. In the provided scenario, the teacher initially assumes that the student's claim of having a migraine is either an attempt to escape math class or an exaggeration typical of an 8-year-old. This assumption reflects a cynical view of the student's intentions without sufficient justification. The teacher's perspective is dismissive and does not consider the genuine possibility of the student being ill, which aligns with the essence of naive cynicism.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Background: my girlfriend and I do long distance. We see each other 4-5 times a year for a week or two each time. We have been dating for 1.5 years.

I could not tell since she was walking around normally (or that's what I thought). I asked her to communicate this but she thinks I should be able to tell because she can't speak when she has low blood sugar. She is currently mad at me. So AITA or should she have given some sort of a clue to let me know she's feeling unwell?
Inference:
Naive Cynicism involves assuming that others are primarily motivated by selfish or negative intentions without sufficient evidence. In the provided scenario, the individual is dealing with a miscommunication stemming from their girlfriend's low blood sugar levels, which affected her behavior. The boyfriend is seeking clarity on whether he is at fault or if the girlfriend should have communicated her needs more effectively.

This situation doesn't exhibit Naive Cynicism because there is no evident assumption that the girlfriend's actions are driven by malicious or purely selfish motives. Instead, it highlights a genuine misunderstanding influenced by the girlfriend's health condition. The boyfriend is questioning the dynamics of their communication rather than making cynical assumptions about her intentions.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
I (F52) wear prescription glasses and have done since I was eight years old. I have really bad myopia (I'm nearsighted) and I'm essentially legally blind without my eyewear. As a child, I was bullied and was actually told that having glasses didn't make me better or smarter than the other girls. (No kidding! I never thought they did!)
So, I currently work in an elementary school and in recent years have noticed an upswing in students coming to school wearing "fake" glasses, by which I specifically mean glasses that either have non-corrective lenses or have no lenses at all. I try to ignore it but I find it both distracting and disrespectful. One child was wearing a pair that were quite obviously broken frames with the lens orbit completely snapped and incapable of even holding a lens anymore. Those glasses frames ought to have been thrown away because the sharp edge (especially so near to the eyes) was dangerous. The "glasses" were put on and removed dozens of times and used as a distraction from doing schoolwork. Another student, a 7-year old, came in a pair that are a copy of the prop worn by the character Elphaba in the recent Wicked movie, but the glasses are adult sized and because they don't fit the child, routinely obstruct her vision. Again, they had non-corrective lenses. She repeatedly asked those around her, "Don't they make me look smart?"

I reported the issues to administration and was told that I had to allow the students to continue to wear the glasses because I had no authority to say anything about their "choices in apparel" since there's nothing about using non-functional medical devices in the school's dress code. Furthermore, I was told that the kids were just having fun and "don't be so sensitive".
Inference:
Normalcy bias generally refers to a cognitive bias where people underestimate or dismiss the possibility of a disaster or abnormal situation because they expect things to continue as they normally have. It can lead individuals to ignore early warning signs or avoid preparing for potential emergencies because they believe that “nothing bad will happen.”

In this example, what we see is that some students are wearing non-functional glasses as a fashion statement or as a playful accessory, and the administration is dismissing the issue by calling it harmless fun. The teacher, however, is concerned about the potential safety risk of broken frames and the distraction this behavior causes in school. While the dismissive attitude of the administration might indicate a tendency to view the abnormal behavior as just a normal part of student life, it isn’t a manifestation of normalcy bias in the classic sense—where one underestimates a looming disaster or risk because of an expectation that nothing will change.

Here, the issue is more about policy and safety concerns related to non-functional “glasses” rather than a situation where there is a failure to prepare for or acknowledge a real disaster or dangerous event due to an assumption of normality. The behavior, while unconventional, isn’t being ignored because the administration believes a catastrophe will not occur; rather, they are interpreting it as harmless play in the context of student conduct. This is not an instance of normalcy bias as defined in its original usage, where people discount potential disasters by assuming that everything will continue normally.

ANSWER: No

Example: so , long story short , i was at school , following my classmates to our next classroom. i stopped a bit to talk with another friend from another class , as i was doing so , i noticed my class was getting a bit distant , so i started following them again. and as i did. i got a bit left behind. as i was passing through some 11th graders classroom. i caught one severly staring at me with a really disturbing stare. when i turned around i noticed they were two. i didnt expect for them to be staring at me for long. i tried saying hi (i was standing still without moving) and they kept staring at me with a look in their eyes i cant describe. i at that moment felt extremely uncomfortable as i then i started to walk away. another guy (from the same class as them) was laughing and saying something about me probably , as i got uncomfortable , i decided to leave. i walked for a few steps and i could hear them whispering something about my leather jacket. some of them were 17 or 16. hell i dont even know. that just made me uncomfortable because it happened out of the blue and i never did anything to them or talk to them. i just know that im really uncomfortable about all this and maybe im overreacting
Inference:

This bias typically manifests when individuals fail to prepare or respond appropriately to the possibility of a crisis because they assume nothing out of the ordinary will happen.

In the provided example, the individual describes an unsettling interaction—receiving uncomfortable stares and noticing peers whispering—rather than a situation that could lead to a widespread catastrophe or disaster. The reaction in the scenario is one of immediate discomfort and choosing to leave the area. Although the person questions whether their reaction is overblown, there is no indication that they are underestimating the potential severity or impact of a larger event based on the assumption that everything is “normal.” Instead, the account describes a single, isolated incident that caused personal discomfort.

The experience does not involve the underestimation or outright dismissal of a threat based on it fitting with a “normal” outlook of the world. The discomfort and resultant behavior (leaving the area) indicate that the individual was not in a state of denial or inaction that is characteristic of normalcy bias. Instead, they were reacting to a specific interaction that felt abnormal and chose to alter their course accordingly rather than ignoring it.

Thus, this example does not illustrate normalcy bias.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I (F21) and my boyfriend (M23) of five years went to my favorite restaurant a few weeks ago. The meal was great and we both really enjoyed ourselves. It was perfect, a completely perfect dinner. I paid the $60 check and we went out to the parking lot to the car. I live in a huge college town along with that Saturday night being a senior ball so the town was busy.

We get back to the car and the cars surrounding it was parked exactly the same as they were when we went in. There were cars to each side of his car along with a truck parallel parked behind him at least two car lengths away. In front of him was the wall of the restaurant and behind him was the roadway in the parking lot then the parallel parked truck at a distance to clarify.

He starts to back out of the space and after a few tries he says he can’t do it. I say instantly I can spot him so he can get out. He says no and that it won’t help him because the truck behind him wasn’t there when he pulled into the spot and he was scared of hitting it. (It was there when he pulled into the spot.) He also added he doesn’t want others to see me spotting him like he can’t handle his vehicle. I say okay, I’ll go into the restaurant and find the owner of one of the car and ask if there was any way they would move so he could get out, didn’t want to but it was the only choice. He says no and kinda flips his shit (throwing his hat and sunglasses into the dash in frustration and also flooring it as if he’s going to hit the building then slamming on the break before he does so.) He calls his parents screaming about not being able to get out of the spot and even locked my door when I tried to get out of the vehicle to go get someone else to help/spot him.

Also when he is on the phone the owner of one of the neighboring cars comes outside. I try to tell him that we talk to her but he ignored me and kept complaining to his parents how there was no way we were getting out of the spot. The owner of the neighboring car gets in another car and leaves while my boyfriend gets off the phone and says: “guess we’re stuck.”

The screaming and me begging him to just let me spot him continues for 20 minutes and he makes a few jabs that I don’t have a license so I wouldn’t understand how he feels. At that point I was really upset and in tears. I had just taken him out to dinner and spent a pretty good amount of money for him to show his ass? Finally he lets me out of the car to spot him and within 2 minutes we are out of the spot.

Later that night I told him that he ruined the night and the dinner I paid for for absolutely no reason. I also added that he always has to find away to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks. He said that what happened was my fault because I should’ve have not spoken to him because it made him more frustrated when he was trying to find a “solution to the problem.” AITA here?
Inference:
Normalcy bias refers to the tendency for people to assume that things will continue as they normally have, sometimes ignoring signs or evidence that a disruptive or dangerous event might be imminent. It’s typically discussed in relation to disasters or major unexpected events, where someone downplays the potential for disaster because nothing like it has happened before in their experience.

In this example, the boyfriend’s behavior centers on his inability to accept help, his insistence on sticking to his own idea of how to solve the problem, and his frustration when challenged. He appears to be unwilling to acknowledge that the situation might be remedied by a small change (i.e., letting someone help him spot the car) and reacts emotionally and defensively when his approach is questioned. However, his actions aren’t an example of normalcy bias. Instead, they reflect personal obstinacy, emotional reactivity, and possibly an issue with control and pride—not a broader psychological tendency to underestimate the possibility of a disruptive event because one believes everything will always be normal.

Therefore, while the boyfriend’s behavior might be labeled as irrational or stubborn within the context of the argument and relationship conflict, it does not fit the specific psychological concept of normalcy bias.

ANSWER: No

Example:
AITA for not asking if someone was okay?
Asshole
So earlier today I was sitting in my car waiting for my wife. I’m a 32 year old man and my wife is 31. But as I was waiting for my wife I saw a girl that looked to be about 14 years old walking with her little sister. This girl lives in our building with her family. But because we live in New York City there’s concrete practically everywhere and it was wet. And in our building we have a parking lot for the whole complex, but the ground was wet because they had been cleaning. The girl was carrying her little sister who’s about 3, and she slipped and fell on the concrete. She landed on what looked to be her butt and lower back, while she made sure her sister didn’t hit the ground.

I had my windows down and could hear the girl yelp as she hit the ground, and you could hear her hit the ground. She then stayed where she was for about 45 seconds all the while making sure her sister was okay. She then helped her sister up and then got up off the ground. But when she started walking she had a noticeable limp that wasn’t there before she fell. I then went back to minding my own business after the girl wasn’t in my line of sight anymore. My wife then got back in the car and told me she had seen the girl fall and that she spoke to her to make sure she was okay. And then she asked me why I hadn’t said anything to make sure she wasn’t seriously injured seeing that her parents weren’t with her. And I told her that I didn’t care because she wasn’t my kid.

My wife then told me the least I could’ve done was warn her about the ground being wet. So again I told her not my kid not my problem. She then said how if that was our kid then we would’ve wanted someone to warn her, but seeing as she’s not my kid I don’t care what happens to her. So AITA for not asking the girl if she was okay?
Inference:
Normalcy bias is the tendency to believe that things will continue to operate in the normal way even when faced with a potential crisis. It often leads people to underestimate the possibility or impact of a disaster or emergency because they assume that nothing will change. In the situation you described, the man witnessed an accident involving a young girl and did nothing to check on her or warn her about the wet ground—his rationale being that since she was not “his kid,” he did not care.

This behavior, though, isn’t really about expecting that things will continue normally despite a looming threat. Instead, it reflects a moral indifference or a lack of responsibility toward someone who isn’t part of his immediate family. He doesn’t ignore the event because he assumes nothing will change; he consciously chooses not to intervene because he doesn’t feel obligated toward someone not related to him. That’s different from normalcy bias, where one minimizes danger due to the belief that circumstances won’t worsen.

In summary, this example is not an instance of normalcy bias. It’s more aligned with apathy or a personal moral stance about helping someone who isn’t close to him.

ANSWER: No

**Normalcy Bias** refers to the psychological state where individuals underestimate the possibility and impact of a disaster or unexpected event, leading them to believe that things will continue to function as they normally have. In the scenario described:

1. **Initial Assumption**: The teacher assumed that the student's claim of having a migraine was either an attempt to avoid math or an over-exaggeration, typical of an 8-year-old's understanding of ailments. This assumption downplayed the potential severity of the situation.

2. **Underestimation of Risk**: By suggesting the student drink water and wait until after the lesson, the teacher underestimated the possibility that the student's condition could deteriorate, which it eventually did when the student fainted.

3. **Delayed Response**: The teacher's initial reaction was based on normal expectations of student behavior, leading to a delayed and inadequate response to a genuine health issue.

4. **Aftermath**: The mother's severe reaction further underscores the misjudgment of the situation's seriousness, highlighting the gap between normal expectations and the actual event.

In this context, the teacher's reliance on normalcy—assuming the situation was not severe based on past experiences and typical behavior—led to a lack of appropriate immediate action, aligning with the characteristics of Normalcy Bias.

Example:
I (F21) and my boyfriend (M23) of five years went to my favorite restaurant a few weeks ago. The meal was great and we both really enjoyed ourselves. It was perfect, a completely perfect dinner. I paid the $60 check and we went out to the parking lot to the car. I live in a huge college town along with that Saturday night being a senior ball so the town was busy.

We get back to the car and the cars surrounding it was parked exactly the same as they were when we went in. There were cars to each side of his car along with a truck parallel parked behind him at least two car lengths away. In front of him was the wall of the restaurant and behind him was the roadway in the parking lot then the parallel parked truck at a distance to clarify.

He starts to back out of the space and after a few tries he says he can’t do it. I say instantly I can spot him so he can get out. He says no and that it won’t help him because the truck behind him wasn’t there when he pulled into the spot and he was scared of hitting it. (It was there when he pulled into the spot.) He also added he doesn’t want others to see me spotting him like he can’t handle his vehicle. I say okay, I’ll go into the restaurant and find the owner of one of the car and ask if there was any way they would move so he could get out, didn’t want to but it was the only choice. He says no and kinda flips his shit (throwing his hat and sunglasses into the dash in frustration and also flooring it as if he’s going to hit the building then slamming on the break before he does so.) He calls his parents screaming about not being able to get out of the spot and even locked my door when I tried to get out of the vehicle to go get someone else to help/spot him.

Also when he is on the phone the owner of one of the neighboring cars comes outside. I try to tell him that we talk to her but he ignored me and kept complaining to his parents how there was no way we were getting out of the spot. The owner of the neighboring car gets in another car and leaves while my boyfriend gets off the phone and says: “guess we’re stuck.”

The screaming and me begging him to just let me spot him continues for 20 minutes and he makes a few jabs that I don’t have a license so I wouldn’t understand how he feels. At that point I was really upset and in tears. I had just taken him out to dinner and spent a pretty good amount of money for him to show his ass? Finally he lets me out of the car to spot him and within 2 minutes we are out of the spot.

Later that night I told him that he ruined the night and the dinner I paid for for absolutely no reason. I also added that he always has to find away to destroy any date or thing in general I want to do just because it’s not something he picks. He said that what happened was my fault because I should’ve have not spoken to him because it made him more frustrated when he was trying to find a “solution to the problem.” AITA here?
Inference:
Normalcy bias typically involves underestimating the likelihood or impact of a disaster, leading individuals to believe that things will continue to function as they normally do, even in the face of changing or threatening circumstances. It often results in a delayed or inadequate response to emergencies because individuals assume that the current state of affairs will persist.

In the scenario you've described, the boyfriend exhibits significant anxiety and an overreaction to a relatively minor parking situation. Instead of underestimating a problem or ignoring potential risks, he becomes excessively fearful of hitting the truck, refuses assistance, and overreacts by calling his parents and displaying frustration. This behavior aligns more closely with acute stress or anxiety reactions rather than normalcy bias.

Normalcy bias is characterized by a denial or minimization of impending issues, causing inaction or inadequate preparation. In contrast, the boyfriend's actions demonstrate an overestimation of the problem's severity and an inability to manage stress effectively.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
AITA for not asking if someone was okay?

So earlier today I was sitting in my car waiting for my wife. I’m a 32 year old man and my wife is 31. But as I was waiting for my wife I saw a girl that looked to be about 14 years old walking with her little sister. This girl lives in our building with her family. But because we live in New York City there’s concrete practically everywhere and it was wet. And in our building we have a parking lot for the whole complex, but the ground was wet because they had been cleaning. The girl was carrying her little sister who’s about 3, and she slipped and fell on the concrete. She landed on what looked to be her butt and lower back, while she made sure her sister didn’t hit the ground.

I had my windows down and could hear the girl yelp as she hit the ground, and you could hear her hit the ground. She then stayed where she was for about 45 seconds all the while making sure her sister was okay. She then helped her sister up and then got up off the ground. But when she started walking she had a noticeable limp that wasn’t there before she fell. I then went back to minding my own business after the girl wasn’t in my line of sight anymore. My wife then got back in the car and told me she had seen the girl fall and that she spoke to her to make sure she was okay. And then she asked me why I hadn’t said anything to make sure she wasn’t seriously injured seeing that her parents weren’t with her. And I told her that I didn’t care because she wasn’t my kid.

My wife then told me the least I could’ve done was warn her about the ground being wet. So again I told her not my kid not my problem. She then said how if that was our kid then we would’ve wanted someone to warn her, but seeing as she’s not my kid I don’t care what happens to her. So AITA for not asking the girl if she was okay?
Inference:
Normalcy Bias refers to the tendency of individuals to believe that things will always function the way they normally have, thereby underestimating the possibility of a disaster or unexpected event. This bias often leads to inaction or inadequate preparation in the face of potential crises because individuals assume that rare or extreme events are unlikely to occur.

In the scenario provided, the man's behavior doesn't align with the characteristics of Normalcy Bias. Instead of underestimating a potential disaster or expecting that nothing bad will happen, his actions demonstrate a lack of empathy and concern for others. He chooses not to help the injured girl because she isn't his own child, which reflects apathy rather than an inability to perceive or prepare for an unexpected event.

Therefore, this example does not exemplify Normalcy Bias.

**ANSWER: No**

Instead, it highlights challenges in communication and awareness within a relationship, especially in a long-distance context.

Example:
I hate it when I’m talking about something I really enjoy, something that I put a lot of emotion into explaining and talking about with someone, just for them to say something like “I wasn’t paying attention”. It just makes me feel like they don’t care about what I have to say even though I don’t do the same thing to them. Even when it’s just them looking away from me or doing something that you have to focus on to do makes me feel like they aren’t invested into the conversation like I am. I just wish that I had someone I could talk to that actually put as much effort into talking as I do. I feel like I pay attention most of the time to what people are saying especially when I know it’s something they like, so it kind of hurts when it feels like no one wants to do that for me.
I love watching movies. I know it’s nothing super duper serious that you have to pay attention to but it’s something I really like. I love being invested and watching franchises and stuff and being able to talk about it and express my thoughts and excitement around it. I know that not everyone I met will feel about it the way I do but I still would like to be able to talk about it without feeling like I’m forcing the other person to talk with me. I’m not sure if there’s something I’m doing wrong but I don’t act that way when they talk about something I don’t personally care for. I still listen and comment and let them talk about what they like. I just feel like every time I bring up movies in general that they don’t feel like watching everyone just turns their ears off and zone out on what I’m saying as if it doesn’t matter. And like I said it’s nothing super serious but I still like talking about things I enjoy like that. You don’t have to have viewed something to listen about someone talk about it. It might make it easier to understand but if there’s something you don’t get I know I could explain it. It just seems like nobody wants me to. I wish there was someone who actually wanted me to talk about this stuff. Someone who cared as much as I did. It would make things way easier and it wouldn’t make me feel like a burden or like the person I’m talking to doesn’t care about me when it’s just what I have to say. I’m not sure why things have to be this complicated. It’s just kind of upsetting and always degrading when they say they zoned out. I know that they probably aren’t doing it on purpose and that they probably think I just look at it like it’s a joke but sometimes it actually does hurt my feelings a bit. I wish I didn’t care this much but it’s hard not to.
Inference:
The spotlight effect is a cognitive bias where a person overestimates how much others notice their appearance, behavior, or perceived flaws. In essence, it’s about feeling as if a “spotlight” is constantly on you, causing you to believe that everyone is paying close attention to your every move or mistake—even when they are not. 

In the example provided, the individual expresses frustration when others appear not to be paying attention during conversations about subjects they care deeply about. The core feeling is one of being undervalued and unappreciated rather than the belief that others are hyper-aware of and constantly scrutinizing their behavior or words. The emotional distress stems from a desire for reciprocal engagement and validation, and the hurt when that doesn’t happen, rather than an overestimation of how much attention others are giving them in a broad sense.

Therefore, this example does not illustrate the spotlight effect. Instead, it highlights issues related to feeling ignored or unappreciated in interactions, which is a different experience from the cognitive bias of thinking one is at the center of everyone’s attention.

ANSWER: No

Example:
In my (F18) country 18th birthday is special because it is the legal age. It's typical to have a bigger party, family celebration or other thing like that. As it happened, on the day of my birthday was my close cousin's wedding, an event which my whole family had (and wanted) to attend.

I had no problem with that. My cousin had a whole big event to plan while being tight on budget and if the place she wanted was free on the date of my birthday, then so be it (she wanted for her wedding to take place in a rather picturesque place which is almost always reserved, so she had to take any date which was free). I planned with my parents that we'll celebrate my birthday one week later and that they'll let me hit a club with some of my friends an evening after the wedding as a sort of late celebration. I was actually very happy with this solution.

On the day of my birthday my parents sang me "happy birthday", gave symbolic gifts and off we went for the wedding. Everything was going great but at one point during reception my mother started silencing the band, got the microphone and told to the whole family that my 18th birthday is today and that they have to sing me "happy birthday". She and dad also proceeded to give me big gifts AND a special torte which I was sure I'll receive only one week later.

It was horrendously awkward, both for me and the guests, half of whom I didn't even know. I felt humiliated and like I destroyed my cousin's (with whom I'm very close) wedding. I firmly believe that one shouldn't make another person's big day about themselves and I never, ever wanted my parents to pull something like that. I spent rest of the reception hiding in the corner, hoping that nobody thinks that I really wanted my parents to do a scene during the reception.

When we returned from the reception, my parents were beaming at me, proud of the surprise they did for me and basically they wanted me to praise and thank them. They also said that they called of the celebration next week, since I had "such a big moment" on the wedding day.

I honestly told them that I was feeling humiliated, that I'd really prefer a smaller celebration at home than forced "happy birthday" from the crowd and that I feel like they ruined both my birthday and, what's more important, my cousin's wedding.

Needless to say they're mad at me and say that I'm ungrateful, spoiled brat.

AITA?
Inference:
The spotlight effect is a cognitive bias in which individuals overestimate how much attention others pay to their actions, appearance, or mistakes—believing that their missteps or unique traits are noticed by everyone to a greater extent than they really are. In the case described, the issue does not stem from an internal overestimation of others' scrutiny, but rather from a concrete, highly noticeable action taken by the parents. They deliberately disrupted the cousin’s wedding by publicly celebrating the birthday with much fanfare, and the narrator’s embarrassment was a direct reaction to this forced public display, not an exaggerated belief that others were silently fixated on him.

If it had been a case of the spotlight effect, the narrator might have felt excessively self-conscious about a minor incident or assumed that his own behavior was under an intense, critical gaze, even when it wasn’t. However, here, the focus was induced by external actions at a significant event, making it less about an internal misjudgment of how much attention he was receiving and more about the actual context in which a large audience was made to celebrate him. The discomfort was not simply an internal misperception but a legitimate reaction to a real, awkward situation created by his parents.

Thus, the example does not neatly align with the definition or the typical characteristics of the spotlight effect.

ANSWER: No

But it’s really hard to learn more about her because she doesn’t let me. She’s like this everyone except for her best friend Marie.

Above all else, she is super super possessive about her phone, she’s never showed me any of her photos or anything, she always takes her phone with her, she has one of those advanced passcodes, and she always turns her phone away from my direction, and just acts a little sus in general.

This has caused me lots of mental torture, as I don’t know what’s going on, if she even likes me, I keep on thinking I’m not good enough for her, and it just feels weird that she’s so cautious around me.
Inference:
The **Spotlight Effect** is a psychological phenomenon where individuals overestimate the extent to which others notice aspects of themselves, such as appearance, behavior, or mistakes. It's essentially the feeling that "everyone is watching me," even when that's not the case.

In the scenario you've described, the focus is on your girlfriend's secretive and possessive behavior, particularly regarding her phone and personal information. Your feelings of uncertainty, insecurity, and mental distress seem to stem from her actions and how they affect your perception of the relationship. While you might be experiencing anxiety or insecurity about how you are perceived in the relationship, the primary issue revolves around trust and communication between you and your girlfriend, rather than an overestimation of others' attention to your actions.

Therefore, this situation doesn't align closely with the concept of the Spotlight Effect, as it's more about interpersonal dynamics and personal insecurities within a relationship rather than the belief that others are excessively noticing your behavior.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
In my (F18) country 18th birthday is special because it is the legal age. It's typical to have a bigger party, family celebration or other thing like that. As it happened, on the day of my birthday was my close cousin's wedding, an event which my whole family had (and wanted) to attend.

I had no problem with that. My cousin had a whole big event to plan while being tight on budget and if the place she wanted was free on the date of my birthday, then so be it (she wanted for her wedding to take place in a rather picturesque place which is almost always reserved, so she had to take any date which was free). I planned with my parents that we'll celebrate my birthday one week later and that they'll let me hit a club with some of my friends an evening after the wedding as a sort of late celebration. I was actually very happy with this solution.

On the day of my birthday my parents sang me "happy birthday", gave symbolic gifts and off we went for the wedding. Everything was going great but at one point during reception my mother started silencing the band, got the microphone and told to the whole family that my 18th birthday is today and that they have to sing me "happy birthday". She and dad also proceeded to give me big gifts AND a special torte which I was sure I'll receive only one week later.

It was horrendously awkward, both for me and the guests, half of whom I didn't even know. I felt humiliated and like I destroyed my cousin's (with whom I'm very close) wedding. I firmly believe that one shouldn't make another person's big day about themselves and I never, ever wanted my parents to pull something like that. I spent rest of the reception hiding in the corner, hoping that nobody thinks that I really wanted my parents to do a scene during the reception.

When we returned from the reception, my parents were beaming at me, proud of the surprise they did for me and basically they wanted me to praise and thank them. They also said that they called of the celebration next week, since I had "such a big moment" on the wedding day.

I honestly told them that I was feeling humiliated, that I'd really prefer a smaller celebration at home than forced "happy birthday" from the crowd and that I feel like they ruined both my birthday and, what's more important, my cousin's wedding.

Needless to say they're mad at me and say that I'm ungrateful, spoiled brat.

AITA?
Inference:
The **Spotlight Effect** is a social psychological phenomenon where individuals tend to believe they are being noticed more than they actually are. It's the tendency to overestimate the extent to which one's actions, appearance, or mistakes are observed and judged by others.

In the scenario you described, your parents intentionally made your 18th birthday a focal point during your cousin's wedding by publicly celebrating you, singing "happy birthday," giving you big gifts, and presenting a special torte. This deliberate action led to genuine attention from the guests, many of whom you didn't know. Your feelings of humiliation and embarrassment stemmed from this orchestrated spotlight on your special day happening concurrently with the wedding festivities.

While you experienced significant attention and felt uncomfortable because of it, the **Spotlight Effect** typically involves a perception of being overly observed without actual excess attention. In your case, the attention was real and intentional, not just a perception.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
On Mother’s Day I got and treated my mom to some of her favorite things and places while we spent the whole day together. I went to church with her along with the Mother’s Day Brunch. I also took her shopping and to her favorite expensive restaurant for dinner. In between stops, I gifted her a card, her favorite candies, favorite flowers, and a $200 gc to her favorite spa.

Sometime during the day, I posted on Facebook with a gif photo of an animated mother hugging her child that said “Happy Mother’s Day to all Moms. We love and appreciate everything you do.” I also wrote a paragraph about how thankful and grateful I am for my own mother and I wouldn’t be who I am without her.

About an hour after I get home from dinner, my mom texts me that she didn’t see her Facebook post from me. I told her that I did post to Facebook about Mother’s Day. She then says that she wants her own Facebook post and that if I don’t do it, she must not mean all that much to me. When she texted that I was taken aback. I responded are you serious? I took you out and treated you all day and gave you gifts all day, but none of that matters because of a Facebook post. I called her ungrateful and said we’re going to have another “time out” period. Since then she’s been calling everyone about how disrespectful of a daughter I am. Even my dad is trying to tell me that it’s okay for her to be upset and that I should just get over and excuse it because of what all shes done for me in the past.

Side note: I have had several time out periods with my mother. My mother had the tendency to say something rude or a dig at a person, but when she’s called out on it, she will play like she doesn’t remember what she said. Or will use tears to make it seem like you’re being mean to her.
Inference:
Illusory superiority is a cognitive bias in which people tend to overestimate their own qualities, abilities, or achievements relative to others. In the instance provided, the conflict between the daughter and her mother is centered on emotional expectations and expectations about how love should be demonstrated, especially on social media. The daughter explains that she spent valuable time with her mother, treated her with gifts, and created memorable experiences. When her mother expressed disappointment over not seeing a specific type of Facebook post, the daughter became upset and defensive.

However, what we see here is more a discord over differing perceptions of what constitutes meaningful appreciation rather than the daughter holding an exaggerated or unrealistic view of her own qualities or abilities relative to her mother. The daughter does not explicitly claim that she is inherently superior or that her gestures are so perfect that they automatically outweigh every other form of validation. Instead, she becomes frustrated that her extensive efforts are seemingly negated by the absence of a social media acknowledgment. This response reflects conflicting views on value rather than the type of self-enhancement bias inherent in illusory superiority.

Thus, this example doesn’t represent an instance of illusory superiority—it’s more about a difference in expected forms of recognition and communication between family members.

ANSWER: No

Another reason why is when I called them out about the fact that they’re all undercover agents & what their true motives about acquiring where the aliens were they removed me from the group chat they knew they were caught so they removed me completely to maintain their cover.

I know they’re all undercover agents my voices confirmed it & what their true motives are. Plus the other night at around 10:30 pm I heard a knock at my door and the doorbell rung. I didn’t answer it cuz I know Danielle Courtney & them sent undercover agents to my door to try to acquire about the aliens I know of. I was freaking out for real, I was like I ain’t say shit to them. I know that there are aliens in disguise walking among us my voices told me.
Inference:

The example you provided is a narrative filled with paranoia and delusional beliefs, specifically persecutory delusions, where the person believes that hidden groups and undercover agents are monitoring and controlling aspects of their life. The speaker claims to have special knowledge (told by voices) about secret organizations and even aliens, which reflects a distorted perception of reality rather than a biased evaluation of their own superiority over others.

In this case, the narrative is less about thinking "I am better than others" or "I have skills or qualities that put me above the average person" and more about believing that there is a conspiracy against them. The focus is on being persecuted and having secret information rather than on an inflated self-assessment relative to peers. Thus, this example is not an instance of illusory superiority.
