Example:
So a bit of background first. Husband and I have been together for 9 years (since high school), married for 4. His sister is older, now in her early 30s and married with a 6 month old daughter. She's a teacher (I have total sympathy for teacher salaries sucking as I'm in education as well) and her husband has a good, salaried job in the automotive industry.

Ever since we've been together, and maybe even before then with her other family members, she always does handmade gifts- really terrible paintings. When she was in her early 20s and in college it was one thing. I get it, I've been a cash strapped college student before too, but it never stopped. We exchange Christmas lists or give indicators as to what we might like every year and we always spend at least a decent amount of money getting her what she asked for (averaging around $50 probably) as well as now for her husband and this year for her daughter. Even as a wedding gift she made us a painting which looked like an 8 year old could have done it. Not even like cool and abstract, just terrible wine and paint night type art. It's sitting in the closet now, never having been hung cause it's horrible but I feel like an asshole if I throw it away.

So we recently asked what they might like for Christmas this year and when she asked what we wanted my husband said "anything on my Amazon wishlist, I'll send you the link" she says "well I already know what I got you isn't on your wishlist cause I made it". Like why even ask us what we want then and UGH another painting!

Don't get me wrong, I think handmade things are great from kids or if you have a particular talent, but otherwise it's not fair to ask people for things that cost actual money and get them and give something unwanted and terrible in return. To be fair we've never expressed these feelings cause it seems mean but also isn't it a given that your adult brother and his wife don't want your terrible paintings? Even if we did want them and like them enough to hang, our house would now be covered in her paintings which is weird too!

To add to that, when we visit and by accounts of everyone else we know in their life, they spend ridiculous amounts of money eating out and buying whatever they want. She even confessed to me that she'd love to quit working and stay home but that they couldn't maintain their current lifestyle that way. No judgment (ok a little judgment)- but if you really want to stay home to raise your child you can't cut back on the other stuff a little?

So AITA if I say something or just continue getting horrible gifts for the rest of my life while spending our money on her and her family?
Inference:
Illusory superiority is a cognitive bias where people overestimate their own abilities or qualities relative to others—for instance, believing one's own performance or traits are above average when, in reality, they are not. The scenario described is mostly a familial conflict concerning the value and nature of gifts. The poster is expressing undervaluation of the handmade paintings (calling them “terrible” and “horrible”) and frustration that the family member continues to present them despite knowing their lack of appeal.

This situation is more about disagreements concerning taste, financial priorities, and gift expectations than it is about someone overrating their own abilities or attributes as being superior to others. While the sister-in-law might truly believe in the sentiment behind her handmade gifts, that belief isn’t an example of illusory superiority; it’s more about personal taste and perhaps a misalignment of expectations rather than a cognitive bias where she thinks she is universally better than others.

Thus, this example does not directly showcase illusory superiority.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I (M32) was driving around with my buddy (M41) and we were discussing a friend of his who he recently spoke with. He was praising how intelligent that guy was and how rare it is to speak with someone who is that sharp. After ragging on how dumb the average person is, he then causally threw out that he believed he was smarter than 95% of the population.

I couldn’t help myself. I suddenly let out a big chuckle followed by 60seconds of friendly interrogation as to why he believed this. It was obvious I had upset him. He’s a very sensitive moody guy who in many ways hasn’t evolved past his teenage angst phase, but still, a ridiculous claim deserves scrutiny. He’s not a dummy but he’s far from a genius. All of our mutual friends would agree.

Most of the time he’s a humble guy but he will occasionally throw out snobby comments about how stupid people are and what a waste most things seem to be. We work in the same field and sometimes when I disagree with him about his methods, he’ll be quick to toss out his counter argument, “You just don’t understand what I’m trying to do.” It’s little comments like that that give me zero qualms about shutting down his feelings of grandiosity whenever they arise.
Inference:
Illusory superiority is a cognitive bias where individuals overestimate their qualities, abilities, or talents relative to others. In the example provided, the friend asserts that he is smarter than 95% of the population. This claim, despite evidence from the mutual friend circle suggesting that he is not a genius, fits the typical pattern of illusory superiority, where one holds an inflated view of one's own capabilities. Therefore, this example is indeed an instance of illusory superiority.

ANSWER: Yes

Example:
Recently, I [25m] was visiting some family, including my cousin [28f], who has a PhD in computer science— relevant later.

For some background info, growing up, I was always seen as the ‘smart’ one in the family, which she resented me for due to wanting that title herself. She was a lot more studious than I am, and got a PhD, whereas I ended my schooling after my bachelors due to not liking specialization. I’m currently a filmmaker that has been surprisingly successful, and she works at a hedge fund doing quant work.

Regarding my opinion on her, I think she’s quite smart in her niche. However, she lacks what I see as traits of a more generalized intelligence— being quick witted, adaptable, open minded, and exploratory. Every truly intelligent person I’ve ever met has been funny and a genuinely interesting person, and I don’t see that in her. She’s more what I would call a ‘sweat’— she works hard, and is talented in her niche, but lacking the originality to be truly intelligent.

Anyhow, when I visited my family, she began needling me about how now she has her PhD (the last time I had seen her, she was still in her program) I had to admit that she was smarter than me. I shrugged it off mostly, but she began demanding that I ‘admit’ she’s smarter than her, so I responded that PhD or no PhD, I don’t think she’s exceptionally intelligent or more intelligent than I am.

This caused her to fly off the handle, and she started yelling that I was just a jealous AH who couldn’t accept that a woman was smarter than her. She furthered that she was confident and secure in the fact she was more intelligent than I was.

I pointed out that if she was so secure in her own intelligence, my disputing it wouldn’t bother her that much, and the fact she needed me to validate her shows she’s not particularly confident. She just got angry again, called me an AH, and stormed off.

AITA? I think she shouldn’t have started a conversation about her intelligence if She just wanted me to sing her praises
Inference:
Illusory superiority refers to a cognitive bias where people tend to overestimate their own qualities or abilities relative to others—often rating themselves as above average, even when that statistically isn’t possible. In many classic examples, one might think “I’m a better driver than most” or “I’m smarter than the average person,” regardless of objective evidence.

In the example provided, the cousin is insisting that she’s the smarter one because of her PhD and her field, and she demands external validation of that claim. At first glance it may seem like she is asserting her superiority, which is one aspect of the phenomenon. However, there are a few reasons why this scenario may not be a textbook instance of illusory superiority:

1. Credentials versus Bias: The cousin’s belief in her intellectual superiority is based on her accomplishments (earning a PhD and landing a quantitative role). While credentials can boost confidence, having a PhD in a specialized area does not automatically translate into the grand, generalized sense of superiority characterizing illusory superiority. If her belief were an overestimation that was disconnected from any real ability or achievement, it would be clearer—but here her credentials are, at least in part, legitimate. 

2. Domain-Specific vs. Global Intelligence: Illusory superiority typically implies that a person globally overestimates their abilities. In this scenario, the cousin seems to be defending her intelligence within the narrow scope of her field (quant work), while the narrator criticizes her for lacking a more “generalized” or creative intelligence. This isn’t a classic “better-than-average” on all counts but rather a dispute over what counts as valuable intelligence.

3. Insecurity and Need for Validation: A key remark by the narrator is that if the cousin were as secure as she claimed to be, she wouldn’t need external validation or react so strongly to opposing views. This indicates that her claim might be less about a cool, unbiased evaluation and more a reaction to a perceived challenge, which can sometimes accompany self-enhancement issues—but isn’t in itself the prototypical case of illusory superiority.

4. Interpersonal Dynamics: The conflict seems rooted in longstanding family dynamics and rivalries (with both parties holding pride in their own achievements) rather than in a clear, isolated instance of one party’s disconnection from reality about their abilities. Illusory superiority is usually observed as a stable cognitive bias across various domains, not a heated moment about a specific attribute.

So, while the cousin’s behavior might reflect elements of inflated self-view or a need to assert superiority when challenged, the example as a whole is more about conflicting definitions of “intelligence” and familial rivalry than it is about the cognitive bias known as illusory superiority.

ANSWER: No

Example:
I imagine I'm gonna get raked over the coals for this one.

So, my fiancé (maybe not for much longer) and I were on our way back from a vacation recently. It was a great time and everything went off without an issue. That is until we started boarding the plane. Now, I know better, I only bring a small backpack with essentials incase I don't get my checked bags. I can survive out of this backpack and it will always pass baggage check for size and weight (done a lot of traveling so why fight the system). My fiancé didn't wanna listen to my advice and chose to bring basically a regular full-size bag that barely fits the standards of carry on, but generally speaking the airline worker doesn't wanna deal with the trouble and allows it through. But this time the airline worker was not having it. It was a packed flight, we were boarding last in economy and it was just a shit show. I got through just fine first with my little backpack, but I could hear the argument from the boarding tunnel thingy and it was getting heated. I was about to go back and try to smooth it out but my fiancé rushed pass and just boarded plane, I assumed not having heard it super clearly that the attended had given in and let her on. That was not the case!

So we found our seats and settled in. I was pretty tired and I could tell she was upset so I just kinda tucked into the window and put my hat down and tried to take a nap. But soon after the airline worker and a cop shows up and they are not fucking around, and want her off the plane. She tries to plead and cry, etc. but they are not having it. And maybe in a moment of panic or just plain self preservation...the cop asks if we're together, and I blurt out, "NO!" shaking my head emphatically. I got kill dagger eyes from her as she shot up and grabbed her bag and followed the cop out. She was also swearing and screaming the whole way out.

Now, obviously this is well after the event I'm posting this. But when she did eventually get home (she caught next flight out with the bag checked, lol), I was there to pick her up. She obviously thought I was the asshole, and to be honest almost everyone I know thinks I'm an asshole except my boss and co workers, who for context were very much relying on me to be back on time, which I gave my word I would, for a really important project that was time sensitive. They were all very happy I didn't get thrown off too.

So, am I the asshole for this self preservation?

AITA?
Inference:
Illusory superiority is the cognitive bias where people tend to believe they are above average in qualities like competence, intelligence, or moral behavior, even when statistically that shouldn’t be the case. In the example, the narrator is explaining a contentious series of events, mostly framing his actions as understandable given the circumstances and emphasizing how his choices helped him meet his responsibilities. However, although one might say he’s self-serving in his narrative or just using rationalizations to minimize his faults (which may align with self-serving bias), this particular account isn’t clearly an illustration of illusory superiority.

In an instance of illusory superiority, the person would typically assert or imply that they’re significantly better or more capable than others, often without sufficient justification. In this case, while the narrator defends his own behavior—even to the point of dismissing or devaluing his partner’s actions—there isn’t a strong indication that he overestimates his own ability or virtue in a way that is the hallmark of illusory superiority. Instead, his account centers around self-preservation and blaming circumstance (or his partner) rather than a broad assertion about his own overall superiority relative to an average person.

Thus, while his narrative may display various biases (like self-serving bias and perhaps even an unwillingness to accept blame), it doesn’t neatly fit into the definition of illusory superiority.

ANSWER: No

Most of the time he’s a humble guy but he will occasionally throw out snobby comments about how stupid people are and what a waste most things seem to be. We work in the same field and sometimes when I disagree with him about his methods, he’ll be quick to toss out his counter argument, “You just don’t understand what I’m trying to do.” It’s little comments like that that give me zero qualms about shutting down his feelings of grandiosity whenever they arise.
Inference:
Illusory superiority, also known as the "above average effect," occurs when individuals overestimate their own qualities and abilities relative to others. In the provided scenario, the friend (M41) claims to be smarter than 95% of the population. This is a classic example of illusory superiority, as it represents an inflated self-assessment of intelligence compared to the general population.

The user's reaction—challenging this assertion and expressing disbelief—highlights the recognition of this cognitive bias. The friend's occasional snobbish comments and assertions of intellectual superiority further reinforce the presence of illusory superiority in his behavior. While the user themselves is not exhibiting this bias, the friend's claim clearly embodies the concept.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
Recently, I [25m] was visiting some family, including my cousin [28f], who has a PhD in computer science— relevant later.

For some background info, growing up, I was always seen as the ‘smart’ one in the family, which she resented me for due to wanting that title herself. She was a lot more studious than I am, and got a PhD, whereas I ended my schooling after my bachelors due to not liking specialization. I’m currently a filmmaker that has been surprisingly successful, and she works at a hedge fund doing quant work.

Regarding my opinion on her, I think she’s quite smart in her niche. However, she lacks what I see as traits of a more generalized intelligence— being quick witted, adaptable, open minded, and exploratory. Every truly intelligent person I’ve ever met has been funny and a genuinely interesting person, and I don’t see that in her. She’s more what I would call a ‘sweat’— she works hard, and is talented in her niche, but lacking the originality to be truly intelligent.

Anyhow, when I visited my family, she began needling me about how now she has her PhD (the last time I had seen her, she was still in her program) I had to admit that she was smarter than me. I shrugged it off mostly, but she began demanding that I ‘admit’ she’s smarter than her, so I responded that PhD or no PhD, I don’t think she’s exceptionally intelligent or more intelligent than I am.

This caused her to fly off the handle, and she started yelling that I was just a jealous AH who couldn’t accept that a woman was smarter than her. She furthered that she was confident and secure in the fact she was more intelligent than I was.

I pointed out that if she was so secure in her own intelligence, my disputing it wouldn’t bother her that much, and the fact she needed me to validate her shows she’s not particularly confident. She just got angry again, called me an AH, and stormed off.

AITA? I think she shouldn’t have started a conversation about her intelligence if She just wanted me to sing her praises
Inference:
Illusory superiority is a cognitive bias where individuals overestimate their own qualities and abilities compared to others. In the scenario you've described, the dynamic primarily revolves around shifting perceptions of intelligence within a family context.

Initially, you were perceived as the "smart" one, a title your cousin resented. After obtaining her PhD, she seeks validation of her intelligence, insisting that she is smarter than you. However, you recognize that her intelligence is specialized, and you challenge her assertion by highlighting other aspects of generalized intelligence that you value.

In this interaction, the cousin is not necessarily overestimating her own intelligence; rather, she is seeking acknowledgment of her actual academic achievements. Her demand for validation and the ensuing conflict suggest issues related to insecurity or the desire for recognition, rather than a cognitive bias like illusory superiority.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
A few months ago, I told my friends and family that I bought a new couch. I don’t even really know why I said it. We were at a dinner, everyone was talking about their apartments, new furniture, little upgrades, and I just… blurted it out. I said I got this “gorgeous L-shaped gray velvet couch” and everyone got excited. I showed them a photo I found on Pinterest and said it was mine.

I thought it would end there. Just a harmless white lie, right?

Wrong.

People started asking to come over. One of my friends was moving and asked if she could crash on the “fancy new couch” for a few nights. My mom kept asking for pictures. My cousin (who I’m not even that close with!) came over unannounced and asked, “Wait, where’s the couch?” I panicked and said it hadn’t been delivered yet. That bought me time—but not much.

Then the lies started snowballing. I claimed there were shipping delays, then that the company canceled the order, then that I got scammed. And that one especially hit hard, because suddenly people were sympathetic. My dad offered to give me money for a new couch. A coworker gave me a “warning” about the company I had supposedly bought it from. I started digging myself deeper with every lie, and I could feel the walls closing in.

Eventually, it all unraveled. One of my friends found the exact couch photo I’d used—same angle, same room, literally a Pinterest pin. She confronted me privately, and I admitted everything. She was confused more than anything. She asked why I would lie. And the truth is, I don’t even know. I just wanted to feel like I had something nice. Like I was doing okay. Like I wasn’t the only one in our group who didn’t have their life together.

Word got around. Now people don’t trust me. I’ve become “the couch liar.”, I’ve lost two friendships over this. One friend told me she felt like I manipulated everyone. Another hasn’t responded to my texts since.

I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.

So yeah. Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life? Or did I just finally hit the consequences of a dumb lie?
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion in which a person magnifies a setback or mistake to assume it will have overwhelmingly negative, all-encompassing consequences—often envisioning the worst-case scenario even when the situation is not as dire.

In the account you provided, the individual describes how a small lie about buying a couch snowballed into numerous complications, leading to strained relationships and a loss of trust among friends and family. The narrative walks through the unfolding chain of events that actually occurred (friends coming over, eventual confrontation, etc.), which are real and consequential outcomes of the lie.

However, the key element to watch is the internal reaction and interpretation. Toward the end, the speaker says, “I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.” Later they wonder, “Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life?” This line of questioning—feeling that the entire self-worth and social life are ruined based on one incident—is reminiscent of catastrophizing. The speaker is taking one mistake and extrapolating it into a belief that “my life is ruined,” even though while there are negative consequences, the overall situation might not be as all-encompassing as it feels in the moment.

Thus, while the chain of events is genuine, the interpretation (feeling that one's life is completely ruined because of this single lie) is an instance of catastrophizing. The cognitive leap from “I made a bad decision” to “my entire life and social standing are irreparably destroyed” is a hallmark of this type of thinking.

ANSWER: Yes

Long story short, I have a friend let's call her H who proposed we get together, I was down and started saving up for Money to contribute. I thought about it and decided I wouldn't go, and here's were I was called the asshole,I asked for my money back since I wasn't going to be attending. H and her friends are calling me a petty person because me backing out will do damage to their budget and so on. But I don't see the problem here, so reddit am I really being unreasonable here??

Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where one tends to imagine a minor setback or problem will lead to overwhelmingly disastrous consequences. The person is disappointed, concerned about being left out because of dietary restrictions, and frustrated by a dismissive response, but there isn’t evidence that they’re automatically assuming that a single disagreement will spiral into an all-encompassing disaster.

The thoughts expressed in the example appear to be reactions to a situation that directly impacts them (their health/allergies and the event’s planning). They decide to change their plans, ask for a refund, and feel that the reaction of others is unfair. While they might be feeling a range of intense emotions, the response does not show the hallmark signs of catastrophizing—namely, expecting the worst-case scenario without sufficient basis.

Example:
I (M32) was driving around with my buddy (M41) and we were discussing a friend of his who he recently spoke with. He was praising how intelligent that guy was and how rare it is to speak with someone who is that sharp. After ragging on how dumb the average person is, he then causally threw out that he believed he was smarter than 95% of the population.

I couldn’t help myself. I suddenly let out a big chuckle followed by 60seconds of friendly interrogation as to why he believed this. It was obvious I had upset him. He’s a very sensitive moody guy who in many ways hasn’t evolved past his teenage angst phase, but still, a ridiculous claim deserves scrutiny. He’s not a dummy but he’s far from a genius. All of our mutual friends would agree.

Most of the time he’s a humble guy but he will occasionally throw out snobby comments about how stupid people are and what a waste most things seem to be. We work in the same field and sometimes when I disagree with him about his methods, he’ll be quick to toss out his counter argument, “You just don’t understand what I’m trying to do.” It’s little comments like that that give me zero qualms about shutting down his feelings of grandiosity whenever they arise.
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion in which an individual tends to jump to the worst possible conclusion or exaggerate the negative potential outcomes of a situation, often leading to feelings of anxiety or panic. In the provided narrative, while there is some snarky banter and criticism of a friend’s grandiose claims, there isn’t any evidence of the speaker assuming the worst-case scenario or exaggerating negative outcomes beyond what is observable. Instead, the speaker is specifically critiquing a remark and reacting by questioning the friend's reasons for his grandiosity in a somewhat humorous and critical way. The situation described does not involve the speaker projecting an irreversible calamity or diving into a pessimistic spiral; rather, it’s an interpersonal critique. Thus, it does not qualify as catastrophizing.

ANSWER: No

Example:
AITA for telling my girlfriend she 'ruined' my night by insisting she comes along?

My girlfriend and I (both 20f) have been dating for a year. My girlfriend-Jane and I have separate friend groups. Jane doesn't get along with my friends, yet insists she is brought along to our nights out/in. It's incredibly uncomfortable because whilst she's also a woman, these get-togethers are no-partners allowed parties. Plus, she doesn't get along with anyone so it's super awkward. I was invited out to one of their parties, and Jane got upset that I'm going without her. I'll be gone from 10am Friday to afternoon on Saturday. She has no issue with both of us going, but without her, it's an issue.
I said I'd leave later and try to get back earlier, but she wouldn't have it either. I ended up bringing her along and it was a nightmare. The mood was brought down and no one really had fun as all my friends seemed to be walking on eggshells around her.

When we got back, she kept gloating about how much fun she had, but I felt the opposite. I said 'well, I'm glad someone had fun.'. She got upset and asked what I meant. I explained that it was a friend night in, and she wasn't invited. She got super upset and pulled some crap about how it's 'toxic' that I want to have a night out without her. She says she's hurt that I 1) didn't want her there and 2) that I said she ruined the night.

I just wanted to spend time with my friends, 1 on 1. AITA?
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion in which a person views a situation as far worse than it really is, exaggerating the negative consequences and often imagining extreme, disastrous outcomes from relatively normal events. In typical instances of catastrophizing, rather than simply noting disappointment or frustration, the individual jumps to conclusions about the absolute disaster that the event represents (for example, thinking that one small mistake will lead to total failure or ruin overall wellbeing or life prospects).

In the AITA example provided, the narrator expresses that his night was “ruined” by his girlfriend’s insistence on coming along. While saying that one’s night was ruined might seem like a strong reaction, it doesn’t necessarily constitute catastrophizing on its own. The narrator is expressing genuine regret over how the social situation turned out—his friends felt uncomfortable and the night wasn’t enjoyable—but he does not go on to suggest that this one instance will have catastrophic or life-altering consequences. He doesn’t claim that because of this night everything is a disaster or that his life or relationship is doomed because of it.

Thus, while the language (“ruined my night”) might be seen as an overreaction in a social context, it does not rise to the level of the extreme, all-encompassing negative predictions that characterize catastrophizing.

ANSWER: No

Example:
Throwaway bc my husband knows my acc

My (25M) husband “Harry” (26M) has been in bed with the flu for about a week now. He’s quite miserable (headache, nausea, fairly high fever) so I’ve been working from home to be able to keep an eye on his throughout the day.

It was my younger siblings’ (twins, 9) birthday on Saturday and my husband and I were invited over to my parent’s house to celebrate.

On Friday, Harry told me he wasn’t feeling up to a children’s birthday party, which is understandable. I wouldn’t necessarily want to be around rowdy children if I was sick either.

So I decided I’d go there on my own, bring over the presents, stay for an hour or two and be back home before dinner. To be honest, after spending days holed up in our flat taking care of my husband, I was quite grateful for the opportunity to get outside for a few hours.

When I told Harry as much, he didn’t comment on it but he did seem a bit grumpy afterwards.

Saturday came and I drove over to my parent’s house in the afternoon (they live about 20 minutes away). I left Harry with some painkillers, tea and tissues on the nightstand so he wouldn’t need to get up while I was gone. I told him he could call me in case something happened, though.

The party went great and I got back home after about 2 hours without any calls from Harry so I assumed everything had gone well.

However, he was frowning all evening and when I asked whether he was alright, he called me selfish for leaving him alone and accused me of not caring about his well-being. He told my I should’ve stayed home with him instead of having fun on my own while he was miserable. He has since been giving me the silent treatment whenever I tried to talk to him about it.

It’s been a few days and I thought he’d have calmed down by now but he’s still sulking and I’m starting to wonder whether his reaction is reasonable and I’m the AH here.
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where a person expects the worst possible outcome or exaggerates the negative aspects of a situation without concrete evidence that such extremes will occur. In the example provided, the issue centers on a conflict between partners regarding expected behavior during illness and obligations within the relationship. Although the husband’s reaction might be seen as overblown or emotionally charged, it isn’t necessarily the result of catastrophizing in a clinical sense; rather, it seems more like an interpersonal conflict where one partner's expectations (or disappointments) are leading to emotional responses.

For instance, when catastrophizing occurs, one might think along the lines of “If you leave me even for a short time, our relationship is doomed” or “This small event will lead to terrible consequences.” In the narrative, while the husband does express hurt and anger by calling the partner selfish and giving the silent treatment, there isn’t clear evidence that he is projecting a chain of catastrophic outcomes or magnifying the event to imply that everything is ruined. His reaction reflects emotional distress and perhaps issues around dependency and expectations, rather than a cognitive distortion of catastrophizing.

Based on this assessment:

ANSWER: No

Example:
I, 26F, have been married to my husband, 28M for 2 years. We have been together for 4 years in total. I love my husband more than I can even express in words and our relationship never really had any major dips until last weekend.

In high school, I dated a guy, who we'll call Dan. Just to be clear, this is not my husband. I cannot remember exactly how long the relationship lasted, but it was no more than a year. We did a lot during the time we were together, a lot of our first experiences with some things were together. Things did not work out in the end as we both wanted different things in life so we ended the relationship and moved on from eachother.

My sister, 29F, ended up befriending Dan in college and they have gotten very close. Since it's been so long since our relationship ended, I really do not care, neither does Dan. He is very close with my family because he gets invited to so many of the family gatherings.

Last weekend it was my mothers birthday and there was a party thrown for her, which my entire family attended, along with family friends. Of course, my sister invited Dan. My husband and I usually do not attend birthday parties, but I insisted that we go to this one seeing as it was for my own mother. My husband agreed.


My husband works a very demanding job so he is normally unable to attend family gatherings, and so he's never met Dan, nor have I told him about my history with him.


At the party, Dan was introduced to my husband as my ex. It was my sister who introduced them while I was in the kitchen speaking to family. When I came back, my husband seemed a little off and when I asked him what was wrong he just brushed it off and wouldn't answer me.


During the dinner, my husband seemed distant and so I asked him again if he was feeling okay. He immediately stood up from his seat and seemed upset that I hadn't told him about Dan. I tried to explain to him that I didn't feel the need to but he didn't listen. He completely lost it and started to call me names that he has never called me before and he even said he didn't know if he could trust me anymore. This was all in front of my entire family and family friends.


I have been ignoring him since the party. He seems to feel very guilty and he keeps trying to apologise to me.

AITA?
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where someone takes a single event or ambiguous piece of evidence and immediately assumes the worst possible outcome, often exaggerating negative consequences far beyond what the situation warrants.

In the example provided, we see a recounting of a specific incident at a family gathering. The narrator explains that her husband reacted very strongly after learning about her past with Dan. While his reaction was highly charged and might be considered extreme or disproportionate, the narrative itself is a factual description of what happened rather than a series of “if this happens, then that will happen” statements that predict catastrophic outcomes without evidence.

A person who catastrophizes might say things like “This means our marriage is ruined forever” or “I’m sure nothing good will ever come from this—it’s the beginning of the end.” In this account, the narrator does not appear to be engaging in that type of thought process. Even if one were to consider the husband’s reaction, his immediate emotional outburst – calling names and questioning trust – is more a demonstration of strong immediate emotion rather than a systematic cognitive distortion of assuming the worst-case scenario from a small trigger.

Additionally, the narrator is not exaggerating or spinning the event into a prediction of endless disaster; instead, she is reporting her experience and seems to be looking for perspective on the behavior that occurred. The focus is on accountability and understanding the motivations behind the husband’s behavior, rather than imagining an apocalyptic outcome.

Thus, while there is intense emotional content in the interaction, it does not clearly exemplify the classic pattern of catastrophizing. The narrative way of describing the incident does not reflect a thought process of turning the situation into an inevitable catastrophe without evidence.

ANSWER: No

Example:
A few months ago, I told my friends and family that I bought a new couch. I don’t even really know why I said it. We were at a dinner, everyone was talking about their apartments, new furniture, little upgrades, and I just… blurted it out. I said I got this “gorgeous L-shaped gray velvet couch” and everyone got excited. I showed them a photo I found on Pinterest and said it was mine.

I thought it would end there. Just a harmless white lie, right?

Wrong.

People started asking to come over. One of my friends was moving and asked if she could crash on the “fancy new couch” for a few nights. My mom kept asking for pictures. My cousin (who I’m not even that close with!) came over unannounced and asked, “Wait, where’s the couch?” I panicked and said it hadn’t been delivered yet. That bought me time—but not much.

Then the lies started snowballing. I claimed there were shipping delays, then that the company canceled the order, then that I got scammed. And that one especially hit hard, because suddenly people were sympathetic. My dad offered to give me money for a new couch. A coworker gave me a “warning” about the company I had supposedly bought it from. I started digging myself deeper with every lie, and I could feel the walls closing in.

Eventually, it all unraveled. One of my friends found the exact couch photo I’d used—same angle, same room, literally a Pinterest pin. She confronted me privately, and I admitted everything. She was confused more than anything. She asked why I would lie. And the truth is, I don’t even know. I just wanted to feel like I had something nice. Like I was doing okay. Like I wasn’t the only one in our group who didn’t have their life together.

Word got around. Now people don’t trust me. I’ve become “the couch liar.”, I’ve lost two friendships over this. One friend told me she felt like I manipulated everyone. Another hasn’t responded to my texts since.

I feel like my whole social circle looks at me differently. Like I’m fragile, or fake, or both. And the thing is… they’re not wrong.

So yeah. Am I overreacting to think this ruined my life? Or did I just finally hit the consequences of a dumb lie?
Inference:
The scenario you've described involves a series of escalating lies that led to significant social repercussions. To determine whether this is an instance of **catastrophizing**, we need to understand what catastrophizing entails.

**Catastrophizing** is a cognitive distortion where an individual **expects or imagines the worst possible outcome** in a situation, often blowing things out of proportion beyond what the reality warrants. It typically involves anticipating disaster, viewing situations as far more threatening than they actually are.

In your example:

1. **Initial Lie**: You told a small lie about having a new couch in a social setting.
2. **Escalation**: To maintain the lie, you created additional falsehoods.
3. **Consequences**: These lies led to loss of trust, damaged relationships, and a negative reputation.

The key point here is that the consequences you faced were **real and direct results** of the actions you took (telling lies), not merely exaggerated fears about what could happen. While the outcome is undoubtedly negative, it stems from your attempts to sustain the initial deception rather than an unreasonable exaggeration of potential outcomes.

Therefore, this situation illustrates more about the **chain reaction of dishonesty and its tangible consequences** rather than a case of catastrophizing.

**ANSWER: No**

You chose to back out of the event and request your money back because you could not partake in the provided food options. Your decision appears to be based on practical considerations regarding your health and well-being rather than an exaggerated fear of negative outcomes.

Furthermore, while H and her friends expressed frustration, labeling you as "petty," this reaction reflects their perspective on the situation rather than indicating that you are catastrophizing. Your choice to prioritize your dietary needs and stand by it suggests a rational and self-considerate approach rather than an overestimation of negative consequences.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
I (M32) was driving around with my buddy (M41) and we were discussing a friend of his who he recently spoke with. He was praising how intelligent that guy was and how rare it is to speak with someone who is that sharp. After ragging on how dumb the average person is, he then causally threw out that he believed he was smarter than 95% of the population.

I couldn’t help myself. I suddenly let out a big chuckle followed by 60seconds of friendly interrogation as to why he believed this. It was obvious I had upset him. He’s a very sensitive moody guy who in many ways hasn’t evolved past his teenage angst phase, but still, a ridiculous claim deserves scrutiny. He’s not a dummy but he’s far from a genius. All of our mutual friends would agree.

Most of the time he’s a humble guy but he will occasionally throw out snobby comments about how stupid people are and what a waste most things seem to be. We work in the same field and sometimes when I disagree with him about his methods, he’ll be quick to toss out his counter argument, “You just don’t understand what I’m trying to do.” It’s little comments like that that give me zero qualms about shutting down his feelings of grandiosity whenever they arise.
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where an individual expects the worst possible outcome or dramatically exaggerates the significance of negative events. In the provided example, the narrator is reacting to a friend's claim of being smarter than 95% of the population. The narrator expresses skepticism and challenges this assertion but does not necessarily anticipate or expect the worst-case scenario from this interaction. Instead, the focus is on addressing what the narrator perceives as an inflated sense of intelligence in their friend.

The behavior described—criticizing or questioning someone's self-assessment—is more aligned with interpersonal conflict or frustration rather than catastrophizing. The narrator is not magnifying the potential negative outcomes of the situation but is instead challenging the friend's overestimation of intelligence.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
AITA for telling my girlfriend she 'ruined' my night by insisting she comes along?

My girlfriend and I (both 20f) have been dating for a year. My girlfriend-Jane and I have separate friend groups. Jane doesn't get along with my friends, yet insists she is brought along to our nights out/in. It's incredibly uncomfortable because whilst she's also a woman, these get-togethers are no-partners allowed parties. Plus, she doesn't get along with anyone so it's super awkward. I was invited out to one of their parties, and Jane got upset that I'm going without her. I'll be gone from 10am Friday to afternoon on Saturday. She has no issue with both of us going, but without her, it's an issue.
I said I'd leave later and try to get back earlier, but she wouldn't have it either. I ended up bringing her along and it was a nightmare. The mood was brought down and no one really had fun as all my friends seemed to be walking on eggshells around her.

When we got back, she kept gloating about how much fun she had, but I felt the opposite. I said 'well, I'm glad someone had fun.'. She got upset and asked what I meant. I explained that it was a friend night in, and she wasn't invited. She got super upset and pulled some crap about how it's 'toxic' that I want to have a night out without her. She says she's hurt that I 1) didn't want her there and 2) that I said she ruined the night.

I just wanted to spend time with my friends, 1 on 1. AITA?
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where an individual expects or focuses on the worst possible outcomes, often magnifying the negative aspects of a situation beyond their actual impact.

In the provided scenario, the user describes a situation where they felt that bringing their girlfriend, Jane, to a friends' party "ruined" the night. This statement suggests that the user is viewing the outcome of the event in an exaggeratedly negative light. While it’s understandable that the presence of someone who doesn't get along with the group can create discomfort, labeling the entire night as "ruined" may be an overstatement. This could indicate that the user is engaging in catastrophizing by amplifying the negative impact of the situation.

**ANSWER: Yes**

Example:
I imagine I'm gonna get raked over the coals for this one.

So, my fiancé (maybe not for much longer) and I were on our way back from a vacation recently. It was a great time and everything went off without an issue. That is until we started boarding the plane. Now, I know better, I only bring a small backpack with essentials incase I don't get my checked bags. I can survive out of this backpack and it will always pass baggage check for size and weight (done a lot of traveling so why fight the system). My fiancé didn't wanna listen to my advice and chose to bring basically a regular full-size bag that barely fits the standards of carry on, but generally speaking the airline worker doesn't wanna deal with the trouble and allows it through. But this time the airline worker was not having it. It was a packed flight, we were boarding last in economy and it was just a shit show. I got through just fine first with my little backpack, but I could hear the argument from the boarding tunnel thingy and it was getting heated. I was about to go back and try to smooth it out but my fiancé rushed pass and just boarded plane, I assumed not having heard it super clearly that the attended had given in and let her on. That was not the case!

So we found our seats and settled in. I was pretty tired and I could tell she was upset so I just kinda tucked into the window and put my hat down and tried to take a nap. But soon after the airline worker and a cop shows up and they are not fucking around, and want her off the plane. She tries to plead and cry, etc. but they are not having it. And maybe in a moment of panic or just plain self preservation...the cop asks if we're together, and I blurt out, "NO!" shaking my head emphatically. I got kill dagger eyes from her as she shot up and grabbed her bag and followed the cop out. She was also swearing and screaming the whole way out.

Now, obviously this is well after the event I'm posting this. But when she did eventually get home (she caught next flight out with the bag checked, lol), I was there to pick her up. She obviously thought I was the asshole, and to be honest almost everyone I know thinks I'm an asshole except my boss and co workers, who for context were very much relying on me to be back on time, which I gave my word I would, for a really important project that was time sensitive. They were all very happy I didn't get thrown off too.

So, am I the asshole for this self preservation?

AITA?
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where an individual anticipates the worst possible outcome in a situation, often without sufficient evidence to support such a dire expectation. It involves magnifying the potential negative consequences, leading to heightened anxiety and distress.

In the scenario you've provided, the expression "I imagine I'm gonna get raked over the coals for this one" indicates an anticipation of negative judgment or criticism. However, as the story unfolds, the anticipated negative outcome does manifest to some extent—your fiancé faces consequences, and others perceive you unfavorably. This alignment between your expectations and the actual outcomes suggests that your prediction wasn't unfounded or irrational.

Catastrophizing typically involves expecting excessively negative results that are unlikely or disproportionate to the situation. In your case, while you did foresee negative repercussions, they were based on the unfolding events rather than an exaggerated or unjustified fear.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
Throwaway bc my husband knows my acc

My (25M) husband “Harry” (26M) has been in bed with the flu for about a week now. He’s quite miserable (headache, nausea, fairly high fever) so I’ve been working from home to be able to keep an eye on his throughout the day.

It was my younger siblings’ (twins, 9) birthday on Saturday and my husband and I were invited over to my parent’s house to celebrate.

On Friday, Harry told me he wasn’t feeling up to a children’s birthday party, which is understandable. I wouldn’t necessarily want to be around rowdy children if I was sick either.

So I decided I’d go there on my own, bring over the presents, stay for an hour or two and be back home before dinner. To be honest, after spending days holed up in our flat taking care of my husband, I was quite grateful for the opportunity to get outside for a few hours.

When I told Harry as much, he didn’t comment on it but he did seem a bit grumpy afterwards.

Saturday came and I drove over to my parent’s house in the afternoon (they live about 20 minutes away). I left Harry with some painkillers, tea and tissues on the nightstand so he wouldn’t need to get up while I was gone. I told him he could call me in case something happened, though.

The party went great and I got back home after about 2 hours without any calls from Harry so I assumed everything had gone well.

However, he was frowning all evening and when I asked whether he was alright, he called me selfish for leaving him alone and accused me of not caring about his well-being. He told my I should’ve stayed home with him instead of having fun on my own while he was miserable. He has since been giving me the silent treatment whenever I tried to talk to him about it.

It’s been a few days and I thought he’d have calmed down by now but he’s still sulking and I’m starting to wonder whether his reaction is reasonable and I’m the AH here.
Inference:
Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion where an individual expects the worst possible outcome in a situation, often without sufficient evidence to support such a bleak outlook. In the scenario you've provided, Harry's reaction to his wife attending a children's birthday party while he's ill seems more aligned with feelings of abandonment, frustration, or emotional distress rather than catastrophizing.

Harry was already in a vulnerable state due to his illness, and his strong emotional reaction might stem from feeling neglected or unsupported rather than from anticipating an extreme negative outcome like harm or disaster. There's no indication that he expected the worst possible scenario to occur because his wife went to the party.

**ANSWER: No**

Example:
I, 26F, have been married to my husband, 28M for 2 years. We have been together for 4 years in total. I love my husband more than I can even express in words and our relationship never really had any major dips until last weekend.

In high school, I dated a guy, who we'll call Dan. Just to be clear, this is not my husband. I cannot remember exactly how long the relationship lasted, but it was no more than a year. We did a lot during the time we were together, a lot of our first experiences with some things were together. Things did not work out in the end as we both wanted different things in life so we ended the relationship and moved on from eachother.

My sister, 29F, ended up befriending Dan in college and they have gotten very close. Since it's been so long since our relationship ended, I really do not care, neither does Dan. He is very close with my family because he gets invited to so many of the family gatherings.

Last weekend it was my mothers birthday and there was a party thrown for her, which my entire family attended, along with family friends. Of course, my sister invited Dan. My husband and I usually do not attend birthday parties, but I insisted that we go to this one seeing as it was for my own mother. My husband agreed.


My husband works a very demanding job so he is normally unable to attend family gatherings, and so he's never met Dan, nor have I told him about my history with him.


At the party, Dan was introduced to my husband as my ex. It was my sister who introduced them while I was in the kitchen speaking to family. When I came back, my husband seemed a little off and when I asked him what was wrong he just brushed it off and wouldn't answer me.


During the dinner, my husband seemed distant and so I asked him again if he was feeling okay. He immediately stood up from his seat and seemed upset that I hadn't told him about Dan. I tried to explain to him that I didn't feel the need to but he didn't listen. He completely lost it and started to call me names that he has never called me before and he even said he didn't know if he could trust me anymore. This was all in front of my entire family and family friends.


I have been ignoring him since the party. He seems to feel very guilty and he keeps trying to apologise to me.

AITA?
Inference:
Yes, the scenario described is an example of catastrophizing. Catastrophizing involves expecting the worst possible outcome from a situation, often blowing things out of proportion. In this case, the husband reacts extremely negatively upon meeting his wife's ex, assuming that not being informed beforehand signifies a breach of trust. Rather than addressing his feelings calmly or seeking clarification, he rapidly escalates the situation by calling his wife names and expressing doubt about their trust, which reflects an exaggerated and disproportionate reaction to the event.

This behavior indicates that he is likely anticipating the worst-case scenario without sufficient cause, a hallmark of catastrophizing. Instead of engaging in a constructive conversation about his feelings, he allows his anxiety to drive an intense and damaging response.

ANSWER: Yes
